name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on 3 October 2013, 366 people lost their lives off Lampedusa in an attempt to reach our coasts. The then government responded by launching the largest humanitarian mission in the Mediterranean, Mare Nostrum. My thoughts today are not only with the victims, but also with those who are committed, every day, to saving lives, to the women and men of the Italian Coast Guard, to the mayors engaged in reception and integration, to NGOs, unfortunately increasingly criminalized for their humanitarian activity.  I would like this date to be remembered as Remembrance Day to honour all the men, women and children who lost their lives because they were forced to leave their country.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statement on the rule of law in Romania (2018/2844(SDR)).

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, you have invited the Presidency to take part in this debate. To begin with, I would like to underline the importance of common values, such as democracy, the rule of law and human rights, as cornerstones of the European Union. It is crucial that every Member State respects, protects and promotes them. Values like the rule of law and the separation of powers are not negotiable and have to be at the heart of our attention. It is of great importance to stay in constant dialogue and to cooperate in order to ensure the best standards and conditions for all citizens. The Council addressed the situation in Romania in its conclusions on the Cooperation and Verification Mechanism adopted on 12 December 2017. The Council reiterated the importance for Romania of focusing on further consolidation and fully addressing the concerns in the recommendations set out by the Commission in its report on progress achieved in Romania under the Cooperation and Verification Mechanism. Of great value, too, are the widely acknowledged opinions of the Venice Commission. The Presidency is aware that the Romanian authorities are in constant contact with both the Venice Commission and the European Commission to find solutions to the issues raised. I trust that all sides are taking the issues raised in this dialogue seriously, as they go to the heart of our commitment to this Union. In this sense we hope that the ongoing exchange between the Romanian authorities and the Commission will continue to prove efficient in addressing these issues in a manner that leaves no doubt about our core values. I will listen attentively to your debate and to the Romanian Prime Minister’s intervention.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, we last discussed the state of the rule of law in Romania in February, and today is a useful opportunity to take stock of the developments which have taken place in the months since. I’ll try to be as concise as I can.  We are all aware that the initiatives taken by the Romanian authorities since 2017 concerning the reform of the justice laws, the criminal procedure and criminal codes and the processes regarding the judiciary have led to concerns from a wide range of stakeholders, both inside and outside Romania and the EU. Many Romanians are worried that the proposed changes to these laws may undermine the longstanding efforts in the fight against corruption and the independence of the judiciary. These are concerns that the Commission very much shares. As Guardian of the Treaties, when it comes to the application of EU law and respect for the EU’s fundamental values, the Commission intervenes on the basis of accurate and thorough legal analysis. It focuses on concrete national measures and engages in a dialogue with the authorities. In these matters, the Commission is politically colour-blind and clinical in our approach. That is the case for Romania just as much as for any other Member State. With your permission, I will set out the main developments in Romania. First, regarding the justice laws: the three justice laws, dating back to 2004, define the status of magistrates and organise the judicial system and the Superior Council of Magistracy. At the end of last year, the laws were amended by the Romanian Parliament. These amendments have been challenged several times before the Constitutional Court. These laws have attracted criticism from institutions inside Romania and from outside. The Council of Europe anti—corruption watchdog, GRECO, adopted a very critical report in March. The Venice Commission’s preliminary opinion, issued in July, was equally critical, raising serious concerns about the independence of the judiciary, its efficiency and its quality. It made a series of recommendations. The final opinion is expected to be adopted later this month. I know this House will pay as close attention to that opinion as we will at the Commission, but unfortunately the fact is that the Romanian Parliament has so far not shown signs of responding to the opinions and recommendations.  Secondly, as concerns the overhaul of the criminal codes and the code of criminal procedures, in May the Romanian Parliament launched a procedure to amend the criminal code and the code of criminal procedures. They were passed in the months of June and July. The Romanian law enforcement authorities, as well as other Member States, expressed their concerns. The amendments have been challenged before the Constitutional Court, and judgments are expected in mid-October. The Venice Commission is preparing another opinion on these amended codes, which is also expected to be adopted later in October. These laws are crucial for the capacity of prosecutors to investigate, and judges to sentence, high-level corruption, as well as for the ability of the judicial system to pursue crime effectively. The climate needed for reform has deteriorated due to the secret protocols between the prosecution and the intelligence services. I call on the Romanian authorities to conduct full and impartial investigations into this issue. Romanians deserve a law enforcement order with all authorities properly supervised and full judicial independence. The reforms of the judicial laws and of the criminal codes are interlinked, and they must be prevented from having a negative impact on the independence of the judiciary and its effectiveness in combating corruption. That is why the Commission has discussed this issue regularly with the Romanian Government at the highest level and has made its concerns public. We have examined the texts passed by the Romanian Parliament to fully assess their impact. We are seeking further clarification on how specific elements of these laws should be interpreted.  Thirdly, as concerns a procedure to dismiss the chief anti-corruption prosecutor and the evaluation of the general prosecutor, I would like to recall that the track record of the anti-corruption prosecution, the so-called DNA, was a central reason for the more positive assessment of Romania that the Commission made back in our Cooperation and Verification Mechanism (CVM) report in January 2017.  (Applause) Moreover, robust and independent procedures for the dismissal and appointment of top prosecutors have always been a key element in our recommendations. The Commission has also recommended that the Romanian authorities seek the help of the Venice Commission in this matter. This remains one of the outstanding recommendations under the Cooperation and Verification Mechanism.   We are following the latest developments in Romania with concern. The independence of Romania’s judicial system and its capacity to fight corruption effectively are essential cornerstones of a strong Romania in the European Union. We have seen substantial progress in the past, but things are now moving backwards in a way that would be damaging for the place that Romania has built as an EU Member State in recent years. The Commission has repeatedly called on the Romanian authorities to rethink their course of action, and to build a broad consensus on the way forward, and I want to reiterate that call today. I would stress once again that the Commission is always ready to cooperate with and support the Romanian authorities in this process. I trust this dialogue will continue, and we will be meticulous and precise in all the elements of the proposals that we would like to discuss with the Romanian authorities. The latest developments are a source of growing concern for the Commission. If adopted without changes, the combined effect of the amended justice laws and the criminal codes would affect the capacity of the justice system, including the prosecution service, to effectively fight against corruption and other crimes. This means backtracking from the situation that led the Commission to make a positive assessment in our report of January 2017. We will report on the situation in our next CVM report next month. You can see what our CVM progress report stated in January 2017 and what it did in the last report in November 2017. The situation has deteriorated. Rest assured that all developments will be thoroughly assessed and reflected in our upcoming report. President Juncker and I issued a joint statement in January this year, setting out our concerns on the direction of travel. We stated clearly at that point that the irreversibility of the progress achieved so far under the CVM is an essential precondition to phase out the mechanism. Without that, we cannot phase out the mechanism. So, while we will continue pursuing our objective of a sustainably positive situation in a dialogue with the Romanian authorities, I wish also to be clear today that the Commission will draw the appropriate conclusions if the amendments to the justice law, criminal codes and laws on conflict of interest and corruption are promulgated without taking account of the concerns. Concretely, this means following up our recommendations from the January 2017 CVM report, and the recommendations expressed by the Venice Commission and GRECO. As the Guardian of the Treaties, we will not hesitate to take action, where necessary, to ensure compatibility with the Treaties. Indeed, the Commission will use all the means at its disposal, be it under CVM or otherwise. The Commission urges Romania to put the reform process back on track immediately. This means going forwards, not backwards, and abstaining from any steps which reverse the progress accomplished over the past years. I honestly think there is still an opportunity to turn things around. The laws are not yet promulgated, and therefore it is not yet too late for the Romanian institutions to act to turn the situation around. As always, we stand ready to help, but the responsibility and the power to deliver change lie firmly with the Romanian institutions. I call again on them to take the right steps now.  (Applause)

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: Prime Minister of Romania. – Mr President, Mr First Vice-President, honourable MEPs, on behalf of Romania, thank you for the invitation. I'm saying from the beginning that I'm not here to answer. I came because I cherish and respect you. I ask, however, for the same value and respect for the Romanian people, whom I represent. I begin with an essential question: for whom do we want to build a viable justice system in Romania? For THE CVM? For institutions? For the magistrates? For politicians? Obviously not. We need to do fair justice for the citizens, they are the beneficiaries of measures in the European Parliament or in the national parliaments. Every discussion must begin from the citizens. Justice must be the guarantee that citizens' laws and rights are respected and whoever violates them will be punished.  It is legitimate to ask: how did the CVM protect Romanian citizens from serious lymitating their rights? There has been a lot of talk in the CVM reports about institutions, about appointments of magistrates, about the fight against corruption. That is very good, but we have not seen anything about human rights violations, about the secret protocols between the intelligence services and the institutions of the judiciary. Under these protocols, millions of Romanians were under the monitoring of the secret services in the name of the fight against corruption. There are court decisions showing how evidence was falsified, how transcripts of intercepts were altered to create guilt, or how witnesses were blackmailed into making false testimony. Nothing about these things in the CVM reports. That does not mean - or does that mean, more to the point, that this mechanism has failed the purpose for which it was created, and I am formally asking to be told who drafted the CVM reports, who provided the data and omitted, negligently or out of bad faith, these unthinkable realities in the European Union. If we are honest, we must start from these serious abuses, because they are taking place within the European Union.  The Venice Commission said that in the Soviet system, the Public Prosecutor's Office was a powerful means of controlling the judiciary. Over the past four years, more than three thousand magistrates have been investigated by DNA. Basically, half of the romanian magistrates had for years cases in which they were probably influenced to give solutions established outside the courtroom. I'm not just saying it. I say this with great concern the associations of magistrates in Romania. Through such forged cases, a judge of the Constitutional Court, a vice-president of the Superior Council of Magistracy, four judges of the High Court, several judges of higher courts, a prosecutor general, a head of the Superior Prosecutor's Office were removed from office. In the end, all were acquitted or files were closed, but they were removed.  The new laws of justice restore independence to judges. No political decision-makers no longer intervene in the appointment and revocation of judges. Independence is total, in no way restricted, and I assure you that we have good faith and will take into account the recommendations of the Venice Commission. There is, however, also a good part of this meeting. Today I informed you all, officially, about the abuses in Romania. From now on, these things cannot be ignored, justice in Romania can no longer be talked about without talking about these abuses, unless a political game is made with no connection to justice. Ask yourself why these things have been hidden from you. Why didn't they tell you anything if everything was legitimate and legal? Ask yourself these questions before you raise the stone against Romania. About the August 10th rally, I'll just say a few words. I see that the Romanian Gendarmerie is accused of intervening at an unauthorized rally against violent demonstrators who tried to occupy the Government building. We have not seen the same position in relation to last week's event in Brussels or with other rallies in France, Spain, Germany, the United Kingdom, when law enforcement intervened with exactly the same means and procedures as those used in Romania. I cannot accept in any way that the Romanian Gendarmerie should be accused of actions and procedures carried out all over Europe. Finally, I ask you this: do not prohibit Romania from what is allowed in other Eu states and do not allow unacceptable things to happen in Romania in other Member States. We want to be your partners, but we want to be your equal partners. No one will ever be able to return Romania from its European journey. Thank.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I would like to welcome Prime Minister Dăncilă to this Parliament, which is also the Parliament of the Romanian people. We are not here to be a court, that is not the role of Parliament, and it never should be. We are here to discuss issues that affect all of us, no matter where we come from – and the independence of the judicial power and the rule of law are indeed European issues of that kind. When Romania joined the Union in 2007 Romanian judges became European judges. This means that they have to defend not only Romanian law but also European law, and that we have to defend them. Europe is not a single market only. We are also a community of shared values and, when our countries signed the Treaties, we signed up to those values too – to all of them. So this is not an east-west issue, this is a European issue. I am telling you this as a representative for Spain, a southern country that has had its own democratic transition. We know how difficult the shift is from dictatorship to democracy. It takes time, it requires sacrifices, it causes pain, it is a difficult journey. That is why we cannot understand the changes proposed by your Government, which are putting in danger the balance of powers and the independence of justice in Romania. That is why we cannot understand the extreme reaction of your Government on that tragic day of 10 August, when thousands of Romanians from the diaspora were trying simply to be heard. And it is why we cannot understand the silence and the complicity of those who are concerned about the rule of law in some countries but not in others. Of course, you can ignore our criticism, but you should never ignore the voice of your own people. Romanians fought for their liberties against communism. They tore down a tyranny and built up a democracy. They are a brave and a decent people, Prime Minister, and you are ignoring them. Tell me, why don’t you want to listen to your people? Tell me, what interests are hidden behind the actions of your Government? Tell me, what are you afraid of? That’s what this Parliament wants and needs to know. Listen to the people’s voice, Prime Minister. They just want integrity, transparency and justice. They just want to have a better future in their own country – not outside it. Nothing more, but nothing less. Prime Minister, you have two options: you can listen to this Parliament, you can listen to the Commission, you can listen to the Romanian Parliament, you can listen to your people; or you can ignore all the democratic controls. But, with all due respect, this Parliament will remain and it will wait by the side of the noble and proud people of Romania. There is not another option for us. You should understand that. (Applause)

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, Prime Minister, I would like to thank the President-in-The-European Commissioner for her work on For us Social Democrats, democracy and the rule of law are at the heart of politics – immovable! These principles are universal and apply to all Member States, whether in the East or the West and without prejudice to who governs! We warmly welcome this debate and are pleased that the Prime Minister is here. We are concerned about the reports that are reaching us from Romania, and we want a detailed analysis of the situation without any ifs and buts. Not because we are against Romania, but because we have the greatest interest in a positive development of the country. The country has great potential for the future, which it can only exploit if it does not leave the path of liberal democracy. Romania's starting point was difficult. That is why the CVM mechanism has been agreed. We are listening carefully to what the Vice-President of the Commission has to say to us in this regard, and we are also awaiting with great interest the results of the Venice Commission. It is also necessary to find out more about the role of the secret service, because the fight against corruption must be a matter for the independent judicial bodies. We also expect the President of the country to respond to this at the next plenary session. In line with our principles, we will participate constructively in the preparation of the planned resolution, for which the LIBE Committee will provide the decisive foundations.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: on behalf of the ECR group. – Dragnea and Tariceanu are now attacking the European Union because their lies and imposture have been discovered, but Romanians want to Europe, democracy and freedom. Now the Romanians are suffering because of this government working against them. Romania is not a group of corrupt politicians, Romania is every honest man, wherever they are in the world - and many have gone out into the world precisely because of corruption, but they want to go home. The government hit its own citizens with batons and grenades. The images of August 10th don't lie. Independent media are also threatened with a criminal sentence dissentenced to ten years in prison for money laundering. Dragnea decided to prepare laws to bury the independent press as well.  Justice is the first enemy of the PSD and ALDE. They changed the laws of justice to control magistrates, changed criminal codes to get rid of crimes and block investigations. The PSD and ALDE are now using some protocols between the intelligence services and the public prosecutor's office to get their sentences reviewed and get out of jail, because an amnesty law will take people to the streets. Romanians protest, Romanians are not inertia. It's a living people. Romania is a living people and will always fight back to defend its democracy.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Romania has, in my opinion, not one but two problems: yes, widespread corruption; and also, Mr Timmermans, a Secret Service out of hand, a state within the state. The nub of my message today is that both problems need to be tackled, and that Romania has to end the bad tradition of what was the Securitate, a Secret Service instrumentalised by one side of the political establishment to hit the other side. This has to stop, Prime Minister. Also, a totally inappropriate reaction – weakening the fight against high-level corruption, undermining even the prosecution of it – is the way that Orbán and Kaczyński lead their countries. That is not the way that we liberals should govern. Not in our name and certainly not with our name! So, may I give you one piece of advice, Prime Minister? Don’t follow the bad Hungarian and Polish examples. Embrace fully the remarks and recommendations of the Venice Commission and let them systematically review your legislative proposals, because the fight against corruption must be strengthened and not weakened, and the independence of the courts must be guaranteed and not undermined. And, yes, the murky power of the new-old Securitate definitely needs to be broken. The one is not in contradiction with the other.

name: Ska KELLER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, Romania has a very long and proud tradition of fighting for freedom and civil liberties; overthrowing a dictatorship after 42 years. The efforts to move towards democracy and civil liberties cannot be overestimated. It’s harsh but Romania did it. Democratic institutions have been developed and Romania has joined the European Union. It is therefore even more worrying, Prime Minister, to see that there is a real backlash. With the reforms of the Romanian Criminal Code, your government is making it legal for officials to abuse their power. Your government will allow convicted criminals to get away with their stolen money and not have it confiscated. You are de facto legalising corruption with that reform.  Corruption makes people lose trust in the state and in democracy. Money is being diverted from the benefit of the many to the pockets of the few. Romanian citizens now lose five times more money to corruption than the state spends on hospitals and healthcare. Romanians do care. They took to the streets to ask for democracy, for good governance from you, Prime Minister, as is their right, as is the right of any European citizen. But, instead of listening to them, you actually sent the police in to attack them, tear-gassing an entire public square.  Even further, your government is now planning to reduce the freedom of assembly, making it obligatory to have an authorisation. Romania would be the first European Union Member State to require an authorisation. Do you really want to go that low? Colleagues, Commissioner, Romanian citizens are asking for freedom, nothing else. Freedom from corruption, freedom of assembly, freedom from discrimination. Europe is built on that freedom. As someone who grew up in the Eastern bloc, I can testify to how important that freedom is. That freedom, democracy and civil liberties are being called into question in more and more Member States. As European institutions, as European deputies, we have to defend the rights of Romanian citizens as well as the rights of every European citizen, be it in Hungary, be it in Poland, be it in Austria, be it anywhere. There is no second—class citizenship. Let’s not wait until it’s too late. Let’s not wait until we have to start yet another Article 7 procedure. Now is the time to change. Now is the time to act.  (Applause)

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Romania has been taking to the streets for years. In view of the time I have, I shall concentrate on a few points. Firstly, the fight against corruption and independent justice is crucial to the Rule of Law, but we should remember that the protest is extremely fragmented. For some, corruption leads to inequality, for others, hampers the neoliberal agenda and justifies more powers than services. The result is a false unity, it is the strength but also the weakness of the movement. Second, in the movement there are dark sides. PSD supporters are disdained as old, stupid, rural. In fact, opposition to this government fails to convince the poorest and most marginalised electorate living in the countryside. Let us not forget the marginalised in the single market. Thirdly, the movement not only fights corruption, it also includes battles against the constitutionalisation of the family as an exclusive union between men and women. Our Charter of Rights neither prohibits nor imposes the granting of marital status to same-sex unions.  Fourthly, the defence of the Rule of Law is only right, but I would ask you, Vice-President, to use it also for countries that regularly save money. I have listened to you in recent days about the August demonstrations in Bucharest. He rightly spoke of shock images, of peaceful protesters being beaten by the police, of inquiries to be opened immediately. There were no such strong words when the peaceful pro-independence voters in Catalonia were beaten and their leaders imprisoned. And I wonder why Romania is severely scrutinised and condemned, while Spain is not.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Prime Minister, since our entry into Parliament, we have reaffirmed the centrality of the rule of law in the European Union and called for the institutions to constantly monitor compliance with it by the Member States and to be able to intervene in the event of violations. We are concerned about what we read about what is happening in Romania. I fear that the reforms of the Criminal Code carried out by the current government may not only undermine the independence of the judiciary in the country and encourage corruption, but also weaken judicial cooperation in criminal matters with other EU countries, potentially making Romania a safe haven to continue its illicit affairs with impunity. I am referring to the law that shortens the statute of limitations to one year, effectively leaving the perpetrators of serious crimes, such as corruption and money laundering, unpunished, but also the measures repealing and criminalising abuse of office, up to the removal of the ban on holding public office for those convicted of corruption or abuse of office and the decriminalisation of the crime of corruption.  We, in Italy, for example, want to do exactly the opposite. We cannot allow those who commit such serious crimes to go unpunished. We want a reform of the statute of limitations by suspending at the first instance or by referring them to court in order to prevent criminals from benefiting from the length of trials in order to guarantee impunity. The fight against corruption in public administration is also a priority of our government. We want to establish the 'daspo' for the corrupt, which means that a person definitively convicted of corruption will no longer be able to deal with the public administration. In the anti-money laundering directive for which I was rapporteur, we succeeded in introducing the penalty ancillary to the ban on taking up public office and running for election for those who have been definitively convicted of money laundering offences. That is our objective: to keep criminals out of the public administration. That must be the objective, Prime Minister, of Romania and of the whole of the European Union. The Commission must ensure that the Rule of Law Treaties are respected and that the Member States ensure the correct transposition of these important legislative instruments at European Union level, such as the directive on combating money laundering through criminal law, which I have mentioned, the fifth anti-money laundering directive, which contains important provisions on politically exposed persons, which I understand have been skilfully omitted by the Romanian Government. , which will be the commission's responsibility to assess its lawfulness.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, after Hungary and Poland, Romania is now in the Commission's sights.  As in the case of Poland, the Eurocrats blame the Romanian government for its reform of the judicial system which would allegedly threaten the rule of law, but each time these legal and technical arguments are in fact merely pretexts, as I had the opportunity to see during the recent mission of the LIBE Commission to Warsaw.  In fact, what the Commission does not support is that people make democratic decisions and are consulted on issues that it would like to decide for them. Commissioner Timmermans acknowledged on Monday night that family policies are the responsibility of the Member States, for this ardent support of the LGBTI lobby, etc., we do not have the right to be against marriage for same-sex couples.  Next Saturday and Sunday, the Romanian people will be able to vote in a referendum and whether or not to approve the proposal to constitutionalize marriage between a man and a woman. Being French, I had forgotten that one could be left-wing and refuse to give in to ultra-minority communitarian demands.  The European institutions must respect Romania, its sovereignty and its democratic choices, mr Timmermans does not mind. It is up to the Romanian people to decide the future they want for their children.

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: – Mr President, I would say to Madam Prime Minister, 20 years ago I worked in Romania, in Bucharest on the laws that became your anti-money laundering legislation. I worked with intelligent, smart and caring lawyers alongside me. We worked on the international rules that finally became your own legislation. What I also remember of my time in Romania was how proud they were of you becoming an independent country, how they can once again vote for their own Prime Minister, such as yourself. When you and your government stood and received over 45% of your nation states’ votes only a few years ago, you became a leader of a country that was also proud. Be in no doubt: today, you are here to be once more one of those Prime Ministers who are to be attacked, bullied and abused by those people on the front bench for having one simple thing: the audacity to actually stand up to them and their anti-democratic ways. You are a Prime Minister who has a vote. You are a Prime Minister that has received the backing of its people. You are standing up to those people in this room who have one vision and that is their own vision. Now you can go away from here understanding that they don’t really want to support you. They’re attacking you – the Hungarians, the Romanians, but you have a responsibility to your people first, not to this lot here.

name: Dan NICA
text: – Mr President, First Vice-President, Prime Minister, I would like to make a first statement which must be very clear to everyone. Romania does not accept to be a currency under any conditions and with any other country. We understand that there have been concerns about certain Member States, but we are asking - and this has also been underlined by the First Vice-President of the European Commission - that each country be judged on its own merits. We in Romania are trying at this moment that all things that have held a dark past, a perverted judicial system, former ministers of justice who have turned prosecutors into their own servants, those who have thus succeeded in turning a respectable institution of the judge into timorous persons, into prosecutors who have been forced to make files on command , become an independent system, controlled only by the Superior Council of Magistracy and in which no one, ever, is blackmailed. Everyone in Romania has to understand one thing: justice is done only in the courtroom and never on the basis of protocols, on the basis of secret services and on the basis of occult understandings, and I welcome this position of the European Commission. Everyone needs to know that the times that have been can no longer return, with all the desperate efforts that these real Romanians in the room, such as Preda and Macovei, are making, and who have managed to turn justice Romanian into a disgrace. We do not tolerate these things, we will change them and we will change them properly, in accordance with democratic norms. (The speaker agreed to answer a question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mr Bostinaru, I would like to thank Mr Bostinaru for his work on this I do not need any teachings from you. I pay close attention to what is called in between. Heckling is possible in parliamentary business and is permitted as long as they are within a reasonable framework in terms of form and content. I decide that. I don't need shouts from the sidelines from you to do that. So that this is clear once and for all.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: blue-card question. – I am more and more surprised about the debate here. I heard the Socialists and Democrats (S&D) Group applaud the extremes up here when defending corruption in Romania, and the question I would like to raise is: aren’t you concerned about a government that is not just not sufficiently fighting corruption, but is fighting those who are fighting corruption? Could I have an answer to that?

name: Dan NICA
text: Answer to a question asked in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – This is part of what the fake news campaign means. Has anyone ever told you that in the last five years, 98% of those allegedly sent for corruption cases in the courts have been acquitted? Have you been told that all these people who were allegedly also reported to the European Commission were declared innocent? In these six months alone, more than 200 acquittals by the National Anti-Corruption Directorate.  Anti-corruption means for us that the guilty person should pay and the innocent not to pay. Injustice for one means injustice for everyone. That's our motto.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I will say from the outset that political decisions have been imposed in Romania in recent years which have violated some European standards with regard to the rule of law. However, these decisions were taken by the leader of the PSD, Liviu Dragnea, to solve his personal problems and all those who support him, here and in the country, know this very well. However, it is obligatory to stress before the European Parliament that I will not agree that Romanians should be punished for what politicians do in their country. No, no sanctions should be adopted that will affect the innocent citizens of Romania, who have never supported Liviu Dragnea's snoring. If his colleagues in government are complicit, then the measures must be taken against them and not against the citizens of Romania.  I therefore invite my fellow social democrats, ALDE, to take a stand against the Romanian colleagues who support the initiative of their political leader. To criticise and punish the guilty politicians, not the citizens of Romania. Romania is a pro-European country. (The speaker agreed to answer a question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: James CARVER
text: blue-card question. – Mr Rebega, thank you for taking my blue card. This is one of a series of debates that have been taking place in here concerning the rule of law in a particular EU Member State. Is it not an indication of the increasing authoritarian approach across the European Union and of the fact that the UK, which has always been a bastion of free speech and democracy, has made the correct choice by voting to leave this increasingly federalist and undemocratic organisation?

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: – What is the question about Romania?  What is the question referring to Romania?

name: James CARVER
text: blue-card question. – We are seeing an increasingly authoritarian approach across the European Union. From the right and from the left – right-wing governments have been criticised, and now left-wing governments are being criticised. Surely it is an indication that my country has made the right choice, seeing what is happening in Hungary, in Poland and in Romania, and seeing how the European Union does not like what is happening?

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mr Carver, I would like to thank Mr Carver for his It won't be like that. I wasn't that strict at first. But you have not managed to formulate a question the second time. That is why we do not need an answer.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: – Mr President, I find it amazing how Brexiteers still feel the need to lecture the European Union about the internal affairs of the European Union.  (Applause) Bye-bye. Mrs Prime Minister, I’m very pleased that you’re here today to debate with us, but I have to say that I am disappointed at your speech. The European Parliament is not the enemy. We are not attacking Romania – we are all in the same family, but we are expressing our concern about developments in your country, so I would suggest that you embrace that as a hand we’re stretching out to you to help – because we’re all in this together. Don’t seek confrontation with the European Parliament. Don’t be on the defensive, but see this as an attempt to create a culture of the rule of law and fundamental rights throughout the territory of the European Union. I’m not going to repeat what has been said about following the recommendations of the Venice Commission or investigate the claims of interference by the intelligence services, but I would urge you to repeal the laws, the anti-money laundering laws and the laws on the freedom of assembly that are going to severely and unduly restrict the freedom of NGOs. I would also call on all political parties – I know I cannot call on the government, but all political parties – to campaign against the anti-LGBTI referendum. I also officially asked the Presidency of this House to investigate claims that EU or EP funding has been used to fund the campaign against … (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: I'm getting some blue cards now. It seems to have been said that we have a great many speeches on the subject of catch-the-eye. I cannot allow this to be circumvented. I would also like to take note of the general line here that I do not want to allow another speaking time by means of a blue card to someone whom I have withdrawn the floor because of the time limit.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report and for his excellent work. To make this clear in advance, I would like to express respect and appreciation for the Romanian people. However, I would also like to place insults and shame on this Romanian Government, for this Socialist Romanian Government, where the boss is being investigated for a corruption sum of more than EUR 20 million. And in August of this year, when more than 100 000 people took to the streets to demonstrate against the corrupt government, a government adviser to this socialist government demanded that these people be shot. And another said they wanted to put up a counter-demonstration and kick these people down. These are things that are simply unacceptable. I maintain that they have pulled up a theatre towards Hungary and towards Poland in order to deliberately conceal what is happening here in these areas in the socialist government in Romania. I can therefore only appeal to you, ladies and gentlemen of the Social Democrats: make order in your own stable and not pull up a theatre where no theatre is necessary.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I believe that, as far as the right to ask questions is concerned, the Lord should not penally, by taking away the right to ask a question, those who have the right to benefit from it, but at most a Member who has exceeded time. It is he who may have a shortened answer about the time for which this right to speak has exceeded, and not those who would like to ask a critical question. It's a complete misunderstanding.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mr! Thank you for this view of things. The management of the meeting is not a punishment, at least not for those who speak. I am trying to get some sort of order here. In any case, it is clear that blue cards cannot be used to circumvent an undeniably existing large number of spontaneous speeches requested. I understand very well that a great many Romanian colleagues want to speak in this debate. But the speaking time in plenary is not there to convey only one view of things and not just the view from one country. I have received well over 30 requests for spontaneous interventions. I will allow little more than five and have taken care not to have only Romanian colleagues from every group.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: – Mr President, the attacks on anti—corruption and judicial bodies in Romania are worrying. The scenes of protesters being beaten are deeply disturbing. These are ordinary people on the receiving end of the baton. These were not terrorists, they were not provocateurs, they weren’t even there illegally. These are the mothers, fathers, sons and daughters of Romania, Europeans whose only crime is to demand an end to corruption and abuse. That is all they want. They stood up for the Romania they were promised and for the rights guaranteed by the EU treaties. This should not be too much to ask. After all, modern Europe is built on the shoulders of the people who shaped history by speaking out with their lungs bursting with tear gas. On 10 August, Romanians took to the streets, shouting ‘justiţie nu corupţie’ – ‘justice not corruption’. If ever there were three words which articulate what the EU must stand for, those are they: ‘justice, not corruption’.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, Prime Minister, the European Parliament is not a foreign power in Romania, because it represents Romanian citizens and because you come from this European Parliament. That is why you understand very well how much we are concerned about the rule of law and fundamental rights. We encourage you in your fight against corruption, but you make a difference with the behaviour of the Governments of Hungary and Poland. You follow the criteria of the Venice Commission. Because, in the fight against corruption, we need an independent judiciary and a tax ministry free of interference in the government. But, moreover, a precepturated referendum is held in Romania on Sunday, which will lead to the manifest objective of preventing the mere legal possibility of same-sex marriage. I encourage you to have the courage to tell Romanian citizens that you do not want for your country any discrimination in the enjoyment of rights on an equal footing.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Mr. Chairman, the rule of law in the countries behind the Iron Curtain is still extremely fragile, and that is why our efforts must go towards protecting and strengthening democratic institutions.  We must not forget that the initial position of former communist states is not the same as that of Western democracies and that certain interventions in the judiciary are probably necessary in order to cleanse them of the relapses of the old structures that undermine it. Since this is a very slippery slope, there is always a risk of being used as an excuse to bring judicial power under the control of the executive and further erosion of the system as seems to be happening not only to Romania but in most post-communist states.  Therefore, I believe that it is necessary to recognize and strengthen the role of those individuals and social groups who can and want to raise their voices against such failures of states, just as I support the fight that in these moments a part of Croatian society is fighting against the non-processing of war crimes in Croatia.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: – Mr President, as a pro-European people we are very constructive and I propose to you, Mr Timmermans, that we say today in the plenary of the Strasbourg Parliament that there is no need for any authorisation and no respect for the law to protest in Europe. This is the democratic standard you impose in Bucharest.  Yes, certainly, we may not have done very much to combat high-level corruption, and I would suggest, Mr Timmermans, that you ask certain Member States to stop providing in legislation for the possibility of bribery in order to obtain contracts abroad. Indeed, officials who allegedly paid bribes in Bucharest never saw them translated into our courts.  Of course, fellow members, the double standard is today, in my view, becoming a reality in this Strasbourg debate. This does not bring any more cohesion, it does not bring any more Europe and it is evidence of a lack of analysis, a lack of objectivity and a lack of standard. I would ask the European Commission, although it is mandatory: why in recent years have we not had any analysis of the situation of corruption in all the Member States of the European Union? Or do you just like these three?

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mrs Nicolai, I would like to thank Mrs Nicolai for her work Do you allow a question from Mr Bütikofer?

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: – Mr President, for the catch-the-eye procedure, it is not possible ...

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mrs Nicolai, I would like to thank Mrs Nicolai for her work First, we speak in a standing state. Secondly, I decide. You have it in your hands to say that you do not allow a question. I understand from your reply that this is a 'no'. That is why Mr Agnew is the next to speak.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: – Mr President, this is a good opportunity. I think the Prime Minister was on the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development with me a few years ago, and I would like to tell her that I have a constituent in my region, whose lighting company sold some materials to a firm in Romania, which then sold them on to another firm in Romania; it paid the original firm in Romania but that firm did not pay my constituent; he then went to court in Romania, and he believes that the official organising the timing of the hearings kept putting them off because he was being bribed to do so. In the end, my constituent went bankrupt. I tried to get the Commission interested because it is supposed to intervene in such cases but it did absolutely nothing. My constituent had thought the European Union would be on his side. He has ended up losing heavily. Please, Prime Minister, can you have a look at your own country, and endeavour to ensure that British businesspeople can invest there with confidence.

name: Răzvan POPA
text: – Mr President, with all due respect to you and this institution, I would have liked you to be as firm with the colleagues there, who have been shouting all over the meeting, and Mr Preda is a disgrace to this institution and to the way he is unable to respect those who are here and this institution.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mr Popa, I would like to thank Mr Popa for his I have said beforethat that it is part of a lively debate – at least in the democracies of the world – that heckling is also permissible. As long as they keep within the framework in terms of form and content, I do not intend to bind them to one another. However, I would like to call you to order for you to call a colleague here in the Chamber a disgrace to Parliament.

name: Emilian PAVEL
text: – Mr President, I cannot help but notice that you are behaving very biasedly towards your political group. You've forgotten that there's no possibility of blue card at catch the eye, but you've really wanted to warn Mrs Nicolai that there's a standing sound. Look, I speak standing up and please, you represent the European Parliament there and not your political group. You must be impartial and respect all The Members here, not just your own.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mr! Firstly, I would advise you to find out which group I belong to. Secondly, I said earlier that I will not allow blue cards to bypass catch-the-eye speeches. And I just said to Mrs Nicolai whether an intermediate question would be allowed, two people decide: the chairperson of the meeting and the one who is to be asked. Her answer was "no." My answer in this case would have been 'yes'. I would also like to tell you why I was inclined here to allow the intermediate question. Because there was not a single speech from the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance on catch-the-eye. That's why I thought I'd allow it. The Rules of Procedure do not specify whether blue cards are possible in the catch-the-eye procedure.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, you stated at the time I picked up the cards, at speaking time, that you could not also give catch the eye and the card. I had a card, you didn't give it to me, and you didn't give it to me at catch the eye, yet you decide if (that's democracy? let's understand it!), you decide if you give cards to catch the eye and not to speaking time. I no longer understand the way of leadership and I will write a letter to the President of Parliament.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mrs Grapini, I would like to thank Mrs Grapini for her work You are welcome to submit something in writing. I said three things. Firstly, if I take the floor from someone because they have spoken for too long, I will not allow a blue card on my part. Among other things, you had come forward. Secondly, I have pointed out that some Members are now trying to re-check their message in catch-the-eye, so to speak, by means of blue cards. I will not allow that to happen. I have never spoken about the reverse of my use of blue cards.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Mr President, Romania accepted sovereignty as a prerequisite for accession to the Union and in exchange for the temporary and opportunistic influx of cheap money, while the Union chose to circumvent its basic constituent principles on the altar of opportunistic political symbolism. Despite the warnings, the mistakes were mutual and their management weighed equally on both sides. More than eleven years later, the process has been diverted and has resulted in recommendations even to change provisions of the Romanian Constitution, which is unacceptable. With a view to faster disengagement, the Union has no choice but to participate constructively and implement this transitional aid measure.  The objective, with clear individual benchmarks, remains to eliminate weaknesses in the areas of judicial reform and the fight against corruption, through reasoned and proportionate recommendations, the provision of know-how and targeted funding, where necessary or necessary.  Of course, one last thing: There is more hypocrisy here. You talked about tear gas in Romania and, when Greek Prime Minister Tsipras came here, who did the same and worse in Pisoderi and Thessaloniki, with the police beating up the citizens, you didn't say a word.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – I have been critical of the President's interpretation of the right to ask questions because speakers have exceeded their time, but in this case I would like to be critical of the President's critics. Catch-the-eye is a collection of normal statements in the debate. And to each of these statements you can ask a question. There is a practice that refuses to do so, but it has no basis in the rules. And the President in this case is absolutely right.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Thank you for the flowers, Mr Jurek.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, for two years the Romanian people have been showing up in the streets to defend European values. People demand justice, people demand justice, people demand the rule of law and people demand good governance and people take to the streets, along with the flag of the European Union, and people ask: what can the European Union do for us? And our answer, First Vice-President Timmermans, fellow members, must be a convincing answer. We must stand with the Romanian people, defend together European values, defend together the European way of life. That's what the Romanian people want, and that's what we have to do. We stand with the Romanian people.  We also need to know that people are against a government that is controlled by the president of the Social Democratic Party, which is a convicted criminal several times, and when criminals make laws, laws are good for criminals, they are not good for people. That is why, First Vice-President Timmermans, you, the European Commission and we, Parliament, are with the people, we must stand with them, defend European values and good governance.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: – Mr President, the debate on the rule of law in Romania was awaited by Romanians with hope. They expected the European Union to help them get rid of the odious system exposed here by the Prime Minister. To their bitter surprise, instead of help, Romanians receive apostrophes and threats that if they do not immediately return to the odious system they are trying to escape now, they will be penalized.  Romanians, among the most pro-European citizens, do not deserve this, because the real Romanians are the many, who, through the massive vote given to the coalition in 2016, asked it to restore the democratic rights stolen by a politicized justice, controlled by the secret services, and not the few who misinform.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Thank you very much, Mr Pacu. The misunderstanding goes to my cap. I said Pacu, but I also said Marinescu when I thanked Mr Mure'an for his contribution. (End of spontaneous speeches)

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: Prime Minister of Romania. – Mr President, thank you all for your position. I've seen things I've considered, constructive things. I wanted a constructive dialogue, but I realized that there is a lot of misinformation and I am not accusing those who have said these things, but those who are behind this misinformation. Mr Pons - yes, we must defend the citizens. That's what I'm asking for, and I'm not going to ignore the voice of the people, and witness is the broad popular support that we have in Romania. I listen to everyone in good faith and I want a constructive dialogue, but a dialogue that is right for Romania and for the European Union. Mrs. Macovei, I know about your misinformation. This government that you criticize so often has brought economic growth of 7%, has increased the standard of living of Romanians and, therefore, Romanians love it. It does not honor you to bring the internal political struggle into the European Parliament, it is a lack of respect for the Romanian people. I'm not going to be able to answer everyone, it would be a long time, but I want to give some more answers. Yes, Romania is divided, and I want Romania to be united, but we have to take care of one thing - and a pro-European country tells you: do we also want a divided Europe? Yes, we have dialogue, but let us not try, regardless of the political group, to challenge each other. Together we must draw, shape the future of the European Union, starting next year. Let us see the things that unite us and put aside the things that divide us. What we have to do, we will straighten out, we will have dialogue, I am willing to dialogue. Mr Corrao, justice reform, justice laws are initiated in Parliament. It is Parliament who is democratically elected, it is the expression of the will of the people. Do you see that there is misinformation here, too? Because they pointed the finger at the government. No - these laws were initiated in Parliament.  Mr Rebega, do not bring the political struggle into the European Parliament. It is not fair to Romanians, perhaps you should think that you have run on the lists of the Social Democratic Party, but I do not judge you, because I do not have the right, will judge those who supported you and whom you have now disappointed.  Ma'am, in't Veld, thank you so much for your suggestions, I'll take into account your suggestions. The European Parliament is not my enemy, I have been an MEP for nine years and I will never deviate from European values. Maybe not all things are right, maybe not all things are as they should be, but I am convinced that a constructive dialogue and the fact that you can listen to all parties and we will take less account of those who do not want to be understanding and dialogue in the European Parliament, those who come with misinformation, those who have always misinformed, not only now - I think things can get better. First Vice-President Timmermans, we will certainly take into account the recommendations of the Venice Commission. Today, the Minister of Justice, present with me, will go to the Venice Commission. Romania is a pro-European country and certainly will not deviate from the pro-European road - and tells you a former colleague of yours. Please trust Romania and trust in the European course and respect for the rule of law in my country. Thank!

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, in the course of my professional and political life over the past 30 years I have been a very close witness to everything that has happened in Romania and I remember vividly that 30 years ago, working on the issue, I saw that the Romanian people had inherited a thoroughly, thoroughly corrupt system. It was not just corrupt because of the corruption, it was morally corrupt. The nation had been under the direction of a morally deeply corrupt dictator and his system. If you take that, 30 years ago, into account and then see where Romania is today, huge progress has clearly been made, apart from the party-political composition of the government. Over those decades, huge progress was made. So why am I so worried today? Because, in the final stretch of this long and painful marathon, we now risk not reaching the finishing line to ensure that the fight against corruption cannot be reversed and that the rule of law is irreversible. To go in the other direction would be to undo some of the most important achievements by the Romanian people in ridding themselves of this horrible past. Someone who comes from a country like mine cannot even begin to imagine how difficult this must have been for the Romanian people. So, if we now speak out and speak up, it is because we are doing it for the Romanian people, who want to fulfil their European destiny by being sure that the system they live in – the country they live in – is a democracy based on the rule of law, with full respect for human rights, and where corruption is combated effectively and rooted out of society. I want to remind the Members of this House who have not made reference to the Cooperation and Verification Mechanism (CVM) report that, yes indeed, the recommendations of the Venice Commission are important and we will work on them, but please also look at the recommendations made in the Commission’s CVM report of last year and the recommendations we will be making in the CVM report next month. I think they constitute a good road map for ensuring that reform is irreversible. I will continue the dialogue with the Romanian Government. Because of time, I could not be precise on every question and critique we have on the proposed and already promulgated laws, but I will be very meticulous and precise in putting my questions to the Romanian Government, and in inviting them to answer those questions and to continue the dialogue so that we can resolve these issues. Let me be very clear: what is at stake is of huge importance for the future of our European Union, but what is at stake is of even greater importance for the future of the Romanian people. So, if the Commission needs to be brutal in our assessment we will be brutal. If we need to use other instruments at our disposal, we will use them. This is not a threat. This is just the Commission setting out what our role is and pointing out that we are the guardian of the Treaty and we need to take this role very seriously indeed. If I may make a political remark: sometimes I have the impression – to put it in the words of the immortal Yogi Berra – that it’s ‘déjà vu all over again’. In response to criticism, two things always emerge: firstly the cry of ‘Double standards’, which is a sort of knee jerk reaction; and secondly the assertion that ‘It’s not an attack on the government, it’s an attack on the nation (or on the people).’ I hope I have made clear today that we have made a clinical assessment of the situation: that we have analysed precisely the proposed changes in the legislation, that we are doing this on behalf of the Romanian people, not against the Romanian people, and that we look at each and every Member State in exactly the same way. (Applause) We look at the facts, while also recognising that every situation is different. We are not putting Member States all in one batch, we are looking at every Member State on the basis of the specific issues in that Member State, and I really want us to be successful here. I urge the Romanian Government, once again: keep the dialogue open and listen to our recommendations – they have been put down on paper in a spirit of cooperation, and of keeping Romania on the right European track. (Applause)

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, the emotionality of this discussion clearly shows how important this issue is. I also want to thank Commissioner Timmermans. The First Vice—President made the situation and the necessity for a dialogue very clear. Let me assure you once again that the Austrian Presidency and the Council as a whole attaches great importance to upholding the rule of law and fundamental values within the European Union. I speak as Presidency of the Council and therefore in the name of all of its Member States. The Council will continue to follow this issue closely and the Presidency will pay particular attention to the views which were expressed during the dialogue and during this debate.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place during the November I part-session. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. – A distinction must be made between bad government and a good people. It is very important that this debate keeps Romanians close to the European Union, even if the government's mistakes seem to be driving us further and further away. These are big mistakes, the most serious being by far the gassing and beating of peaceful protesters, for which the government must leave as soon as possible, by a motion of censure.  However, Romania should not be helped to get into Hungary's situation. I do not think that discussions about the activation of Article 7 are justified in any way, although some of the politicians in government seem interested in making the most of the exchange of words with the European Union, because in this way they distract from their own errors.  Romania was supposed to be in the Schengen area, already meeting all the technical conditions, and the fact that it is not a member of a political indecision is a subject that constantly fuels the critical current towards the European Union and, unfortunately, is a subject that has remained unclear.  This is a political reality that Eurocins, i.e. Eurosceptics in interest, who criticise the European Union for diverting their own responsibility, benefit in particular.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. – While we strongly criticise Hungary and Poland for the lack of the rule of law, the Romanian Government is working almost unnoticed to radically weaken the judiciary. The changes to criminal law and criminal proceedings and the dismissal of the chief prosecutor of the anti-corruption authority raise many questions. We now need a comprehensive analysis by the European Commission on the impact of the amended laws in the areas of justice and law enforcement. And then we have to draw conclusions from the results. The rule of law must not be restricted, corruption must not be legalised. We must send a signal to the citizens of Romania and support them in their fight against corruption.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. – The debate on the rule of law in Romania was included in the EP programme at the insistence of the EPP Group, in an artificial way, in order to balance politically Parliament's resolution on Hungary, which voted in favour of activating sanctions on that country.  On 1 October, in the EP's LIBE Committee, in the speeches of some EPP, ECR, Greens, etc. MePs, various situations in Romania - many of which do not conform to reality - on the independence of the judiciary, the protests of 10 August and the referendum to be held in Romania on 6-7 October.c. There have been pros and cons of Romania, but it is obvious to any informed observer that a political goal is being pursued, namely the weakening of the Romanian social democrats and the government led by them. It is a political scenario of striking in the Romanian Government and the creation internationally of an image of instability in Romania, which uses European right-wing forces.  Why debate sin only on the situation of the countries of Central and Eastern Europe? Is the aim of creating a new fracture between western and eastern Europe? Is a multi-speed Europe to the benefit of the future? Definitely not, because the discrepancies between western and eastern Europe will widen.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. – In this atypical debate organized only for Romania, I find that those who criticize the rule of law and justice in Romania do so on the principle of "salt drug". What if you don't have good justice laws?  I am calling for an objective and comparative analysis of what is happening in all Member States. You have sparked a wave of reactions against Europe! Is that what you want? Romania is a sovereign and independent state and respects its own Constitution and the will of Romanian citizens. How can the Commission justify the fact that neither the protocols between the SRI nor the position of the Constitutional Court and the National Union of Judges were mentioned in an CVM report? What sources of information does the Commission use to give verdicts on Romania?  To increase the credibility of the EU, you must respect all states and not use the double standard in the assessment of Member States. I call on the Commission to convey transparently how you analyse the functioning of the rule of law and corruption in all Member States. You will be surprised that exporting corruption from the west to the east is consistent! We want a clean, democratic Romania, but also a Romania with equal status in the EU with the other states.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. – Last plenary session we had Mr Orban, and now we have Mrs Dăncilă to discuss the same issue – a possible breach of the rule of law in an EU Member State. Poland, Hungary and now Romania – we see a ‘tendency’' which highly threatens the core values and the existence itself of the EU. It is very worrying, especially before the upcoming EP elections. What we see now in Romania is a clear sign of an illiberal democracy in the EU: the Social Democratic Party of Romania has embarked on a process of overhauling the judiciary and change legislation to decriminalise several graft offences. Several party members, including leader Liviu Dragnea, are under investigation or on trial for corruption. Justice Minister Tudorel Toader pushed through the dismissal of chief anti—corruption prosecutor Laura Codruța Kövesi earlier this year. We see a clear threat to transparent judiciary processes in Romania which also leads to direct threats to the democratic rights of Romanian people, which we have to protect. However, the Prime Minister herself calls this fake news. Do you see the current processes in Romania as a healthy democratic development of your country Prime Minister? If you think it’s acceptable, then that is deeply worrying to me.

name: Eva JOLY
text: In writing. Two weeks ago, I was speaking here to denounce the serious excesses of the Hungarian government. I could go back almost point by point to address you, Madam Prime Minister.  As in Hungary, your government is attacking the judiciary in an attempt to remove corrupt and convicted elected officials, at the risk of jeopardising recognized and sustained progress in the fight against corruption. As in Hungary, you enact laws to hinder the work of NGOs and the mobilization of civil society. As in Hungary, you hide behind the election results, forgetting that the rule of law is not limited to electoral deadlines. It is based on pluralism and is based on a foundation of values. Like Hungary, you owe the relative silence of the EU to the support of a major European political party, here the Socialist Party. Like the Hungarians, Romanians should no longer be exploited for the benefit of a few. They are entitled to respect for their fundamental rights and support from the EU in their demands for true democracy. I cannot finish my speech without praising the remarkable work of my colleague Laura Codruta Kovesi against corruption.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: in writing. – Mrs Dăncilă, last week in Brussels I told you that you represent all Romanians and that you need to inform correctly about what is happening in Romania. You did not do so, either in Brussels or today. Unfortunately for you, there are enough credible and accurate sources of information to find out the reality. You will go down in history as the person who served as Prime Minister during the events of 10 August. What happened then is a summary of the work of your government: contempt for people, contempt for democracy, European values, attitude of dictatorship, untruth and manipulation. You have beaten and gassed peaceful people, not high and paid as you, women and children, have claimed. Those who are now under investigation for these facts should not be left alone. You must be responsible for all this, you and the Interior Minister, as well as the shadow leader, Liviu Dragnea. Romania is a European country and Romanians will continue to support the EU regardless of the efforts you and your colleagues make, out of interest or lack of competence, to go in the opposite direction.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Writing. – The situation in Romania is alarming. The government's approach to tolerance of official corruption is unacceptable. The government should listen to its citizens. If he does not take seriously even a hundred thousand demonstrations, then this debate in the EP is necessary. We are replacing the voice of Romanian citizens, to whom the government does not listen. I fully support the Commission's efforts to monitor the situation in Romania under the Cooperation and Verification Mechanism. However, I do not call for financial sanctions against Romania in the form of a suspension of payments from EU funds, as these would be the ones that would most harm citizens.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. – The European Parliament debated yesterday on the state of the rule of law in Romania. I believe that this debate has not presented the real situation in our country, that of a legitimately elected government acting to ensure the security and safety of its citizens and fighting against a 'deep state' system. The objective of the Romanian Government is to ensure respect for the civil rights and freedoms of Romanian citizens.  All this process of misinformation and the dissemination of false information is meant to discredit Romania in the most democratic institution of the European Union. The interventions of the gendarmes in the Bucharest protests were heavily criticized, but there was no debate on this issue when the gendarmes, for example, in Brussels or Barcelona acted in the same way as those in Bucharest.  I would like in the future, in the debates, to focus on key issues such as Romania's economic growth of 7% over the last four years and its role in achieving the objectives of unity and strengthening European construction.  In this context, it is clear that we need a new and constructive and fair approach and dialogue between Romania and the European Union.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: Writing. – We can welcome the fact that, breaking with the double standards so far, the European Parliament is applying the rule of law mechanism not only to hungary and Poland, but also to Romania, which is led by a left-liberal government. In today's speech, I am confined to two minority Hungarian cases, which are clearly a gross acre of the rule of law in Romania and even evoke the anti-minority practices of the Communist dictatorship of the Ceauşescu era. As in communism: political prisoners are once again in prison in Romania. It is well known that the institutions of the judiciary have communicated dozens of illegal secret agreements to the intelligence services. This was also the case between the Romanian Intelligence Service (SRI) and the Organised Crime and Counter-Terrorism Prosecutor's Office (DIICOT), which resulted in hungarian public leaders István Beke and Zoltán Szűcs being innocently sentenced to five years in prison on trumped-up charges, without evidence and terrorism. A similar case of its kind is the case of the University of Medicine and Pharmaceuticals of Târgu Mureş (MOGYE). The prestigious Hungarian school was romanianized during the time of dictator Ceauşescu. Subsequently, the Romanian Education Act required the institutional introduction of full Hungarian language training to no avail, and the chauvinistic university management has not yet implemented it. Now, however, the university is in the process of being permanently merged and terminated. We strongly demand immediate remedy for these discriminatory anti-Hungarian violations!

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. – Romania is another country where a socialist government is in power and where it is obvious that the rule of law is not working.  It was clear from the debates of Members, especially those of socialists, that they have double standards when dealing with individual countries. While they were highly critical of the debate on Hungary, this time their tone was more conciliable or quite quiet. It can be inferred from this that this is not a sincere commitment to the rule of law according to the same criteria and criteria for all. In the last ten years, almost a fifth of its population has emigrated from Romania, which is worrying. It is an indicator of the situation in society that we also face in Slovenia. Part of that is the apathy that manifests itself in electoral abstinence. We must fight this and demand that unfair and corrupt policies be removed from the political space. Not through political persecution, but on the basis of fair and fair criteria, which should apply in a country where the rule of law is truly respected. Apathy in the election is also followed by an exodus as a result of the loss of hope that a better future can be found at home.

name: Monika VANA
text: Writing. – Following the recent cases of corruption and influence of the judiciary by the Romanian Government, there is an urgent need for an investigation into the rule of law. The European Union must learn from the failures of Poland and Hungary and respond more quickly this time in order to protect democracy and the independence of the judiciary in a Member State. Romania must not take the path towards 'illiberal democracy'.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the debate with the Prime Minister of Estonia, Jüri Ratas, on the future of Europe (2018/2731(SDR)). I would like to thank the Prime Minister of Estonia for accepting our invitation to take part in the debate on the future of Europe. We are listening to all the Prime Ministers, but I would particularly like to thank Jüri Ratas for always giving great emphasis to Parliament's position during the Estonian Presidency. There has been no Council meeting, even an informal one, to which I have not been invited and which has not played a prominent role. That is why I thank him and he can certainly count on the support of a Parliament that also wants to have the power of legislative initiative in this direction. Prime Minister, you have the floor, welcome once again to the Chamber in Strasbourg.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Prime Minister of Estonia. – Mr President, Vice-President of the Commission, distinguished leaders of the political groups and Members of the European Parliament, Europe is a thought that needs to become a feeling. I am honoured to be back in this great House. I would like to thank President Tajani for organising the debates on the future of Europe and for giving me the opportunity to participate. Today, we can all together congratulate our German friends, and all Europeans on the occasion of German Unity Day. For my generation, this day symbolises not only the end of the division of Germany, but it also heralded the liberation of Eastern Europe and the start of the eastward enlargement of the European Union. It made possible the starting of accession talks 20 years ago. It has been an amazing journey for our country, for Estonia. The role of the European Parliament in it has been remarkable. I would like to thank you, honourable Members of the European Parliament, for your support.  This year, Estonia celebrates the hundredth anniversary of our statehood. Like Germans in the east of the country, we had to wait and dream for 50 years about freedom, rule of law and justice. I very clearly remember watching Finnish TV, as this was our only connection to the free world.
