What unites us in the EU is much more that than what divides us. By having common policies, we have been able to make a difference. We Europeans are stronger together and I hope we will spare no efforts in securing our collective interests and values in the world. I am very appreciative of all the Members of the European Parliament and the President of Parliament, Mr Antonio Tajani.  (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Thank you, Prime Minister. Once again, Parliament has been at the centre of the debate on the future of Europe, and we are moving forward in this direction. Thank you again. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Dear Prime Minister, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. I ask you to try to convince the Heads of State or Government, when discussing the new financial framework, that there is a need to triple funding for Erasmus+ for the period 2021-2027. This programme is the most popular and valued EU initiative that supports activities in the fields of education, training, youth and sport. Millions of citizens have been able to learn and train abroad through Erasmus, as well as work on joint international and cross-sectoral projects for new, innovative solutions in the field of education and training.  This programme makes a significant contribution to personal development and to the knowledge and skills of its participants and is therefore an important tool in the fight against youth unemployment. Through the exchange of good practices and the improvement of education and youth workers, Erasmus is also a driving force for improving the quality of education in the Member States.  Prime Minister, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. Education and training is the best investment in the future of the European Union. Erasmus has been in operation for 30 years and the demand for participation far exceeds its budgetary capacity. Therefore, at least three times the budget is necessary for us to maintain erasmus success and increase citizens' support for our actions.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The competent authorities of Sweden have informed the President of the election of Mr Sellstrom as a Member of the European Parliament in place of Mr Adaktusson, with effect from 3 October 2018. I therefore welcome the new colleague and I recall that he will take up his seat in Parliament and in his bodies with full rights under the conditions laid down in the Rules of Procedure.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I appeal to all the sensitivity of this House to identify with a mother and father who saw a 33-year-old son, Alessandro Fiori, lose his life in Istanbul, and we really ask the European authorities to take an interest in the Turkish authorities in order to understand how this 33-year-old boy lost his life.  He was initially said to have committed suicide, then he said he was ill, now it turned out he was murdered. I think it is the duty of the European Parliament to our peoples, our families, this mother and this father to ask the Turkish authorities to really find out who murdered this thirty-three-year-old.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: Ladies and gentlemen, with regard to the decisions of the ECON Commission to open interinstitutional negotiations, announced at the opening of the meeting on Monday 1 October, I have not received any request for a vote on this in Parliament under Article 69c(2). The ECON Commission can therefore start negotiations.

name: Giulia MOI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to officially ask why this Parliament has never allowed me to dismiss 2 assistants in whom I have not had confidence for a long time and who I am now forced to maintain and overpay in order to do nothing because of improper intervention ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: Mrs Moi, there is no room for the floor to address this matter.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: We move on to voting time now. (For results and other details of the vote: see Minutes).

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, thank you to the House for the support you have given to the report, and I would like to request your referral to the Committee on the Environment to begin interinstitutional negotiations.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: Rapporteur. – Grazzi Chair, ippermettili, l-ewwelnett nixtieq nirringrazzja lix-Shadow Rapporteurs gťaliex hija bl-attitudni tagťhom li qegťdin hawnhekk illum, u grazzi lil din il-Kamra li fehmet li din hija liżi fejn verament irridu nkunu ambizzżjui. F'dan ir-rigward, nixtieq gťalhekk nitlob il-mandat biex, abbażi tal-Artikolu 59, paragrafu 4, subparagrafu 4, tar-Regoli ta' Prożedura, inkunu nistgťu nagťtu bidu gťan-negozjati interistituzzjonali. Grazzi - Wikipedia

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: This concludes the voting shift.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by We have a fairly simple situation when it comes to voting. An ambitious task has been adopted to harmonise VAT in the area of developing economies, new technologies, but also with specific tasks. I would like to emphasise three things in particular: the need to reduce the cost of compliance and the complexity of procedures for companies, to reduce the revenue losses of Member States due to non-compliance and, thirdly, to ensure that companies in the European Union are not disadvantaged vis-erilegated towards companies outside the European Union. I wanted to pay special attention to these three elements.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the Aegean islands have always had a low value added tax. This is because they had to, because they were remote, to have support for their economic development. At the same time they faced and faced competition from Turkey, where VAT is 5%. Unfortunately, the troika and the Tsipras government have now made it possible to increase VAT, i.e. in essence they have imposed an increased VAT of 24% on the Aegean islands, resulting in the economic ruin of the whole region, which is currently also being hit by huge flows of illegal immigrants and refugees. We call for what our Parliament voted for yesterday: a special scheme for the Aegean islands, as is the case for VAT in the Italian municipality of Campione d'Italia and in the Italian waters of Lake Lugano. There they are allowed to have low VAT because they have competition from Switzerland. In the end, should the Aegean islands, which are remote, not have a low value added tax?

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I supported this proposal, which was approved. In general, I support all harmonisation and simplification procedures in the area of indirect taxes, i would like to emphasise this. Here it is important to take harmonisation steps so that they do not affect European businesses so as not to weaken their competitiveness, and I think that this proposal has also succeeded.  I am distinguishing this proposal from direct taxes, where I think there is, in turn, a significant ingerence of the Member States. I do not support excessive activism by the European Parliament or the institutions in general in direct taxation.  But I would like to point out that VAT will change, it seems, several more times by 2022.  Yesterday, another amendment to the VAT amendment was approved on the Czech proposal, it is a so-called reverse charge. The Czech Prime Minister calls this change bombastic. On the contrary, I think that it will be very unpleasant precisely the administrative burden on taxpayers, and I would like to call on the Member States to think about this again, because the constant changes in indirect taxes undoubtedly do not indicate good harmonisation practices.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European VAT is the main source of income for the Member States, a major problem is that the vat established and the VAT paid do not match, the difference continues to grow. This requires the introduction of uniform rules to help reduce the risk of cross-border VAT fraud and to create a single market. A significant change is that the sale of products from one Member State to another is taxed as if the product were purchased in the same Member State from which it originates. This requires the operation of a harmonised cross-border IT system. Together with the amendments, the Directive can help to harmonise the tax system, while continuing to consider the role of national tax authorities to be important. In view of all this, I voted in favour.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of this report, which seeks to introduce important measures that will simplify cross-border trade, reduce VAT fraud and minimise compliance costs for businesses. This update to the current EU VAT system will be particularly needed in years to come, as fraud continues to increase and to become an even more pressing issue. It is crucial for businesses across the EU that excessive compliance costs be reduced, and I welcome the fact that this is reflected. Additionally, it is extremely important that the heavy administrative burden on Member States, due to lack of harmonisation, is eased, and this text will help to ensure that this is the case. I also welcome the text in relation to the new status for certifiable taxable persons, which, once effectively harmonised across the EU, should be a significant step in simplifying the VAT system across the Union. I was also pleased to vote in favour of musical instruments being able to qualify for reduced rates of VAT should a Member State choose to make provision to that effect. It is important that we recognise and help the creative industries.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Mr President, there are well—grounded concerns about the functioning of the EU medicines system, as new medicines are very expensive and a large proportion of them do not bring better results than the ones previously circulating in the market. The EU-wide health technology assessments will be an evidence-based and uniform criteria-based process of evaluation and comparison of health standards and technologies in the Member States. This assessment should speed up access to medicines for patients, provide guarantees on medicines’ quality and reduce the bureaucratic burden, as only one assessment would be needed instead of one assessment per Member State.  Finally, I also supported proposals for the text to include the necessary additional flexibility so that Member States can meet certain national requirements, thus respecting Member States’ subsidiarity.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The European Parliament's report points to a number of actions suggesting that not only is a new directive needed to harmonise or to regulate additionally between the various parties in this big pharmaceutical business. I draw attention to this because, in my opinion, what we have voted for does not guarantee us satisfactory progress. On the other hand, I consider that this challenge was necessary, albeit too late.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the troika has impoverished the Greek people, resulting in the Greeks' inability to provide serious health care. We have huge prices for more expensive drugs. Cancer drugs are out of the way. Patients can't buy these drugs. You realize, then, that Greece has been left with this great party of drug multinationals, with expensive medicines, with medicines that are particularly problematic. And patients are now forced to resort to these expensive drugs without having the money. There must therefore be intervention to stop the party of drug multinationals, to stop over-invoicing and, of course, to stop the policy of violent fiscal adjustment, which has broken up the health sector in Greece.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European The fundamental objective of the proposal is a joint clinical evaluation of health technology at European level. Health is the most important value for European citizens, as the Eurobarometer survey has repeatedly shown. Moreover, health spending in the EU accounts for 10% of total GDP. The proposed measures include examining the therapeutic value of health technology and coordinating clinical trial aspects of medicinal products. This increases reliability, encourages quality innovation and enables technologies to be differentiated. Thus, it also increases the competitiveness of the European pharmaceutical industry by eliminating unnecessary overlaps. Against this all, I supported the adoption of this report.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by We have been building a community for more than sixty years. It therefore seems that it is high time to harmonise many areas, industries and sectors, including in the field of medical technologies. Well, especially since they concern perhaps the most important value for a person, and therefore his health. As has already been said, health is often dependent on treatment, on the use of medical technologies, and therefore on medicines, medical devices, and these are sometimes inefficient. Most often they are very expensive. Harmonisation of impact assessments, not only of action but also of the effectiveness of medical devices and medicines, can lead to a reduction in bureaucracy when it comes to the authorisation of new medicines on the market and, on the other hand, perhaps increasing their efficiency. And that's the point.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the assessment of health technologies is a central point of promotion and innovation, which can make real health gains available to patients and to society as a whole.  It is on the basis of this assessment that prices and contributions can be established, a point of paramount importance for the sustainability of health systems. This proposal is balanced and builds on the collaborative spirit between the Member States that make up the Union, but still leaves room for manoeuvre for national decisions. Centralisation avoids duplication of assessments, with resource savings, and will create a less asymmetric Europe in access to health care. Although this is the meeting of combined technical-scientific efforts of national agencies, I welcome the inclusion of patient representatives in the evaluation process in order to consider the added value of a therapy as going beyond mere clinical or pharmacological statistics, and the contribution of technology to the ease of treatment or quality of life of the patient can be considered. To this end, it is essential that the process be as transparent as possible to convey confidence to the entire value chain of the medicine.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, I would like to explain why I did not vote in the final vote to change the emission standards for new passenger cars. Reducing CO2 emissions is important in the fight against climate change and the European Union is a leader in this. The Commission has proposed changing the emission standard to reduce CO2 emissions by 30% by 2030.  I think it was a sensible decision. I was also willing to vote in favour of a compromise of 35%, and this, too, is already a very ambitious plan. However, even though many of us from the PPE voted against the amendment, parliament finally approved a commitment to a 40% reduction in emissions, and this is already an unacceptable ambition for me, counterproductive, because the European car industry will be less competitive, we will clear the way for Chinese competition. I hope that this decision will be rectified in negotiations with the Member States.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Mr President, Parliament today has pushed further on the Commission’s proposal to reduce CO2 emissions from new cars in the EU market by at least 40% by 2030. I am really happy with the political will and ambition shown by Parliament in this regard. I fully support the aim of the proposal to help Member States to reach the EU climate commitments under the Paris Agreement for the transport sector by incentivising the best use in production of new technologies such as electric vehicles. The vote was motivated in part by a reading of the impact assessment which estimated that this proposal could possibly create up to 70 000 new jobs in the European Union and that it will allow our citizens to save up to EUR 17 billion a year on fuel.  Lastly, the decision to reduce environmental pollution will also significantly reduce the EU’s geopolitical dependence on transport fuel imports, and it carries a very clear geopolitical message.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: – Mr President, I would like to express my joy at the adoption of the Dalli report on emission control, which is a milestone in the contribution of the road transport industry to the fight against climate change. I would like to stress the importance of ending traps in CO2 emission measurements, because measurements were not limited only to the laboratory, and I hope that there will never be any more dieselgates in that regard. And, in that sense, it is positive that we have passed awards for those who more than meet the minimum sales targets for vehicles with zero or low emissions, and punishments, too, for those who do not. On the other hand, it is important that this transition is gradual, realistic and that we prevent our builders from living that fearsome Nokia effect or Nokia moment, by which an industry either takes a leap forward, or irremissibly condemns it to die. And I would like to stress, lastly, the importance for creating green jobs. This transition represents a 1% reduction in jobs in this sector, but involves the creation of tens of thousands of new, more sustainable jobs in the industry.

name: Morten MESSERSCHMIDT
text: Mr President! It was a bit of a beauty contest to see what was going on in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy here in the process leading up to today's vote, with all the incredibly ambitious proposals put forward by the various groups. We ended up with a good compromise, and we have also been able to endorse this in our delegation and group, partly because it is of course important to do something for the climate, but it is also about our strategic and great political independence, which is an overlooked theme of this debate. When we import large quantities of coal and gas and oil, it is from regimes and states with which we generally do not want to be associated and certainly not in our pockets - in the Middle East, Russia, etc. I think it is important that we also talk about this dimension of the whole energy supply business, that it is really also about who we are allying ourselves with - and that must of course be the Western alliance with the United States at the forefront, Nato, etc. Not various regimes in the Middle East.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by This is another irresponsible resolution of this Parliament. Once again, you pass the law without knowing things, and then others have to worry about how to do it. If the aim of this Parliament is to bring about a situation in which only Members and European officials can afford to drive, then I think that is what we are heading in this direction. If this is your idea to solve the problem of traffic jams on the Strasbourg bridge, I really congratulate you very much. I voted against.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Protecting the environment, including air, is probably one of the most important goals of our civilization. It is therefore worth devotion to such an important task a great deal of attention and activities, including financial resources. However, everything must be done within the right time frame, rationally, sensibly, so that one good does not undermine another good. One of these goods, which I mentioned at the beginning, is precisely the environment, a clean, healthy environment, but the other equally important good is man, his family, his work, his life, opportunities for development. This good is also the state and the international community, which is why the objectives we set ourselves in terms of environmental protection should take into account the needs of man, society, the countries of the international community. It seems to me that we would have had a chance here if we had adopted a compromise solution, but we went much further as Parliament and this is not a rational and sensible solution.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I could not support this proposal in the end, i considered the european Commission's original proposal to reduce emissions for new cars and vans by 30% by 2030 compared to 2021, so I considered the sharpened proposal – 35% – to be realistic, and I considered the joint proposal of the ECR and our group to be sensible and acceptable. However, I would no longer want to set ambitious targets that will be pursued anyway, and this is, I think, one of those objectives that has been agreed. A 40% reduction is one of those goals that is very ambitious but not realistic.  The setting of these limits must, in my opinion, reflect both the need for climate-related changes and the possibilities of the automotive sector, which provides thousands of jobs not only in the Czech Republic but also throughout the EU. We must encourage carmakers to invest in the development of low-emissions and electric cars, while at the same time we must not resort to measures that should, as a result, dramatically affect the price of a car and thus fall significantly on the end consumer.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of this report because the environment cannot wait any longer. The emissions targets must be ambitious in order to be able to reverse the dire situation of global warming caused by greenhouse gas cases by 2030. We must establish a value of at least more than 40 %.  The targets set out in the Commission's text are insufficient and provide for an excessively positive scenario. History shows that the automotive sector has been systematically in breach of the targets set by the abuse of exceptions and subterfuge. It is time for us to give a strong political signal that clearly indicates an end-to-end trajectory for fossil fuels, a focus on the electric technologies of renewable energy sources and demand greater transparency in the measurements of gases emitted. Efficient cars bring enormous benefits. In addition to low emissions, they bring more competitiveness to European industry, bring more jobs and bring less dependence on oil imports.  By favouring low-emission and zero-emission light vehicle quotas and, on the other hand, by penalising the rest, we are enabling greater accessibility of this type of vehicle with obvious savings for consumers and air quality. Ladies and gentlemen, there is only a future with fresh air.

name: John HOWARTH
text: – Mr President, I am delighted to support this report today, particularly the 40% reduction target for 2030 for both cars and light vans. It’s a big step forward in the ambition of the European Union and everyone who has, as I have, dealt with transport policy and looked at emissions from transport, knows that without serious action on emissions from vehicles, you will not meet climate targets and you will not address key problems of air quality in urban areas.  Every time we’ve had a step forward on this we’ve had to have the automotive industry dragged, kicking and screaming, in the direction of reform. But they have nothing to fear, because this will make the industry more competitive in the future and it is essential that we have just transition funding for workers who would otherwise, potentially, be thrown out of work because of these changes. I believe they have nothing to fear if we do this properly.

name: Morten MESSERSCHMIDT
text: Mr President! It is absolutely central to a nation's autonomy to have control over the economic, i.e. on tax collections, on the finance bill and also on the way in which we tax the deal. That is why we voted against this report. We do not want to be part of the EU's setting a top limit on VAT payments. Fundamentally, it should be the case that it is a Member State's issue of how to finance its budgets - and when the EU should have its budgets funded, it should be the Member States that collect the taxes, not the European Union itself. So the whole line that this report takes is fundamentally opposed, because it leads to an increase in the federalisation of the whole financial system, the whole financial law system in Europe. I honestly do not believe that this is what Europeans want. That is why we are voting no.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Technical corrections to the VAT Directive are necessary. I am observing this directive through the lens of enormous problems regarding e-publications. It should be borne in mind that, more than a decade ago, in different countries, electronically supplied services were subject to very different rates: zero, 5%, 22% and even 23%. A few days ago, the Council agreed that reduced rates should apply to electronically supplied services, in this case e-books. On the other hand, this debate on this directive shows how much we have to do on this subject. And I am very pleased that this task has been undertaken. I supported the directive, supported the report and hope that the pace of response to changing business conditions in the case of VAT will be faster and better.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, low rates of value added tax help to strengthen competitiveness, to compensate for the problem of geographical removal of areas and transport costs. And while in the Aegean islands there should be a low rate of value added tax, at a time when in Turkey VAT is only 5%, as I said in my previous speeches, the government and the troika have imposed the highest VAT rate of 24%, at a time when the Aegean islands have been flooded with thousands of refugees and illegal immigrants and tourism is falling apart.  We are calling for a special VAT regime for the Aegean islands, as decided by the European Parliament in the case of the Italian Municipality of Campione d'Italia and the Italian waters of Lake Lugano, which have been exempted and have low VAT, because Switzerland, with which they are adjacent, has low VAT. We are calling for a special VAT regime for the Aegean islands, so that the islands can stand, that they can survive. It is our appeal.

name: Morten MESSERSCHMIDT
text: Mr President! One of the areas where globalisation has really taken place is, of course, the financial sector. I think we are all aware of that and have been through the last ten years, starting with the financial crisis, which was something of an eye-opener and what has happened subsequently. Therefore, it also makes sense to create these new rules, to obtain insurance contracts that ensure a more transparent and comparable system. In line with international developments and financial globalisation, more and more consumers will need instruments that allow easy comparison of services offered across borders. Here I believe that what the ECON Committee has come up with in relation to insurance contracts is something that will benefit a great many consumers. That is why we voted in favour.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European The motion calls for an extension of ifrs international accounting standards to insurance contracts. Currently, this accounting standard is used in the EU for companies whose securities have appeared on the EU regulated market, the stock exchange. The report highlights that there are significant differences in insurance accounting, including in terms of revenue and profit. The motion contains a number of points harmonising the accounting rules for insurance contracts between different groups of countries. The aim is to provide a realistic description of the financial statements and better comparability within the insurance sector. On this basis, I supported the adoption of the report.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: – Mr President, it is very good that the European Parliament has started to address new phenomena in the digital space, be it blockchains or data sharing, replication and synchronization technologies. These are all new phenomena, they are phenomena that really have a cross-border global character and therefore, in a way, they are on the agenda of at least the European Parliament, and they are also phenomena that will certainly affect the digital space in the future. They will affect the flow of information and therefore the economy.  I supported this report, I would just intercede that we should be careful when considering or legising on these new phenomena and not get on thin ice. These are sensitive things, and as we have seen in the past few cases, when we have treated the Internet, attempts to regulate various matters related to it, it has not always been well understood.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, I would like to explain why I supported the report on the European Union's agenda for rural, mountainous and remote areas. This report deals with a majority territory in the European Union of 70% to 80%, but there are far fewer people living here in this comparison, around 20%. Therefore, even though it is such a large territory, it concerns a smaller population. Even so, the territory is very important in terms of food security, its agricultural production, in terms of environmental quality, in terms of oxygen production, water retention.  These are all very important functions that these areas have and deserve our attention, our protection. Also, people who live in these areas need the same quality services. I therefore consider it important that the European Union does not weaken policies that relate precisely to ensuring the infrastructure and quality of services in these territories, be it the common agricultural policy and other specific programmes.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: – Dear Mr President, honourable Members, rural, mountainous and remote areas make up 80% of the territory of the European Union, with more than half of the Union's population living there. At the same time, however, many are deprived of a number of services, such as social services, quality physical or digital infrastructure. It is no secret to anyone that the population, especially in mountainous regions, is ageing due to the lack of prospects and opportunities for economic development. However, this should be blamed on the governments of those countries that do not take the necessary measures to reach people. In Bulgaria nearly two years ago, a targeted investment program was prepared to support the development of Northwestern Bulgaria, the Rhodopes, Strandzha and Sakar. Unfortunately, this strategy seems to have stuck with someone's desk. I therefore call on the Bulgarian Government to take concrete measures aimed at creating economic opportunities for the development of these Bulgarian regions as soon as possible. The people of Smolyan, Strandzha-Sakar and Northwestern Bulgaria are just as European as everyone else in Europe.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: – Portugal, with the recent fire situation, is the only example of the failure of the European Union's cohesion policy, which objectively promoted the desertification of the rural world with the closure of public services and the mass destruction of thousands of farms and now, regrettably, the proposal for a multiannual financial framework, with less funding for cohesion , less money for the Common Agricultural Policy and more money for Security and Defence maintains the fundamental political guidelines of the European Union, which will aggravate the social and economic anaemia experienced by rural and mountainous areas.  But let us be serious on the part of the CFP, the fight against regional asymmetries goes far beyond cohesion policy. It means breaking away from the constraints of the European Union's policies at euro level at the level of the single market. Only then will it be possible to implement in Portugal a balanced regional development policy at the service of the people.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by This report is simply a concert of wishes. You want to subsidize everything at the taxpayer's expense. There are no things you wouldn't promise people, people who live far from other people. It is not known in the name of what, because if living in a secluded area does not pay off, then let people move to where it pays, and do not still sit in a remote area, where at the taxpayer's expense you will now send them urban transport. We just passed emission reductions at the same session, and now you're going to let the buses go there, so that instead of driving around the city on the mountains and emitting carbon dioxide. You just don't know what you want. Think about what you're really aiming for. I voted against.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I supported this motion for a resolution, and unlike my colleague and the speaker, Mr Sośnierz, I think it is very important to show our helping hand to those people who live in these areas. I certainly do not want 80% of europe's population to live in the largest agglomeration centres within 10 years. It poses a great risk to our future. If the inhabitants actually move only to the agglomerations and their rings.  We should also invest in these mountainous areas precisely because this landscape deserves it, that it deserves agricultural production that is carried out there, and we have to invest in infrastructure, that is, in the transport service of the territory, but also in services. There must be available health, school services, social care services. I think that the territory that My colleague Šojdrová has mentioned is quite extensive and to release it as my colleague, Mr Sośnierz, has suggested, I think that there is really no respect for those people who live there.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: – Mr President, I supported this report, I think it is a partial concern and I stress the partial concern of the European Union also of taking care of remote, mountainous and agricultural areas.  On the other hand, we know that the European budget is limited, that it will certainly not grow in the future, and therefore this whole issue must also be linked to the revision and reform of the common agricultural policy, which is still based on promoting production. And we need to transform it to support the all-round development of these very areas, that is, to develop infrastructure, networks, to grow quality of life, also to protect nature, water management. All of this is related, which is why it must go hand in hand with the restructuring of the budget and the reform of the common agricultural policy. I hope that this is where we are heading in this report.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by We pay a lot of attention in the European Parliament, but not only in urban policy. And it is hardly surprising – the absolute majority of people, especially in developed countries, live in cities. The share of rural and mountain areas in GDP in individual countries is also minimal, trace. But equality, equality, sustainable development – these values require us to treat rural, mountainous, remote and local communities appropriately.  I would just like to point out one point, so that it does not follow from our discussion that we do not take into account the needs of these areas and these people. Look at how much money is secured each year and in every financial perspective, whether within the framework of cohesion policy or under the common agricultural policy, precisely for these purposes, precisely for these areas, precisely for these communities.

name: Laura AGEA
text: Author. Madam President, Commissioner Thyssen, ladies and gentlemen, we are very pleased that we in this Parliament are debating at our request for citizenship income. A few months ago, thanks to our work, this House adopted our own text on minimum income as a measure to reduce poverty.  Ladies and gentlemen, this is a very expensive subject for us for two reasons. One, we are Italian and in Italy there is no income of citizenship. It is present in 26 out of 28 European countries but not in ours. Two, we are an expression of a political force, the 5 Star Movement, which is now in government of the country, a young force founded only on 4 October 2009. Citizenship income has been in our DNA since October 4, 2009. It was immediately the dream of Beppe Grillo and Gian Roberto Casaleggio. He's been there all these years, he's been on our program, we've taken him to all the squares. We have made the journey from Perugia to Assisi several times on foot, and we have made it a theme at the center of the political debate. I still remember those early years, it was a simple idea, but it is also true that simple things are the most extraordinary. Nor did it seem to us to be anything new, taking millions of poor people out of despair and poverty. All these years we have experienced it as a moral obligation, and I will tell you more, it seemed to us a battle of civilization in which political affiliaties had to disappear. We thought that those who oppose the income of citizens are opposed to Italians, not to the 5 Star Movement, and instead in Italy a stupid, devastating ideological war has been waged against our proposal. They thought they were hitting us, but they didn't realize they were hurting the millions of poor people that their social policies kept increasing. In those years, we kept saying "rest assured, when we go to government we will make the income of citizenship", I want to say this to all citizens living in absolute poverty, like Anna who a few years ago wrote to me to tell me her story. His is a story like so many, wife and husband with a failed job because of the crisis, the search for a job that is not found, the despair, the endless drama of not knowing how to get to the end of the day and the cowardice of a state that did not give answers, that turned its head the other way, because to some politicians the tables and numbers warm the heart more than the suffering of a person. Your story, Anna, I took you with me to the European Parliament, your life experience was my work agenda. I promised you, in fact I swore it to you, to you and to all the people who can't find a job. To all anna daughters and victims of a devastating economic crisis. In these years I have wanted this moment to come like nothing in the world to embrace you and to be able to say "we have not left you alone, we have kept our promise". With the government of change, in Italy there will be the income of citizenship for more than six million citizens. It is an epochal measure, we are erasing poverty in Italy, reviving consumption and relaunching the economy. You can't win with those who never give up, gian Roberto Casaleggio said, we never gave up, and the dream that nine years ago was few, today is everyone's dream. At the top the hearts of the weakest.

name: Laura AGEA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, thank you for the invitation and the opportunity to contribute to your debate on minimum income. Our joint commitments to the European people are to protect those most vulnerable, to create adequate jobs and to lift up those who have fallen behind. Less than a year ago, we reaffirmed the basic principles – the European Pillar of Social Rights, Principle 14 states that everyone lacking sufficient resources has the right to adequate minimum income benefits, ensuring a life with dignity at all stages of life. In 2008, the banking crisis and the ensuing sovereign debt crisis tested our economies, shocked our labour markets and put a strain on our social protection system. Unemployment rates and at-risk-of-poverty rates soared throughout the EU. In the past decade, we have had to tackle manifold emergency situations. However, with determination and hard work and by taking difficult decisions, we have managed to restore our economies. In 2017, the EU average unemployment rate stood at 7.3% and employment exceeded its pre-crisis peak. Albeit with some delay, youth unemployment and long-term unemployment also continue to decline. Today, thanks to our combined efforts, the Europe 2020 strategy target of 75% employment rate for men and women seems again to be within reach. While the picture looks positive from certain angles, there is no place for complacency. The total number of people at risk of poverty or social exclusion remains very high. In 2016, 118 million European citizens, 23.5% of the total population, were at risk of poverty, even after social transfers. It is clear we still have a long way to go before we reach the Europe 2020 target of lifting at least 20 million people out of poverty. Ladies and gentlemen, we are all increasingly aware that economic growth must be to the benefit of all and must be socially sustainable. This is clearly demonstrated by the fact that almost all Member States have made a real effort and have established schemes for minimum income or benefit in one form or another. Furthermore, Member States are making good use of the open method of coordination (OMC), to cooperate and to exchange best practices. The European Semester equally has provided an excellent platform for cooperation in this area. However, minimum income schemes do not exist in a vacuum. The real challenge is to establish inclusive labour markets to make sure that people don’t fall through the social net and, at the same time, to ensure that national social security systems remain sustainable. Balancing these elements is not an easy task, especially if we look at the wider context of an ageing population and increased digitalisation and robotisation. Again, I am grateful for your invitation to contribute to this debate. It was with great interest that we took note of Parliament’s latest resolution on minimum income policies as a tool for fighting poverty. I’m looking forward to hearing your input on this important matter.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I am very glad that this House keeps social issues high on its agenda and debates them regularly. As President Juncker said in his State of the Union address, Europe has largely turned a page on the economic and financial crisis, and this is well reflected in the employment and social situation in Europe.  Employment has indeed been growing for more than five years in a row and there are now 239 million people at work in the European Union. This is more than ever before. The unemployment rate has dropped to 6.8%. These are the figures from Eurostat for August 2018. In 2016, there were 5.6 million fewer people at risk of poverty or social exclusion than at the peak of 2012, and there are clear signs that the situation has further improved since. For instance, severe material deprivation declined in almost all Member States, falling to an all—time low of 33.4 million in 2017. This is a reduction of 16 million people since 2012. Having said this, we should not be complacent. Thirty—three million materially deprived people is still too many, and we know that income inequality has stabilised in the last few years, but at higher levels in the European Union than before the crisis. Moreover, the overall number of people at risk of poverty or social exclusion, albeit reduced relative to 2012, is still higher now in 2018. This is, as we all know, far from the Europe 2020 target of taking 20 million people out of risk of poverty and social exclusion, and that is why the Commission has proposed to act.  A year ago we all proclaimed the European Pillar of Social Rights, which recognises that everyone lacking sufficient resources has the right to adequate minimum income benefits ensuring a life in dignity at all stages of life, and effective access to enabling goods and services. For those who can work, minimum income benefits should be combined with incentives to integrate or reintegrate into the labour market. That is what the Pillar says. In other words, the provision of adequate minimum income schemes is non—discriminatory and should go hand—in—hand with access to services, with employment in line with the active inclusion approach.  However, I would like to recall that the setting—up of minimum income benefits is the responsibility of Member States. Since the introduction of minimum income schemes in Greece and Italy in the last two years, now all Member States have some form of minimum income scheme. However, their design and implementation vary greatly.  For this reason, the Commission and Member States have decided to deepen the analysis. A benchmarking framework has been agreed with Member States for minimum income schemes supporting a thorough across—country comparison of national practices. It looks in particular at adequacy, coverage and activation and it will feed into the country—specific analysis in the 2019 European Semester. The European Semester has proved to be an effective framework to monitor and provide guidance to Member States. It is now the main instrument for monitoring the implementation of the Pillar. In 2018, some Member States received country—specific recommendations addressing minimum income. And, of course, the European Semester framework allows us to have a comprehensive view, including the availability of fiscal space to expand social provision.  In addition, the Commission has already put forward proposals and initiatives that want to make sure no one is left behind. To ensure the rights for the most vulnerable workers we presented the proposal for a directive on transparent and predictable working conditions to tackle women’s under—representation in employment and to create a more balanced distribution of caring responsibilities between women and men we put forward the work—life balance for parents and carers initiative. So this is just to mention a few of our initiatives on the table. They now need to be adopted and implemented and, honourable Members, I count on your support to make sure that they will be adopted within the current mandate of this Parliament.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, as the Group of the Party of European Socialists and Democrats, we strongly wanted the European Pillar of Social Rights, which provides, among other things, for income support measures for people in difficulty and at risk of poverty, because we believe that no one should be left behind and that all citizens have the right to living conditions. , social and economic dignified.  We have supported, in particular, proposals for the weakest, such as the Youth Guarantee for our young people, the Child Guarantee for our children, and we have promoted concrete aid to families, especially single parents with a woman in charge who are those who have almost 50% risk of falling into poverty.  We believe, however, that a person's first right is that of a job, decent, secure, stable and protected work, a job that allows everyone to be an active part of society and contribute to its growth. We believe that the work should be paid for and paid for the right. That is why our group was the first to launch the proposal for a guaranteed minimum wage at European level. And we're talking about the guaranteed minimum wage, not just income.  We believe that a minimum wage for all workers allows us to lead a peaceful life with real work for all, and that is our main objective. All this, of course, within the framework of investments capable of growing the economy and stimulating the participation of people in society, especially with strong active labour, training and continuous support policies. However, protections and rights must not turn into forms of past-looking welfare, but must ensure that everyone has the opportunity to contribute to the growth of society and not to be excluded from it. However, the current debate is very much linked to an internal Italian political debate which is preparing a measure that seems to us to be discriminatory and punitive, given that, for example, it would be reserved only for Italian citizens, against European rules, which say instead that it must be reserved for all people at risk of poverty living in countries.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Ladies and gentlemen! This debate we are having here is yet another example of how the Commission and the Council are misleading citizens with definitions. Because we are suddenly talking about a minimum income. But that is wrong, ladies and gentlemen. Mrs Bresso has just pointed this out. We are not talking about an income, we are talking about minimum social assistance. An income is something associated with gainful employment. An income is something that is associated with effort and also with fulfillment, because you can work and because you are allowed to work. Anyone who has spoken here about a minimum income – the representative of the Commission, the representative of the Council, the representatives of certain political parties – has misled the citizens, because they give the impression that a problem is being solved, which is actually being resolved by paying a minimum social support and thus trying to keep people in the joblessness. Or at least there is a risk that they will remain in unemployment precisely because they receive this kind of support. It goes without saying that we provide a minimum level of social support for those who are unemployed. Clearly, no one disputes that. I actually find it downright ridiculous that we need to talk about it again today. The real problem, however, is: how do we get the people who get social support because they have no work into work? In other words, we still need to talk about what incentives we give people to move to work when they receive social support. There is, for example, this idea of an unconditional basic income, which is quite an interesting idea, but which must of course always answer the question of how great the temptations are to somehow rest on this basic income and not to switch into employment, and which must also answer the question of who should actually finance this and when the tax liability begins. Those who only talk about social support and do not talk about the incentives to work are misleading citizens because they are not asking the right questions.

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, Mrs Thyssen, thank you very much for discussing our affairs. The minimum income or minimum income of insertion, or some model of minimum income, which there are many, is already recognized in the pillar of social rights and a year ago, almost every day, Parliament said that it is a fundamental instrument for combating poverty. So, there's little to talk about there. What you have to do is get down to business. Of course, the Commission has done things, but per maybe, within all that needs to be developed from the social pillar, it must intensify its efforts, and it must intensify them because what makes the minimum income is to tackle a very hard problem, which is poverty. It is inadmissible that rich areas of the world will still be able to maintain pockets of poverty. And we have to attack this. It is shown, from the studies, that minimum income systems are effective in that. Having said that, and that the ALDE Group fully supports that right and the intelligent implementation of that right, we do need to talk precisely that this is in the hands of the countries and what the Commission can do, and I would say that urgently. In this area, it is clear that minimum income is just one more measure to help people include. Why? Because the second point I say is obvious to the ALDE Group: we do not believe in assisted societies. They're unworthy. We don't believe in assisted people. It has to be transient and everything has to go get them out of there. Second point. Of course, minimum incomes have to be at the service of the cohesion of nations and Europe because other words, economically it is a disaster. You have done very well to point out in the European Semester for Spain how regionalisation, for example, of minimum income is a factor of exclusion and brutal inequality. And that has to be subject to the Commission's supervision. And finally, the funding. We should not be afraid to talk about European solidarity funding on these issues.

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, we’re coming up to the International Day for the Eradication of Poverty on 17 October, so this is a very timely debate, and I thank my colleagues for proposing it. The minimum income scheme that we’ve been talking about in Parliament is about the last resort income so that people are not left destitute. We should also be aware in this that we’re not talking here about unemployment benefit, because not everybody is in a position to be able to work.  This is, as people have said, an ongoing problem for the European Union. It’s really disturbing to hear the Commissioner remind us about the stabilising of income inequality. Even in my own region, London, which is just about the richest region in the European Union, we have over one—in—three children who are living below the poverty line. So when we’re looking at questions about minimum income, adequacy is a key point. Many of our Member States’ systems don’t ensure adequacy; they don’t keep up with the rising cost of living; they cap systems; they have harsh criteria in many cases, and they certainly have an increasingly harsh public perception of people who are on these schemes.  When we’re looking at what else the European Union can do, we should come back to an idea that was floated some time ago by the Anti—Poverty Network, which is about putting in place a directive setting out the principles upon which minimum income schemes should be based within our Member States.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we seem to want to produce, produce and produce more, and then we do not give anyone the means to consume what we produce. Looks like we're stuck in some kind of Marx Brothers joke.  We want to protect and protect our borders, but then we don't protect each other and each other.  There are many people around us, there are many people in Europe — tens of millions of people — who cannot afford decent housing, who cannot afford adequate food, who cannot afford their children's textbooks, or who cannot afford heating in winter.  Minimum income is no privilege, it is an urgency. Of course, it shouldn't be a handout, it's a right.  Because, ladies and gentlemen, let us be aware: Europe only has a future if we are not leaving millions of people on the way. Ensuring the right to life, that our people have guaranteed existence, must be the backbone of the Union, of our Union.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the demand for dignity and social justice from millions of citizens experiencing the tragedy of poverty, lack of work and social exclusion needs immediate answers, we can no longer wait for the failures, the high social costs of austerity policies for which the weakest part of society is always the lowest price. We have nurtured economies from which not everyone benefits, but few, which tend to dismantle the system of protection of workers and the most vulnerable groups, leaving unsatisfied the needs of those who live in situations of extreme social hardship, economies that allow the exploitation of work, boundless in forms of neo-schiavism, for example caporalato. Wealth continues to be concentrated in the hands of a few and fails to stem the spread of poverty, lack of job opportunities, inequalities produced in the name of manoeuvres that must take into account debt reduction, budget balance and market confidence. The time has come for Europe to change course and to remedy the wrong policies that have produced all this. It is in this context that the granting of a minimum income, accompanied by measures aimed at integration into the world of work, education and training programmes and restarting the real economy, is part of this context. An example of this is the income of citizenship that the Italian Government wants to achieve through the manoeuvring of the people. We are not talking about forms of charity or welfare, but about an instrument of social redemption, inclusion and participation in society, which ensures the full exercise of fundamental rights, an instrument that will also serve to combat the action of mafias and corruption, which feed on the condition of economic blackmail in order to strike at and restrict individual freedoms, rights and to attract those in need to the world of illegality.  The minimum income that a Europe that wants to be fairer and fairer needs must be an instrument of civilisation, one that provides equal dignity and equal opportunities for all its citizens and does not leave anyone behind.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, the income of citizenship or the minimum income, as presented today, is an attempt to respond to one of the most egregious aspects of the failure of sixty years of European integration. It did not in any way follow up on the prosperity movement that grew out of the boom years of post-war reconstruction. Nor did it prevent or cushion the great crisis of 2008.  Today, it is no longer enough to work to escape poverty. This is, of course, unacceptable. Moreover, almost all European countries have a minimum wage and/or a minimum old age and/or social minimums. Yet all of these minimums are themselves below the poverty line.  It is therefore a comprehensive European policy of economic recovery training individuals and freeing up businesses that is becoming urgent, but also of major global policies of direct responsibility of the Member States, which should help to preserve their social system.  So let's just move on to dealing with the consequences and finally tackle the causes!

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Madam President, the minimum guaranteed income, boasted by the European Union, far-right, liberal, social democrat, neo-left and opportunist, who like-for-like support it, is a mockery and a trap. He's sharing poverty. It is paid for by the less poor, but never by companies that are taxed, taxed and subsidised. It is seen as a safety net on the issues of now liberated redundancies, high unemployment and extreme poverty, in order to prevent social explosions, especially in order to squeeze down all wages, to abolish social benefits. It strikes collective agreements: see Macron's France, Tsipras's Greece, which supposedly comes out of the memorandums, but re-votes and implements a memorandum law on the effective abolition of collective agreements, the definition of the minimum wage by the state on the basis of profits and the competitiveness of businesses; what capitalists demand.  Workers must reject this Trojan horse, handouts and the lesser evil that always turns out to be greater. With the nationwide strike in November in Greece, to claim collective agreements, make up for losses, increased benefits throughout the duration of unemployment for all unemployed.

name: Romana TOMC
text: – Thank you very much for the floor, Madam President.  The idea of a minimum income is, of course, not new. It has already been successfully implemented in many countries, and I am defending it myself, but let me say immediately that I am not talking about a universal basic income or a minimum wage, because these concepts are too often mixed. And we need to make this clear so that we don't have any misconceptions, because even today there was quite a bit of confusion in this Chamber. I am talking about the need for all citizens to get help, which can also be said to be a minimum income or a social transfer, when they need it. However, when we are talking about this at European level, we must, of course, pay attention to subsidiarity, take into account the different economic development between countries and cannot exercise coercion, but we can encourage Member States to set an appropriate minimum income in their national legislation. However, a minimum income must not be just a right that is taken for granted. This right must also be linked to obligations and responsibility, and we often also adopt regulations here in Parliament, where we forget this reciprocity. In Europe, we want to maintain the social standard that we are used to, and our standard is the highest in the world. That's good. At the same time, however, we must be careful not to devalue the importance of work and decent pay for work, the ratio between the minimum wage for work and the minimum income, which, as we can also understand from this debate, is, as we can also understand from this debate, social assistance.  This relationship is completely inappropriate in some countries, including my own country, and this does not, of course, encourage people to actively seek work, but encourages them into passivity. We need to pay attention to this in our policies.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, in line with the debate, do we intend to create universal aid for people by being citizens? What are we trying to do? We aim to create a new safety net that protects people from adversity;  that when a person has lost unemployment and all financial aid, by redistributing wealth through public authorities we create a new safety net to prevent them from falling into poverty. We intend that, since when? Precisely since a situation of near-poverty vulnerability is created. How long? Until you are able to find a job and, of course, linked to the will to find a job. But I think we need to be aware that creating a minimum income is a new instrument ⸻ which is true that we have enshrined in the social pillar⸻ that what it does is give more dignity to democratic societies, because it is not only a measure of social justice, it is also a measure of economic efficiency and a measure that prevents many people from disassociated from democratic systems precisely because democracy has taken away their last chance , has dropped them down the ravine of economic crises or economic recessions. But, Mrs Thyssen, I share your good words, but we need not only good words. We need political activity, political initiative. We have created and enshrined minimum income within the social pillar and this also allows us to enshrine it as a European policy calling for a directive to regulate, forcing Member States to develop minimum income systems. We cannot enshrine the social pillar, the minimum income within the social pillar and call it for political inactivity in the European Union. We have the possibility of creating a directive that allows the development throughout the European Union, throughout the Member States, of income systems with some homogeneity. Because, Commissioner, we need co-responsibility. We all agree that it is a good tool for promoting social justice and economic efficiency. If we all agree, let's all make words become facts.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Whatever we call the subject of this debate, whether we call it citizens' incomes or unconditional basic income or minimum income, we are always talking about redistribution, and redistribution does not regularly lead to poor people getting richer, but to the rich becoming poorer. In other words, it is the completely wrong way to achieve anything sensible and sustainable here. Because in the case of an unconditional basic income, one will always have to answer the question of how much it should be paid. Should everyone, including a millionaire, actually get it? Or do I have to introduce bureaucracy for this? These are all unanswered questions, but they have to be answered beforehand. But it is also crucial: this question does not have to be answered in the European Parliament, because this is a question that the states of the EU must define for themselves in a sovereign decision. And in doing so, they have to decide what they can and want to afford in terms of social benefits. This is something that each country can decide for itself. However, we must not turn a blind eye to the fact that the countries of the euro area in particular have very special obligations here. Those who participate in a common currency must also adhere to the common rules, e.B. debt limits. If we now take Italy, for example, because the justification for this request comes from a representative of Italy, we have 134% of the debt ratio in relation to gross domestic product. So if Italy wants to afford something like this, then it is wonderful. But the question must then be asked in Italy: can this be afforded? I therefore believe that we cannot adopt such measures at European level, which will result in the damage to solidarity, otherwise we will introduce transfers that are in no way justified.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Madam President, coming from Sweden, I can only reassure my colleagues that I am very committed to keeping a strong safety net that can alleviate the impacts of poverty and social exclusion. However, listening to this debate, I have a feeling that some of you are proposing the basic income guarantee, which is a completely different thing. There, I have to say the basic income guarantee undermines the incentive to participate in society.  The help and minimum income connected to it should be designed to help overcome unemployment and find work for those able to work. Help can never be an unconditional free ride for healthy adult people to live off other people’s incomes. On the contrary, if you design it that way, you are likely to lead to high rates of inequality and poverty. Reallocating welfare payments from targeted transfers, those for unemployment, housing disability, etc. to a generalised transfer for everyone, means that the amount that goes to the most deserving will be lower. Do we really want less for everybody? Do we really want less for those who need more?  Therefore, I urge you, we have to have a minimum income in a certain way, designed to help overcoming the troubles and the poverty that exist, but if you design it as an income guarantee you will end up stripping people of the incentive to participate in society and make it worse for the needy.

name: Florent MARCELLESI
text: – Madam President, Europe is one of the richest societies in the world; that's why we can't let people living in poverty here.  To end this social scandal, Europe would have to take a step forward, at the height of the one it took with social security after World War II. Well, yes! Let us bet at European level on a universal basic income as a sign of the identity of 21st century Europe.  There are people in poverty who do not have jobs, and jobs, such as care, who are not recognized. In addition, there are profound technological changes that change the concept of work, as well as other ways of contributing to society that go beyond production and consumption.  Universal basic income is a response to these challenges and, above all, it is a great opportunity to cohere our continent after the 2008 crisis, give it a new just and sustainable boost and be, again, an example to this world.  I hope that the European Commission, Commissioner, will study it.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: Madam President, more than 120 million poor people, including workers, are a deep binge on the pediment of the European Union.  We should act to ensure that every citizen living in the European Union has a decent minimum income, that is, well above the poverty line, combined with an effective right to health, housing and training leading to the guarantee of work for which there should no longer be a salary below 60% of the European median wage.  But the main issue is work and its remuneration. Commissioner, you should launch a framework directive for professional social security combining a guarantee of work and lifelong learning for each and every member of the European citizen and the right to health and housing. The financial resources of large companies today, those of banks, central bank loans given to private banks, exist today for this. In short, there is an urgent need to create a Europe of work.

name: Michał MARUSIK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Ladies and about! We need to look at the inevitable dependence of causes and effects on the economy. If we interfere with voluntary contracts in such a way that someone is forced to pay out larger amounts than they have negotiated on the market, then some contracts will not be executed. Some contracts will be broken and people will move on to keeping those few who stay in work. But in the case of these contracts, which will be maintained at higher forced prices, the cost of manufacturing will simply increase and the prices of goods and services will increase. We will be able to buy less. We will be poorer. And if we can buy less, consumer demand falls, then production will fall, so, ladies and down, I appeal for common sense, because ignorance in economics leads to sabotage. Well, let us not be the place that causes the economic catastrophe of the whole of Europe. Let's think a little more wisely. Some demagogic words sound beautiful, but no one is going to eat it.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Madam President, the minimum income is nothing more than a wish list used, because it sounds good to the ears of those who do not have the means to survive or support their families. But the reality is much more different from your announcements.  Initially the aim should be to create and secure decently paid jobs for those who wish to work and not vaguely to secure some income. But how can we avoid the risk of state benefits being exploited, especially by immigrants, who why work, since the minimum guaranteed income easily guarantees them a living? The logic of allowances and flexible forms of employment with very low wages does not guarantee the decent living of workers, with the exception of disabled people, who are entitled to protection automatically.  Protect work, create new full-time jobs, and then you won't need any statutory minimum income. Those who really want a single market will have to explain to us why there is no single basic salary throughout the European Union. Is it to serve the interests of Germany, other large states and multinationals?

name: Geoffroy DIDIER
text: Madam President, there is a lot of talk today about the income from inactivity. I would also like to talk about the revenues from the activity. In Europe, as we know, the differences between the different minimum incomes can vary by a factor ranging from 1 to 8. For example, it is 2,000 euros in Luxembourg, while it is only 260 euros in Bulgaria. Such differences are an ideal breeding ground for the proponents of withdrawal, the followers of Europhobia, because the economic and social consequences of such wage gaps can be disastrous for factories, which are increasingly closing, as for workers who unfortunately suffer unfair competition from seconded workers. And it is indeed the least advantaged who pay the price for the dysfunctions of the internal market. Millions of them believe that Europe is not only responsible for certain bankruptcies of our industrial fabrics, but also responsible for unemployment and precariousness. A first step has thus been taken thanks to the decisive contribution of our EPP colleague, Elisabeth Morin-Chartier, who, in revising the directive on seconded workers, imposed this fundamental principle: 'equal work, equal pay'. But I propose that we go further, and with regard to the minimum wage gap, I would like to propose something very concrete today. Just as we are considering conditioning the allocation of structural funds on respect for the rule of law, I propose to condition the allocation of these same funds on compliance with certain wage criteria, such as the introduction of a minimum wage high enough to give dignity and to combat unfair competition and social dumping. Ladies and gentlemen, if we do not want the differences in wages to fuel disputes between peoples, it is imperative that we harmonize our social systems. This is the credibility of the European project.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is essential to insist on Stronger European instruments to combat poverty and social exclusion.  Poverty and social exclusion are still at alarming levels in Europe today. The Democratic Party, the Group of Socialists and Democrats have for years been at the forefront of this battle with proposals such as European unemployment insurance, the framework directive for income support measures. I was hoping, however, that with this debate promoted by my colleagues of the 5 Star Movement a greater specificity in the proposals concerning the so-called citizenship income, because I have not yet seen a text, there is no decree, we do not even have the economic and financial document, today, available. I have heard clear words from Mrs Ferrara about job placement, measures against a non-market welfare system instead for a measure that integrates people into the world of work, but for today we have heard about social "cards" to buy bread and milk, socially useful jobs, we have seen millions of euros of savings of Italians burn with the confusion of these days and we have heard the idea of excluding European citizens who are not Italian citizens , European citizens resident by this measure. It seems to me that, with regard to Italy, very clear right-wing measures are hiding with regard to Italy: the flat tax, the tax amnesty, to which the allies of the 5 Stars, Salvini and the League have committed themselves.  So I say, today, we have in Italy the inclusion income, the REI, which will give us support to put the funds also from the European Social Fund plus to support this measure with that budget.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Speaking in this discussion, I would like to point out that the effectiveness of the experiments conducted in Europe and around the world in paying out unconditional basic income or other forms of guaranteed income has not yet been sufficiently positively verified. Experiments conducted in Finland, France, also by the new Italian Government, which wants to pay eur 780 per month to every unemployed person or person living in poverty from 1 January, have not yet been assessed positively. It should also be recalled that in a referendum in 2016, the Swiss strongly rejected the idea of guaranteed income payments, considering this idea to be too costly and harmful to the economy. Experts draw attention to the negative features of this concept: strong wage pressure from already employed and less incentive to work and seek employment, as well as a strong incentive for increased immigration processes to Europe. Moreover, in order to finance such schemes, there would have to be a much greater progression of income tax than before, because this tax is widely identified as a source... (The President has received the speaker's vote)

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Madam President, the best response against the populsmos that disintegrate Europe is to make our Union a useful project for people, to put people at the centre of public policy. And that means developing the social pillar, combating the risk of exclusion and poverty and maintaining social cohesion. In short, values that are from the beginning in the European project. Principles that the party to which I belong sponsored as a hallmark of this project, as certified by our contributions in the Hague Congress and in the New International Teams. They were defended by a politician, lehendakari Aguirre, retaliated against by Francoism, who preached social policy by example. He made a reference for advanced social management in the 1930s and his own company, Chocolates Bilbaínos. Today, if we want to be true to that hallmark of the European project, we must bet on insertion income. They are programs that help rescue people with the same determination that banks have been rescued with. This was described by the current lehendakari of the Basque Country. The Basque Country, true to this social vocation, invests almost 40% of the total amount spent in the Spanish State annually on such programmes when we account for only 4% of the total population. The experience of more than twenty-five years of operation of our income guarantee income shows that offering this support to people without any recourse to workers with precarious jobs or low-income pensioners minimizes exclusion, marginalization and the risk of poverty. It encourages access or insertion into the labor market and mitigates social bankruptcy and protects integration. That is why we support a European project.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: Thank you, Mr President, you have now taken the floor. You exceeded your speaking time by almost half a minute, and that is, of course, away from someone else.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: – Poverty and social exclusion are one of the most pressing problems in many countries in the European Union. Despite economic growth, individual people, families and even entire regions continue to be poor. Social policy is often sacrificed to solve other problems, and talk of living and well-being standards is often forgotten. Although the European Parliament recently adopted a resolution on policies guaranteeing a minimum income as a tool to combat poverty, the issue of commitment and responsibility of national powers against the most vulnerable members of society is a cause for concern. In Lithuania, for example, the painful problems of irresponsible social warfare caused a decade ago are now being repaired. We say, 'Irresponsible politicians will be punished by the electorate'. However, we must already look for ways to make social policy and social investment issues fit the agenda of both national states and Parliament in Europe.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: – Madam President, we believe that Member States should have the sovereign capacity to define their instruments for responding to growing economic and social inequalities, poverty and exclusion, among others. The minimum income should be subject to a temporary, transitional measure of dignification of the condition of those in situations of greater deprivation and vulnerability. A response that requires complementary measures of inclusion, through public policies of employment, support and promotion of national productive capacity with a view to job creation, responses that cannot compromise other instruments already in force and which should not be confused with proposals of apparent modernity, such as the availability wage or the universal minimum income.
