False solutions that we reject. The recognition of the causes justifying such instruments and the increase in exploitation and poverty and of constraints imposed by the European Union are crucial for the definition of alternative policies that determine a more equitable redistribution of wealth, the promotion of decent work with rights, the valorization of wages and the guarantee of free, universal and quality public services.

name: Auke ZIJLSTRA
text: Mr President, there is no discussion for economists. Minimum wages are fine for people with work and bad for people out of work. The "insider-outsider" effect is a diabolical dilemma. However, the free movement of people has added an extra dimension to this discussion. Because full employment in the European Union is an illusion, partly because the euro is not working, there are now endless numbers of people available who are disrupting the local labour market by wanting to work against starvation wages in another Member State. The European Union is not making an int trouble by tackling this problem, but by hijacking the social agenda of the Member States and imposing minimum wages. Fundamentally, however, that is not an answer. After all, the minimum wage in the Netherlands is a millionaire's ransom in Slovakia. Moreover, the European social agenda undermines the legal freedom of negotiation of trade unions and employers' organisations. It must therefore be different, unless it is a European value to divide poverty equally. Because it's not the employers who are causing the lower wages here. Lower and falling wages are inherent in the internal market and the free movement of people. Mr President, you must be able to live on a job. The labour market must therefore be accessible to local workers and disruption must be combated. I cannot draw any other conclusion than that the free movement of people must be called into question.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab If someone has the right to some evidence, then someone else has a duty to provide them with that proof. Promising help at someone else's expense, Mrs Agea, is not charity, it's just thievery. And if that were to happen to your salaries, I understand. But if you promise at the taxpayer's expense, it is simply a shame that you are in a faction that has freedom in your name. What is freedom? If one person has to work forcibly on another, it is slavery, not freedom. This is slavery. At the same time, you acknowledge that 23% of people in Europe are still at risk of poverty. It means that your social policies don't work, they just encourage people to be poor, or at least they seem like that. Because if we reward a course of action, we have more of it in society. If we reward people for inaction, for not doing, for laziness, for pretending to be poor, then we will have more people like that. And at the same time we punish them for their reliable work, because then we take money for those who do not work reliably.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support Thanks to rapid technological changes and automation, we can see serious challenges in the field of employment. According to multiple estimates, between 75 million and 375 million people globally will have to change professions by 2030 thanks to automation. In my country, Hungary, only about 500,000 jobs could be at risk from automation, especially among low-skilled people. Unconditional basic income is a dead end. Despite noble intentions, pilot projects for introduction have failed because they are costly, encourage inactivity and are unfair. I am convinced that a conditional support system to encourage learning and work is the right response to these challenges. Responsible economic policy can only choose forms of support linked to conditions, which take into account the specificities of the country. I therefore do not personally support mandatory EU rules on the concept of adequate minimum income, even though there is already a minimum wage in Hungary. A single and binding EU rule makes Member States' employment policies inflexible and has the opposite effect in the long term, since specific national circumstances and situations can no longer be taken into account.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Minister, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. On the subject of minimum income, I want to be short and clear: people should be able to live off their jobs. That is what it is all about. Whether they are click workers, truck drivers, work in an office, live in the north, south, east or west of Europe. The best guarantee for this is strong trade unions, a functioning social partnership, a nation state and a European Union that create the framework conditions for this. These include minimum social standards, such as minimum income schemes and the elimination of wage and social dumping, the child guarantee, the Youth Guarantee. In other words, a social network on which we should all work here. This is what ultimately provides the basis for really enabling people to live off their work. Moreover, we now even need a wage increase, because the economy is buzzing.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I hear here about basic income, the minimum wage, only normative rates. You can repeat this for as long as you want: the world does not change! Minimum incomes depend on the productivity of the economy. The decisive factor is whether jobs are made available. And then I would like to look at Mrs Thyssen's figures. These are the figures I always have. Please tell your staff that they are presenting correct numbers. If you take the northern countries out of the unemployment figure for Europe, you can see how dramatic the situation is still. And look at where jobs have been created. That is what we have discussed here in this House. These are precarious jobs. We have more work for less money. Please look at this, then you will see that a rift is going through Europe, that the North is doing well because it has an undervalued euro, and we are dealing with an overvalued euro. As long as you do not eliminate this basic phenomenon, we will keep saying what we need and will not change anything.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: – Dear Sirs, today's debate is the story of the people tom ed out of the European Pillar of Social Rights and the European Parliament resolution of October last year offering a protective net, as used by acrobats, except that it is a network to protect people from falling into the depths of poverty. Yes, poverty. For even today, we must remember the European Commission's data that 119 million citizens of the Union, or a quarter of all its citizens, live on the brink of poverty and social exclusion even after receiving social support.  Excessive income inequality is damaging social cohesion and also hinders sustainable economic growth. Growth alone does not solve the problem of social exclusion. In times of crisis, those on the lowest incomes will be far more affected than those who have been given economic growth by material security and wealth. The different level of development of the countries of the European Union is also at the critical disadvantage of the most disadvantaged citizens in the income. Problems cannot be solved through policies at European Union level, we know this, but it is clear that we need a more coherent and decent life for a man's worthwhile and decent life.  These should be a reminder to the Union, and not just to individual countries, that a decent life, even with a minimum income, is a human fundamental right.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: – Madam President, the figures are clear, there is enough wealth in the world to guarantee people's dignity, we only need to share it better. I support basic, universal, European income, so that no person is condemned to live in poverty or to accept jobs in increasingly precarious conditions, I support free, universal, quality public services for all, policies to provide affordable housing, put an end to tax fraud and tax evasion, decent retirement pensions guaranteed by public budgets , reducing working hours and better labour sharing, decent wages and decent agricultural prices for farmers and farmers as well.  We will therefore be able to fight poverty at European level because poverty too, Commissioner, has a face of women, unemployed people, young people, children or retired people.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is well known, whenever it fears the rise of dissent, the European Union ventures into a ground it does not like: the social terrain. Because unable to bring prosperity and full employment to all its Member States, the European Union is trying to make itself aware by coming out of this old chimera of the European minimum income. But several questions arise: how to impose a minimum income when social policy is the exclusive competence of the Member States? And even so, how do you calculate it? Should it be set at 60% of the median income, as indicated in the initiative report voted a year ago? If it is too low, it will not change anything and it will not reduce poverty or social inequalities. If it is too high, it will lead to an increase in public deficits and a decrease in the competitiveness of companies in the short term, in total contradiction with Brussels' injunctions on the consolidation of public finances. As usual, the European Union is trying to solve problems in vain, which it is causing.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Guaranteed minimum income is the idea that every citizen of working age, whether working or not, should be guaranteed and, if necessary, paid by the State with a minimum income that will provide him with social security, a certain minimum needed to survive.  The minimum guaranteed income is therefore such a social and political concept to combat poverty, and de facto in various forms in most countries of the European Union such minimum social security is ensured. It is not universal – usually various social benefits, social housing, benefits require certain conditions. The system is often complicated, but it is, and the question arises whether it is therefore necessary to move towards a guaranteed income.  I see, of course, the positive, pragmatic features of this solution, the simplicity of this concept. However, this solution, which meets the demands of social justice and the European social pillar, has its drawbacks. Guaranteeing a minimum income for everyone regardless of employment status can be dissuasive and discourage whole groups from entering and remaining in the labour market. The question is who will pay for it. I therefore believe that minimum standards of employment and pay should be discussed first and that social policies relating to non-working citizens should be left to the Member States.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, with robotisation and digitisation, the labour market and work environment as we know it will change sooner than people realise, so we should explore the possibilities of a minimum European income as a matter of urgency. As a champion of social justice, I think that adopting a minimum income is an issue of fairness that would solve many issues, including child poverty, which is unacceptable in the 21st century.  In order to efficiently fight inequalities, poverty and social exclusion, we must take a rights—based approach, and minimum income is one of the key tools we could have at our disposal. It is also time that we had a collective discussion on the possibility of having a universal basic income. To consider income that is not linked to work is often perceived as undermining the value of work but I believe, on the contrary, that we must change our traditional mindset so as to realistically address the existing and future revolutions affecting the labour market. This would allow us to approach social and economic policies from the perspective that individuals are not only workers but also rights holders and active citizens.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: – Madam President. Revered colleagues. We must fight poverty. One thing it costs. I propose that we promise every european population, including millions of migrants, a minimum income of 100% of the average wage. 60% is definitely not enough for a dignified life. Let us guarantee this income, regardless of whether it works or not. Let's stop investigating whether someone is lazy, incompetent, hardworking. Let us guarantee everyone a minimum income of 100% of the average salary. In this way, we will abolish poverty directly in the Constitution. We will achieve social justice. And we're going to abolish social exclusivity. We're finally going to have real communism. We're going to learn from North Korea. China, Cambodia will envy us. So much of my contribution to this jal, pointless and utopian debate.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, I did not join mr Sulík's applause because I think he did not understand what the debate was supposed to be about. If we're reading the title of today's negotiating point, it's about minimum income. The minimum income, as presented here by Mrs Agea, is to be introduced in Italy as a form of social support. Many have said so here, too.  I am not going to talk about a guaranteed minimum income, that is, the flat dose that some of them may have also talked about. The European Union is based on the concept of a social market economy. This concept provides for social support as an expression of solidarity for those who cannot work or have lost their jobs. For those who are sick or care for a person close to them.  Social support must be derived from the cost of living and must be conditional on activity, because the aim is a decent life and it provides for work. That is why social policy must be in solidarity, but also motivational, of course, and I think the Commissioner has spoken very strongly about this here. What is decisive, of course, is the action of the Member States, which decide on the level of solidarity, on the level of social support, on the minimum wage, which should not have been discussed here today. Social support is really to be talked about. The European Union has only a complementary role and fulfils it in the form of the European Social Fund. It helps where unemployment is high, because only addressing unemployment allows for a truly dignified life for all.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: – We Social Democrats have repeatedly called on the Commission, the Member States, to set minimum income standards for the European Union, because it would certainly be a concrete instrument to combat poverty. Firstly, with female poverty, child poverty, elderly poverty, pensioner poverty, and certainly this would give those people in our European Union at least some opportunity to meet their minimum living needs. But isn't it too often we get the answer 'no, it's a matter for the Member States, it doesn't touch us'? But that's not the case. It is a matter for all of us, and it is a matter for our European Union's common family, and for our politicians, and our commissioners and the Member States, is a shared responsibility for the citizens of our European Union, for the citizens of our European Union. Let's look reality in the eye – how many people get the minimum wage? How many people receive low pensions? As families with children are struggling to survive. There is therefore a real need for a common European Union directive on minimum income and a European guarantee for the child.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Dear Madam President, honourable representatives of the Commission, with all due respect – let no one be affected, but the discussion of an unconditional basic income is a kind of communist utopia. It is completely unfeasible, unworkable and unreasonable. The far bigger problem of the European Union at the moment is the huge difference in living standards between the eastern and western parts of the European Union. That's what we should be fighting for, not talking about. And it is very strange and inexplicable when it is the Socialists, the left in this chamber, who support the theft of business, who support the violation of the free market, who support the introduction of restrictive measures in the field of road transport, which will steal business from hundreds of thousands of people in Eastern Europe, to demand an unconditional basic income. What we need to do in this chamber is not to let the idea of a common market be violated, which would allow the people of Eastern Europe to work in the common market and live normally and with dignity. Not to talk to each other, not to talk about nonexistent and impossible things.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: – Madam President, minimum income was a floor below which income should not fall and it can vary for different countries. It could be a wage supplemented by state support; state—provided targeted benefits, such as those for persons with disabilities; unemployment support in housing, or indeed schooling and education; or it could be for carers. Child poverty is one of the real targets in this area to address to ensure that we bring all children out of that. In my own country, it is still the case that child poverty levels are quite high, and they are not keeping pace with the growth in the economy and growth in employment. Nevertheless, the way to address child poverty is to help parents, through employment and through support that can ensure adequate living standards. Today, we had a report published in my country on the minimum wage. Whilst I know that’s not a solution to everything, the study said today that of those on minimum wages one-in-three would move on to a higher wage in a matter of nine months. It acts as a stepping stone to jobs with better pay. However, those on minimum wage are most likely to lose their jobs; they are more likely to have poor education, be part-time employees and be on temporary contracts. That all ties in with the Commission’s pillar of social rights and, indeed, transparent and predictable working conditions, which I fully support. I hope we see progress through this Parliament. So, income guarantee is not a guaranteed minimum income, but it’s certainly at a level below which we should recognise income should not fall, particularly for those with families.

name: Michael DETJEN
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Work is a meaningful element in life. Renaming unemployment benefits or social assistance into basic security makes little sense. A fair wage must be a goal for European politics. Wage policy is a key element in the approximation of living conditions in Europe. The negotiation of wages is the task of employers and trade unions. Where there are no strong trade unions and employers' associations, the state must ensure a fair minimum wage and protect collective agreements and freedom of contract. High wage differentials in Europe are a fissure for society. That is why we need a European minimum wage based on living standards and the middle incomes of the European regions. Germany is not a role model here either. With the German minimum wage of EUR 8.84, the worker receives only about 47% of the median income. In A European comparison, the German minimum wage ranks 14th in terms of median income. The minimum wage poverty threshold is 60% of the median income. The low minimum wage contributes to old-age poverty and child poverty. We must continue to fight in Germany to ensure that we have a minimum minimum wage of eur 12. We want all people in Europe to be able to make a good living from their work.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Madam Chairman, a guaranteed minimum income would solve as many problems as it would create new ones.  Politicians would find it harder for social transfers to buy votes if everyone received the same amount from the state. Bureaucracy would be smaller and, more importantly, less influential. Workers would have a better bargaining position towards employers and some material security that would allow them to look for a job where they are happiest and most productive, but not necessarily the best paid. Poverty would be less, as would disgruntled workers, and people would devote more attention to family.  On the other hand, a guaranteed minimum income represents an unbearable financial burden for the state. It would negatively affect work habits, and in countries that are tormented by black labour, it would also create a labour shortage, which in these demographic circumstances would be disastrous for the economy and public services financed by labour taxes.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab For several years now, we have been discussing the minimum income that all citizens would be entitled to, whether they are working or outside the labour market. The importance of this idea is evidenced by the fact that it is also talked about by the heads of companies such as Tesla and Google. One of the arguments in favour of this solution boils down to the belief that robotics and automation of the economy will lead to a situation where there will be no jobs for everyone. While the idea seems lofty and motivated by concern for citizens, the experience so far with a guaranteed minimum income is not optimistic. In Finland, an experiment was conducted in recent years on a group of unemployed people living in selected areas of the country. The project unexpectedly ended this year. Although there are no official results yet, the first information indicates that it was a failure. First of all, it has not translated into an increase in the labour force of the unemployed. It is unfortunate, because it thus confirmed the argument that a guaranteed minimum income would lead to a permanent withdrawal from the labour market rather than an increase in proactive attitudes. We have had similar experiences in France and Switzerland.  I therefore recommend that you be careful and careful when discussing this issue. A minimum guaranteed income will not eliminate corruption, precariat, illegal employment or poverty-contributing unemployment. We should focus our energy on measures that activate and include the unemployed, measures to ensure decent working conditions for everyone, actions that support women in particular, so that they can successfully reconcile family responsibilities with work. It seems to me that such an idea would be better if it was addressed to pensioners who have worked all their lives.

name: Sergio Gaetano COFFERATI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, for many years Now I have been convinced of the usefulness, of the need for a universal instrument for the protection of people when they do not have a job or lose a job and are therefore exposed to dangers, risks to them and their very large families. That is why we need a guaranteed minimum income. We need a European directive which generalizes the experiences that exist today in some countries of Europe and makes them workable. We proposed it in 2010 and this Parliament opposed it, albeit by a few dozen votes. This instrument must be proposed again and this instrument must be universal, because in times of need there can be no difference between those who have an instrument that protects it and those who have nothing, and resources must be sought primarily in these different and not always effective instruments, which also exist in the labour market. Finally, it is clear that the guaranteed minimum income must be placed in a general framework, where there is a welfare policy that protects people, otherwise it becomes only compensation, and where there is an active labour policy. Income is not an alternative to work, it must accompany the transition from one activity to another and cover the moment of need.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab  Last week, walking down the street in Brussels, I met a young man who was raising money. He begged. But he had a piece of paper telling him what he was raising that money for. He was collecting beer. A few days later in Krakow, walking down the street, I met a young man who played the violin beautifully. He was raising money. He also had a piece of paper on which it was written that he was raising money for a conservatory, for higher education, for learning. One case and the other, one might say, similar. One was raising money. He wanted someone to give him a donation and the other wanted a donation. Only one offered nothing in exchange for this donation. He just lay down and waited for money to drink alcohol. The second offered a beautiful game for this donation, and also collected for a noble purpose – to be educated, to develop, so that then he can give us all something wonderful, beautiful, his artistic skills. I ask myself, should one and the other be able to throw money into the can? In my opinion, no. The aid must not be blind. The aid must be addressed by name, then it will be a real help. The aid must also be fair and fair to the beneficiaries, and therefore to those who need it. I think equally they shouldn't get and those who lie on the sidewalk and want a beer, for alcohol, for wine, and those who want to be educated, want to grow, want to have children and then work on the development of their children. But it must also be fair to those who give this money, and therefore to those who work.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I must admit that I am a little surprised by this debate, because we are talking here – some people are talking – about the market, about the minimum wage and about fairness. We are simply talking about human dignity at this point, and that is the subject of our debate. Human dignity, that is, those who, for various reasons of chance, life, misfortunes, disability, are unable to obtain income from work, and we want to tell them whether to stay under this proverbial bridge, whether expenditures such as food, housing, clothing can be financed from this minimum income, which it seems can provide a minimum of dignity.  I understand that this is our common task. The European level is the rules, the rules, and the national level, the national level, is the amount – because the value of one euro in Luxembourg is different, and another in Bulgaria – and the recipients. I think we can solve this problem together.

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: – Mr President, the strength of society is measured by its ability to care for the weakest. Integrity, equality and avoiding the living standards gap also ensure a safer and more competitive society. In Europe, however, 120 million people are at risk of falling into poverty. Children, the unemployed, single parents and the disabled are in the greatest need. The child guarantee advocated by my group would be a step towards everyone's Europe, and I hope that this initiative will be supported in the negotiations on the financial framework. Those at risk should be supported in matters related to housing, health care and education – poverty is hereitable, whether we like it or not. In this way, young people would be best placed to take care of themselves and their future family.  Different European models do not prevent the need to demand a livelihood to survive. The current system has been well able to take into account different countries, the Nordic model and the minimum wage countries. It should be remembered, however, that a sustainable system requires the maintenance of the state's finances. An economic collapse or a banking crisis has not helped any poor people.  In Finland, we have had a basic security experiment that does not inspire anyone very much: EUR 560 for 2000 people, but we need a system that prevents falling into holes between different social security systems.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, poverty exists, poverty exists because the poor exist, but who are the poor and why they are. They have different faces and stories of deprivation and ask different questions about the present and the future. Complicated questions, which we cannot answer with the rhetoric of poverty and propaganda, capable only of finding the simplest, the least laborious solutions, useful only to increase the percentages of electoral consensus.  The shortcut to monetizing need cannot be the only way forward. In a context in which there is a high risk that a new multitude of poor people will be added to the one that is already knocking on our doorstep today, it is necessary for politics to be responsible and to be sober. Europe has already indicated its horizon, the social pillar and the programming of the European Social Fund as an opportunity to define strategies and resources to promote instruments to combat poverty. The minimum income, the citizenship income is certainly useful in the emergency, but we need policies oriented towards growth and development for the future, but this step is not included in the agenda of the Italian Government, the declension is therefore up to each Member State. Those who up for the principle of popular sovereignty do not believe that they are able to make the right choices wisely, seriously and balancedly. The choices, daughters of that populism that we are learning about, will condemn the poor to remain poor and drag thousands of new poor people below the poverty line, and it will not be Europe's fault.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, today’s debate has proven how important it is to ensure that the social dimension is well integrated in all EU policy areas and why the European Pillar of social rights is so relevant. The principles enshrined in the Pillar underline the importance to invest in people and to support them through changes stemming from new and emerging challenges. As President Juncker said, Europe’s social dimension should be given the Cinderella treatment no more but should instead be geared towards the future.  Poverty and inequality are not only detrimental to social cohesion, but also to sustainable economic growth. This is why we believe that fit—for—purpose social protection systems can contribute both to the smooth functioning of the labour market and to inclusive growth. This includes, indeed, that minimum income provision has to be accompanied by activation measures and enabling services. An adequate income will always be important for maintaining human dignity and full participation in society and economy. It is important, however, to note that minimum income provisions are only one element in the whole policy mix that is needed to guarantee a decent life for the most vulnerable people in society.  Now on Italy. Italy was one of the few countries not to have a minimum income provision for a long time. We recommended its introduction in country—specific recommendations for many years, and finally the previous government introduced it in 2017. We understand that the current government would like to modify the measure, including by extending its coverage. We will judge it, within the framework of the European Semester and the analysis of the draft budgetary plan, according to the well—established procedures you all know.  Last but not least, Madam President, about the requests for new legislation, for instance on a minimum income directive or the other suggestions made during the debate, I can tell you that right now our focus is on the important legislative initiatives already proposed to implement the Social Pillar. Our goal is to see this completed within this mandate of the current Parliament. In parallel, there are important initiatives underway to ensuring upwards convergence in these areas, and here I am referring in particular to the recently agreed framework for minimum income benchmarking which includes indicators for defining adequacy of benefits. This will for sure be of great help to developing adequate minimum income schemes in all our Member States.  Thank you very much for this debate.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I want to thank you for the vibrant but incoherent discussion we are having now. We have to combat poverty, we have to leave no one behind, but I think next time it would be helpful to clarify in advance what we are talking about. In my opening speech I was talking about minimum income as a social system to bridge difficult times.  Nevertheless, thank you once again for inviting me here and allowing me to could contribute to this fruitful and lively discussion. I think though that next time we should decide on whether we are talking about minimum income or minimum wages.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. – The Socialists reiterate our demand to the Commission and the EU Governments for the implementation of a Directive regulating and forcing Member States to develop minimum income systems. It is a moral and legal obligation in Europe to assist people at risk of poverty and an imperative to implement point 14 of the social pillar contained in this proposal. We call for a new safety net that protects Europeans from adversity and applies in a situation of loss of unemployment or all financial aid. The development of a homogeneous income system across the EU is essential as a measure of social justice and also of economic efficiency. Moreover, it would be able to stop the disengagement of the city from democratic systems because we would prevent citizens from falling into poverty through public authorities. Minimum income must be linked to the will to enter the labour market, it must be applicable from the time you enter the limits of poverty and until a job is found.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. – The Socialists reiterate our demand to the Commission and the Member States for the implementation of a Directive regulating and forcing them to develop minimum income systems. It is a moral and legal obligation in Europe to assist people at risk of poverty and an imperative to implement point 14 of the social pillar contained in this proposal. We call for a new safety net that protects Europeans from adversity and applies in a situation of loss of unemployment or all financial aid. The development of a homogeneous system across the EU is essential as it is a measure of social justice and also of economic efficiency. Moreover, it would be able to stop the disengagement of the city from democratic systems because we would prevent citizens from falling into poverty. Minimum income must be linked to the will to enter the labour market, it must be applicable from the time you enter the limits of poverty until employment is found. Minimum income policies must also be combined with universal and quality social protection systems. This combination must be at the heart of European policies.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. – The Socialists reiterate our demand to the Commission and the EU Governments for the implementation of a Directive regulating and forcing Member States to develop minimum income systems. It is a moral and legal obligation in Europe to assist people at risk of poverty and an imperative to implement point 14 of the social pillar contained in this proposal. We call for a new safety net that protects Europeans from adversity and applies in a situation of loss of unemployment or all financial aid. The development of a homogeneous income system across the EU is essential as a measure of social justice and also of economic efficiency. Minimum income must be linked to the will to enter the labour market, it must be applicable from the time you enter the limits of poverty and until a job is found. Minimum income policies must also be combined with universal and quality social protection systems. This combination of social protection and adequate income guarantee must be at the heart of European policies.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. – Private consumption has grown. Exports and investment have increased. Unemployment continues to fall and it has gotten closer to pre—crisis levels. Profits of corporations have increased. Public deficit and debt levels have been largely brought under control. Not so the share of the economic cake being enjoyed by the working and middle classes; there the deficit has continued to grow. In most cases where a national minimum wage exists in Europe, it still falls short of what a living wage should be. Meanwhile, the divergences between the highest income earners and the lowest have continued to increase. This is not fair. At best, Minimum Income schemes play the role of safety nets for the most vulnerable workers and for individuals unable to guarantee an adequate standard of living through their own efforts. They are hardly doing so. The time has come, however, for such schemes to go beyond this minimum. We need to push for the adoption EU—wide of a national minimum wage adapted to the conditions of each Member State. And we need to propose that where this national minimum wage exists, all over the EU, in the current favourable economic context, the minimum wage levels are increased across the board by at least 5 per cent.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on Axel Voss' report, on behalf of the Civil Liberties Committee, Justice and Home Affairs, on the proposed regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on the European Union Agency for Judicial Cooperation in Criminal Affairs (Eurojust) (COM(2013)0535 - C7-240/2013 - 2013/0256 (COD)) (A8-0320/2017).

name: Axel VOSS
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her Mr President- -- I would like to begin by thanking the president-in-office of the Council for his excellent work on Since the founding of Eurojust on 6 May, Eurojust has been  On 1 March 2002, we are supporting Eurojust and the Member States in the judicial coordination of their national authorities. The aim is clear: to combat terrorism and serious organised crime more effectively within the European Union. The first half of 2018 alone underlined the positive impact of Eurojust. In April, a ring of people smugglers was unearthed by arrests in Austria and Romania, in May the cooperation between Belgium, Spain and Germany led to arrests in cases of organised systematic VAT fraud, and in June a german-Danish group was finally convicted of selling residence permits to migrants as part of sham marriages. However, due to this new threat situation, but also to technical progress and institutional changes since 2002, the regulations from the founding act were no longer adequate and should and should be renewed. The Commission therefore published a draft regulation in July 2013. We in the European Parliament have, of course, placed this draft in the ordinary legislative procedure, and we have only been able to assess it in its entirety. And that, in turn, was a little lengthy, because we had, of course, to wait for the draft report on the European Public Prosecutor's Office until the Council debate, so that we could not actually present the draft in Parliament until 2017 and then in October we also got parliament's mandate to enter the trialogue negotiations. I would like to commend the cooperation with the Estonian and Bulgarian Presidencies, but also with the Commission and with the shadow rapporteurs. All the actors here were very committed, very professional, which is why the trialogue on the 19th.  June of this year was successfully completed – with a satisfactory result for all sides, I would say. We have therefore also created an Executive Board to relieve the College of Discharge, which will take on administrative tasks. The college will then focus on purely operational business. We have established clear responsibilities and procedural procedures, and the Commission is also involved in the work of this agency through a representative in the college and executive board, as well as Parliament at the hearing of the President of Eurojust or the national parliaments at interparliamentary meetings. The tasks and responsibilities of Eurojust are clearly regulated in relation to the European Public Prosecutor's Office (EEA), thus avoiding gaps and overlaps. In addition, the principle of proportionality and the principle of subsidiarity are also taken into account. It also ensures that prosecutions must continue at national level. A bigger problem was the creation of the data protection directives. We have now integrated the so-called operational data into the founding act of Eurojust, while all other data protection issues in Regulation 45 (EC) No 2001 have been included by Mrs Ernst. This means that Member States can also be sure that their data will not be shared with Eurojust without their consent.

name: Axel VOSS
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, Eurojust makes an essential contribution to judicial cooperation in the European Union. It helps Member States to combat serious cross-border crime and to protect our citizens. In recent years, Eurojust has further increased its role in the fight against cybercrime, terrorism and trafficking in human beings. Last year alone, Eurojust supported Member States in more than 2 500 criminal cases and organised 200 joint investigative teams. Eurojust also supports the execution of European arrest warrants as well as judicial cooperation with third countries. Given this changing and ever more challenging operational environment, the reform of Eurojust was necessary. We had to make sure Eurojust stays fit for purpose in the future. The revision you are about to adopt will, among other things, ensure that the national members of Eurojust can focus more on operational work. It will also allow the European Parliament and national parliaments to be more involved in assessing Eurojust activities. We also needed to clarify Eurojust’s future relationship with the European Public Prosecutor’s Office, the so-called EPPO. The EPPO will be a specialised body with investigatory powers dedicated to the fight against crimes against the EU’s financial interests. It will need to cooperate closely with Eurojust. Moreover, Eurojust will continue to be responsible for judicial cooperation in relation to crimes against EU financial interests in respect of those Member States that do not yet participate in the EPPO. The EPPO will be operational by the end of 2020 and I am pleased that it will have a stronger Eurojust as its partner. In this context, let me also highlight the importance of sufficient resources for Eurojust to do its important work in the forthcoming financial period. In the meantime, I would like to thank the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs for the excellent cooperation on this proposal. I would like to highlight three points on which Parliament’s support was decisive in the negotiations. First, Parliament obtained agreement that the regulation on access to documents should be applicable to all Eurojust documents, including those related to operational matters. This will ensure more transparency for citizens. Secondly, Parliament ensured that the harmonised data protection laws for EU institutions and bodies would also apply to Eurojust. Thirdly, Parliament allowed the Commission to have a representative on the management board of Eurojust. I am convinced that, with this revision, Eurojust will be even more efficient in making the EU a safer place. The Commission regrets, however, that on several points the co-legislators have decided to deviate from the approach agreed in the joint statement on decentralised agencies. A written statement on this issue has been provided for inclusion in the record of this session. Honourable Members, thank you once again for your work. I look forward to the vote tomorrow.  Commission statement (in writing) "The Commission regrets that on several points, the co-legislators have decided to deviate from the approach agreed in the Joint Statement of the European Parliament, the Council of the EU and the European Commission on decentralised agencies of 19 July 2012, without providing the necessary justification. This relates in particular to the number of Commission representatives in the College/Management Board and the procedure for appointing and dismissing the Administrative Director of Eurojust. The Commission will assess the impact of those deviations on the functioning of the Agency at the appropriate opportunity. They should not be considered as a precedent for other agencies."

name: Ingeborg GRÄSSLE
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Budgetary Control. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I would like to start by congratulating the rapporteur on the work that has been done. It is important that we get a result at all. On the other hand, the current regulation naturally opens up the beauty contest at the level of 'who does what' between OLAF, EPPO and Eurojust. That is why I very much regret some of the results. For example, I find it completely incomprehensible why the EPPO's access to Eurojust's case management system has been deleted in Article 23 and why only indirect access is provided for. The automatic cross-checking mechanism has also been deleted. I think we will still be sorry for that here in this House. I would also like to take a negative view of OLAF being taken into account in Article 51(2). We will see how the provision affects practice. We are glad that the budget discharge for Eurojust is also reflected in the final text. And I would like to say to you that we will, of course, accompany the work of Eurojust and the question of efficiency and will certainly be happy to come back to one or the other. The bottom line is that it is good that we have it, but it is a pity that we have incomplete work and work that is not as efficient as it should be in order to help the European level achieve the breakthrough that the citizens expect of us.

name: António MARINHO E PINTO
text: rapporteur of the opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs. – Madam President, Commissioner, it is necessary to prevent Eurojust from becoming another nest of bureaucrats in the European Union, or another golden shelf to reward, with luxury reforms, certain magistrates who are obsessed with the political power of their countries. That is why political courage is urgently necessary to reform justice in the Union, starting with transforming Eurojust into the embryo of a genuine European Union Public Prosecutor's Office, with exclusive competence to investigate a catalogue of crimes which must also be quickly defined. Commissioner, justice is not the same in all member states of the European Union. It's a bit like human cholesterol: there is a good justice that respects, values and prestigious the rule of law, but there is another justice that does just the opposite.  It is therefore urgent to carry out a reform of judicial institutions which levels the standards of administration of justice. This reform will also be a way to overcome the impasse in the process of European integration and will be a decisive step in that integration.

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: PPE Group. – Madam President... congratulations, Axel!  Eurojust is essential to respond effectively to the challenge of cross-border organised crime, terrorism, migrant smuggling or cybercrime. Thanks to this reform, Eurojust will gain efficiency and strengthen cooperation between Member States on criminal justice.  Eurojust has facilitated coordination and cooperation between national tax and investigative authorities in managing cases affecting several Member States. It has also helped build mutual trust and connect the full range of existing legal instruments in the European Union.  Eurojust's adaptation to the creation of the new Public Prosecutor's Office, as well as to the new data protection regulations for institutions should be full. The SOCTA 2017 organized crime report identified five thousand organised crime groups acting and under investigation in the European Union, an increase of one thousand and four hundred more groups compared to 2013.  This indicates that a coordinated response must be improved and given to the Union, both at the police and judicial level, in order to deal with the terrorist threat, drug trafficking, cybercrime, migrant trafficking or child pornography.  Eurojust is a fundamental tool for cooperation and enhanced coordination between the judicial authorities of the Member States, the new Public Prosecutor's Office and also with other agencies, such as Europol, as well as with third countries. It is important that working agreements are made between Europol and Eurojust so that both agencies can share information and data, especially now that we will enter the interoperability stage and the European search portal.  Finally, Eurojust must remain a fundamental agency in the fight against all forms of organized crime and crime.

name: Sylvia-Yvonne KAUFMANN
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, Commissioner Jourova, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Cross-border crime cannot only be combated nationally. No, we must address it with cross-border cooperation between the Member States and their judicial authorities. Since we do not really have European criminal law, we need a bridge between the authorities of the Member States in order to be able to successfully put offenders on trial. This bridge is Eurojust. The Agency started its work in 2002 and the increasing number of cases involving national authorities in Eurojust is a testament to the need and importance of the European Agency for Judicial Cooperation. The range of cases in which Eurojust provides assistance is diverse – be it the detection of fraud against bank customers with fake e-mails in Romania and Italy, whether it is the detection of raids on freight transporters in France and Poland or, for example, the detection of drug smuggling between the Netherlands and Finland, to name but a few examples from recent months. All these cases have one thing in common: cross-border crime has been combated with cross-border cooperation. In order for Eurojust to be able to carry out its tasks even more efficiently in the future, it is good that, with our vote tomorrow, we are launched the new Eurojust regulation in accordance with the Lisbon Treaty. What are the main innovations at stake? Firstly, the structure of Eurojust is being modernised, and this now allows the national members of Eurojust to focus more on operational tasks. An executive committee will take the lead in the administrative work. Secondly, as you know, from 2020, the European Public Prosecutor's Office will be able to investigate and prosecute crimes against the EU budget. Here it was important to avoid any form of skills gaps or even duplication of work. In order for the Public Prosecutor's Office to cooperate effectively with Eurojust, the guidelines for the division of powers are clearly defined. Thirdly, there is, of course, much to be done to improve judicial cooperation between the Member States. In order to support this process, Eurojust will be able to draw up written opinions in the future to alert the authorities of a Member State to existing problems. Fourthly, we are strengthening transparency and accountability. Parliamentary control of Eurojust is strengthened by the cooperation of the relevant committees of the European Parliament and also of the national parliaments. Fifthly, as the rapporteur has pointed out, data protection will be adapted to the new rules at European level, and this is extremely important for sensitive data relating to law enforcement. All in all, this reform will make Eurojust more capable of action, and Eurojust will have the opportunity to work more efficiently in the future. I would like to thank everyone, especially Mr Voss, for their good cooperation.

name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, to discuss Eurojust today this evening is to talk about this actor who has become central and indispensable in judicial cooperation and who is directly involved in strengthening our area of freedom, security and justice. With this reform, we are making a definite step towards a genuine European agency for judicial cooperation, a modernised agency, thanks to this revision, to be more effective in combating these multiple and different types of cross-border crime. Discussions on the reform of Eurojust have long been dependent on, and then linked to, the agreement on the creation of the European Public Prosecutor's Office, a creation which is a real step forward for our Union. Therefore, it is, of course, following closely the developments relating to the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office that we have been working on. As rapporteur for my group, ALDE, we have put particular emphasis on the relationship between Eurojust and the Public Prosecutor's Office, because this future cooperation is essential for strengthening rights. The final agreement on our text clarifies and improves links with the Public Prosecutor's Office in the administrative, institutional and above all operational framework. This is all the more important since many of us called for the strengthening of the role of the European Public Prosecutor's Office by extending its competence to cross-border crime and terrorism, which was echoed by President Juncker in his State of the Union address a few weeks ago. With regard to the reform of Eurojust in particular, I would like to commend the fluid work of our fellow rapporteur, Axel Voss, who was patient during the negotiations, particularly on the issue of the data protection regime. I sincerely believe that we have achieved a good balance that respects data protection. My group will obviously support this agreement.

name: Eva JOLY
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, crime knows no borders, especially financial crime, which uses them to defraud VAT, to evade taxes and to launder dirty money. That is why the work of our justice cannot stop at national borders. We need the Eurojust agency and the European Public Prosecutor's Office.  Judicial cooperation within the European Union is essential to better combat crime and terrorism. Eurojust facilitates the exchange of information and contributes to the strengthening of a European legal culture.  I therefore welcome the adoption of the new regulatory framework for Eurojust, which in particular clarifies the relationship between this agency and the new public prosecutor's office. These two bodies will need to work together to effectively combat cross-border crime. Their effectiveness will also depend on the human and financial resources allocated to them.  Let us ensure that impunity is no longer an option. Let us give ourselves the means to have a European justice worthy of the name.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, this is the first reading of legislation that seeks to update and enhance the powers of Eurojust. Eurojust has a presence in every Member State, with an unprecedented concentration of judicial and police powers and with no separation of powers between judges, prosecutors and police. It has enormous power and enormous potential for the abuse of power. Eurojust is just one element of the EU’s own evolving system of criminal law, which is superseding the legal systems of Member States.  This legislation will enhance its powers to incorporate cooperation with the European Public Prosecutor’s Office. It will permit Eurojust to exercise its powers not only at the request of the so—called ‘competent authorities’, but on its own initiative and at the request of the Prosecutor’s Office. This legislation is a step on the way to absorbing Eurojust into the European Public Prosecutor’s office. The UK is a participant in Eurojust but has supposedly opted out of the jurisdiction of the Prosecutor’s Office. However, this opt—out is illusory. The European Public Prosecutor can easily circumvent that opt—out in the UK by using the other legal institutions and instruments to achieve its objectives. The evolving EU system of criminal law may not be alien to some Member States, but it is completely alien to the English legal system. Our freedoms and liberties under our constitution, the common law and statute law, have evolved over centuries. They are being swept away by measures such as these.  It has not been possible to ascertain Her Majesty’s Government’s position on this legislation, but UKIP has proposed a rejection amendment, and we urge every UK MEP to vote for it if they have any desire to protect the freedoms and liberties of British citizens.

name: Diane JAMES
text: – Madam President, well this siren call that I hear so often here in this Chamber of ‘more Europe’ couldn’t be better exemplified by what we have before us in terms of the evolution of Eurojust.  The European Union federal state, mission creep, removes nation control of legal matters – we’ve heard about the European Public Prosecutor, data exchange, etc. – and that is a key pillar and foundation of nation sovereignty. Therefore, when it comes to the vote tomorrow I will be absolutely astounded if any MEP here in this Chamber feels they have have been given a mandate to sacrifice their national judicial control, in the manner that this report sets out, away to the European Union.  I only hope that everyone who opposes Brexit in the United Kingdom will watch this debate to see what European Union judicial control means.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, first let me smile a little at the speeches of my British colleagues, who are calling for the sovereign right of Member States to decide on criminal matters, and then, on the other hand, to see the United Kingdom, which makes the most use of Eurojust and most calls for cooperation, because, of course, it needs to coordinate the fight against crime or, in the case of terrorism, the most.  But sometimes that's the case. It is simply that someone has to go through Brexit so that they realise where and in what family they have been, and I personally see the role of Eurojust above all at the level of coordination and there I think it needs to be strengthened. I think you rightly said in your introductory speech that it is important to divide the competences between the public prosecutor and Eurojust so that those competences do not overlap, that the authorities are effective and that they can work better together.  I think that is also the point of this report, and that is the point of our actions, which we have been trying to promote here for four years or more. I think that Eurojust is of great importance in the area of cooperation and, of course, unlike my colleagues, I know that it will not interfere in any way with the national sovereignty of individual Member States. I think that, in addition to what you have said here, it is also important to say that Eurojust has proven itself and that it is necessary to constantly praise this agency, which is one of the shop windows of the European Union, and to constantly show the results of its excellent work.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Madam President, Commissioner Jourová, since the emergence of Eurojust in 2002, it was clear that this agency was called to be one of the great promises of the area of freedom, security and justice that decisively confided the Lisbon Treaty in 2009. It was therefore time for us to have a new Regulation, which the Commission pushed for in 2013 to strengthen its operational effectiveness, its governance model, but also the incardination of Eurojust's national members. But the goal is what you can't lose sight of. The aim is to strengthen mutual trust, mutual recognition of judgments in the pursuit of serious and, particularly transnational, criminality. And in order to keep mutual trust alive, it is very important that there be mutual respect between the judiciary of the Member States. That they should not examine each other as to the quality of their resolutions but, exactly, that they rely, unless very exceptional reasons, to ensure the objective of the fight against serious crime which is kept by Article 83. Child pornography, cybercriminality, drugs. The target can't be out of sight. But I would also add that the great importance of Eurojust having this new regulation which relaunches it as a true judicial cooperation agency in criminal matters of the European Union is highlighted by the fact that even the Member States which have decided to opt out of the instrument, such as the United Kingdom and Denmark, are committed to signing cooperation agreements , because the objective can no longer be achieved by any Member State, has to be achieved by showing political will at European level.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Freedom of movement is one of the pillars of the European Union, but unfortunately it is not only job seekers, students and businesses who benefit from it. According to Europol, there are thousands of crime syndicates operating in the EU, with drug trafficking, trafficking in human beings, child sex trafficking, money laundering, fraud, cybercrime. This makes it an obligation for the EU and all Member States to do more for law enforcement and prosecution, and hence the safety and security of citizens. A Eurobarometer last year shows that 92% of european citizens want us to work strategically to combat serious cross-border crime. In other words, citizens across our Member States expect us to deliver answers to the challenges we face. The problem is that cooperation between Member States in sharing and interpreting information does not work very well – partly because different systems are used. The Eurojust legislation on which we are now voting is therefore a very, very important step in the right direction.  Another important step forward we have achieved is the European Public Prosecutor's Office. In this context, I regret that Member States, including Poland, Hungary and Sweden, have chosen to remain outside this cooperation against crime and corruption. We can still join, and that would be important. What we are voting on tomorrow, however, is a major step forward in improving and improving the efficiency of law enforcement, so let us look positively at the possibility that freedom of movement will also work in the area of law enforcement and prosecution.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the updating of the Eurojust Agency regulation modernises its organisational structure, which is now essential in order to cope with the worrying evolution of cross-border organised crime, but it is also functional to the new institutional framework that is emerging with the imminent establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office, which is responsible for crimes against the financial interests of the Union. I would say that the heart of the reform is precisely the provisions necessary to regulate relations between Eurojust and the new European Public Prosecutor' s Office. The competences of each institution must be clearly defined, in order to ensure legal certainty, to avoid possible gaps in the application of criminal law and duplication of procedures. I firmly believe that the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office will not disre end with Eurojust but, on the contrary, precisely because the European Public Prosecutor's Office is based on the principle of enhanced cooperation, the Eurojust agency will play a leading role both in coordination with member states that have not yet acceded and in all those crimes that are not provided for in the PIF Directive, and I am thinking of terrorism. , drug trafficking, cybercrime or child pornography, all of which are cross-border offences. I also welcome the fact that the modernisation of Eurojust, which we are about to vote on, strengthens data protection protection, as well as accentuates the separation of administrative and operational activities, and that it fully focuses on judicial cooperation and coordination between competent authorities in the Member States.  I would like to thank Mr Voss and my fellow shadow rapporteurs for their work.

name: Iris HOFFMANN
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The cross-border networking of law enforcement authorities within the European Union is important. Eurojust builds mutual trust, where there are traditionally differences, and builds bridges between the legal systems of the European Union. With the creation of the European Public Prosecutor's Office, it has become necessary to draw a clear and clear distinction. It is a pity that not all Member States have been able to get their way together, because that does not make it any easier for us to crack down on crime within the EU. With the reform, Eurojust is now to focus on its essential tasks, which are to promote cooperation between national judicial authorities in the fight against cross-border crime. I think the clear separation of operational and administrative tasks makes perfect sense here. I think it is important that Eurojust continues to support and coordinate those Member States that do not want to participate in the European Public Prosecutor's Office.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the reform of Eurojust was necessary. If we think about the statistical data and the results we have on the fight against organised crime and the annihilation of criminal organisations, I believe that it remains a challenge and I believe that by reforming and voting on the new regulation on the organisation of Eurojust, the Commission will have a much better working instrument and I believe that the Member States should all come together.  I am surprised that we have colleagues here who say that there should not be such a regulation. I cannot imagine how it is possible, cross-border, for a single state to be able to solve criminal networks, and we know well that - I, as a member of LIBE, but also of IMCO - know well that these networks affect very much the internal market, fair competition and many things and ultimately the lives of citizens. I don't think it's normal for our colleague to ask for a warrant, because I don't think any citizen or company is happy that these organised crime networks exist.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab It's probably about me. Mr. Zdechovský has just spoken. He spoke in the debate. Yes, thank you very much. In my work in the Committee on Terrorism, I have repeatedly encountered the fundamental problem of cooperation between services and, in particular, between states. It can be said that this is the most sensitive, not to say insufficient, piece of cooperation related to the fight against terrorism in Europe. Looking at the increase in cases over a period of 15 years, more than tenfold, it is undoubtedly – and I would certainly stress – that this debate is needed and the document itself prepared for the reform of this fundamental institution is essential. That's how I would define it. I wanted to thank the initiators and also to say that Not only do I support those activities that are reforming the institutions, but I regret that my country, my country, Poland, did not sign up to the European Public Prosecutor's Office. I believe that, together with Hungary and the Swedes, we should change this view.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, cross-border organised crime has increased exponentially in recent years as a result of terrorism, drug trafficking, cybercrime and child pornography. These forms of crime are carried out in crimes committed by extremely mobile and flexible groups operating in multiple EU jurisdictions and criminal sectors. It is clear that law enforcement cannot be carried out effectively without appropriate instruments at international level. The operational network for the exchange of information between law enforcement agencies must be implemented under the leadership of Europol in order to overcome the current difficulties. I say this also in the light of the transnational investigations following the attacks in Paris and Brussels, which revealed serious shortcomings in the ability to cooperate between the various national law enforcement authorities. Judicial and police administrative cooperation throughout the European Union must be enhanced at several levels, aiming at effective synergy between the European Judicial Network Europol and Eurojust. All this while waiting to see what role the newly established European Public Prosecutor's Office will play.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Madam President, the many and varied activities of organised crime, combined with the action of terrorists, cross-border fraud and cyber attacks, require the cooperation of the judicial authorities of each country with the European Union Agency in the field of criminal justice, the well-known Eurojust, in order to deal with all these cases.  But Eurojust must operate in a way that does not violate the sovereignty of the states. It is therefore necessary to define its mission and to define the limits of its activities. Another issue that is particularly sensitive is that human rights must not be violated in the context of the fight against organised crime. Finally, it goes without saying that the operation of Eurojust must not succumb to political purposes.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Madam President, criminal organisations are currently active in Europe, which pose a serious risk to the societies of the Member States. In fact, over the last decade, it has been observed that these organisations are not confined to one state, but by exploiting the free movement of persons, they are developing europe-wide. At the same time, there is also increasing cooperation between criminal groups in the various states. Terrorist networks, smuggling networks, trafficking in human beings and economic crime are making the most of the delay shown by the national authorities.  Unfortunately, however, instead of the Commission presenting a comprehensive proposal to create a body that effectively coordinates the law enforcement authorities of the Member States, it is more concerned with the creation of a European So-called Public Prosecutor's Office with limited possibilities, with powers that conflict with those of Eurojust and at the same time with certain judicial powers. Moreover, by showing unprecedented indifference to the principle of separation of powers , the Commission is essentially seeking to monitor the appointment of the Presidents and Vice-Presidents of Eurojust . In the end, the Commission is probably more interested in creating new appointment posts and absorbing funds.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, thank you very much for your valuable contributions in this debate. I would like to respond on several of the comments made. It is true that criminals have no borders. Also, criminal creativity has no limits, and criminals are using and abusing several new factors. Firstly, they abuse the loopholes which we leave in the system. They are abusing new technological tools and possibilities because – while a number of speakers mentioned the Schengen area, which enables free movement – the digital sphere, in fact, has no borders, and we have the statistics from the national police and prosecutors’ offices which show that criminality is shifting to the digital sphere and cybercrime is on the rise. Sadly, another aspect widely abused by international organised criminal networks is the fact that national police and prosecutors have limited powers in relation to cases with cross-border scope. These are the cases which we need to address. We need to reorganise powers and redistribute tasks and competences among the institutions which the EU has established, in order to prosecute these big cross-border cases. In relation to Europol, and now the reform of Eurojust and the new EPPO, of course I have to mention OLAF, which also needs reconstruction – and all these institutions will need to work without overlap. There must be very strong synergies and it is our duty to fine-tune the tasks and competences of these institutions to work as one in a well-orchestrated way, because if we fail to do that the criminals will be celebrating.

name: Axel VOSS
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her First of all, here also in detail the individual contributions, especially the contributions that I have just heard from this page. I have the feeling that the system and the Eurojust platform have not been understood at all. Britain has not sunk yet because they have been in the works since 2002, and they will continue to do so in the future. It is precisely from the individual Member States that cooperation is desired here. It's not that you're just indiscriminately accessing it. One would have to close one's eyes to the realities. I am grateful for the contributions as a whole, and I believe that we are now bringing the whole system closer to the current challenges of global crime-fighting. Effectively combating organised crime and supporting the Member States is one of the essential things we have here – even though Mrs Grässle now very much regrets that one or two opportunities may have been missed. But I wouldn't see it as negatively as she sees it. We have created very explicit cooperation here in Articles 3, 13 and 50, on OLAF in Article 75. We have also done this there with regard to the exchange of data. Of course, we are also subject to certain data protection regulations, which we have now discussed in general terms. Both OLAF and the EEA can conclude internal agreements with Eurojust in order to make the work more effective. That is why I do not see it as so negative. Maybe it could have been sorted out directly, yes. But I believe that the whole thing will come to an end once everyone has started their work properly and can work together within this framework and on this basis.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, October 4, 2018.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on Nathalie Griesbeck's report, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on the proposed regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on the mutual recognition of freezing and confiscation decisions (COM(2016)0819 - C8-0002/2017 - 2016/0412 (COD)) (A8-0001/2018).

name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I am very pleased to present to you this evening, finally, our final agreement, after the negotiations on the regulation on mutual recognition of decisions to freeze and confiscate.  It is true that the Union already had minimum rules and rules of mutual recognition, but they were far exceeded. In particular, they made it very easy for criminals and terrorists to use loopholes. That is why it was important to go back to the legislation and work fast enough. Freezing and confiscating the property and assets of criminals is also a tool in the fight against crime and terrorism, particularly because depriving terrorists of the proceeds of their illegal activities prevents them from organizing attacks. However, in this area, our margin of progress is very wide since, since we are currently working on this very important file, 98.9% of the estimated criminal profits are not confiscated and remain in the hands of criminals. In other words, only 1% of the profits of criminal origin are confiscated. This is not acceptable and we cannot continue in this way. On the other hand, let us not forget that the confiscation of the property of crime is also a very important instrument when it comes to compensating victims.  Our tools must therefore be thought of at European level and for Europeans. I was happy when the Commission immediately proposed to work on a regulation, not a directive. Even if a few Member States, in this respect, were dragging their feet a little, it is finally this legal tool that has been accepted and on which we will vote tomorrow.  Parliament, of course, adopted an ambitious position in January by a very large majority that simplifies and normalises procedures, and improves the speed and effectiveness of freeze and confiscation decisions by tightening deadlines. Of course, this is a position which gives a major place to the victims and which has been defended tooth and nail in the inter-institutional negotiations with the support of the shadow rapporteurs, whom I particularly thank for their confidence and for the good working atmosphere that has been ours. Faced with the importance of this tool, our institutional partners responded and worked quickly and painstakingly. At the end of the negotiations, we obtained a balanced tool, respectful of fundamental and operational rights. The final agreement is based on better procedural safeguards with a definition of "person concerned." This was a very important point because it could not be ignored that innocent people are sometimes affected by freezing and forfeiture decisions. Then we also had a consensus in the negotiations - it is important to say, when it exists, even with the Council - on the place given to victims and, in particular, to the compensation of the victims, since they must be at the heart of our justice system. We fought and got the social reuse of confiscated property and, finally, in one of the key objectives, Parliament was particularly united on the objective of creating a tool that is quick to be effective. Member States have been difficult to convince, but a 45-day deadline has been introduced for the recognition and enforcement of confiscation decisions.  Finally, we have fought hard to strengthen and take fundamental rights into account even better. In addition to the obligation to respect the key principles of necessity and proportionality, we have successfully fought to insert a fundamental rights-based non-recognition clause for freezing and forfeiture decisions. After weeks of deadlock, we reached an agreement and obtained such a clause for freezing decisions as well as for confiscation, which was more difficult, with a crucial mention made to the European Charter of Human Rights.
