For all these elements, I thank my colleagues for their patience, their determination and the good atmosphere and, in conclusion, I would of course also like to thank Vera Jourova and his teams for the reason that this agreement was presented to tomorrow's vote.

name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, tomorrow you will vote on the regulation on the mutual recognition of freezing and confiscation orders. The Commission attaches high importance to the adoption of this regulation as it is part of the action plan to strengthen the fight against terrorism and contributes to completing the Security Union.  First, I would like to congratulate and thank the rapporteur, Ms Nathalie  Griesbeck, for her excellent work and strong dedication on this file. For instance, her determination to maintain this piece of legislation as a regulation was very impressive. Thank you for this. We all understand that it has to be a coherent, reliable and swiftly functioning instrument and with the directive maybe this coherence would not have been as perfect as we need for the practical use of this tool.  With this regulation, we take a big step in the EU criminal justice system. It is the first regulation in the area of judicial cooperation in criminal matters. The rules will apply directly in all Member States. Secondly, the instrument will be an important step to facilitate cross—border recovery of criminal assets and lead to more efficient freezing and confiscation of funds from illicit origin in the EU.  As we already heard, at this moment, quite shockingly, 99% of criminal proceeds remain in the hands of criminals and terrorists. This is clearly not acceptable. The regulation will contribute to ensure that criminals and terrorists cannot use loopholes to fund further operations. National authorities will cooperate better and faster, with clear deadlines and standard documents. In cross—border cases, the victims’ rights to restitution and compensation will have priority over the state’s claims. That is also why I like this proposal – because it contains elementary fairness for the victims of crime.  The text includes safeguards ensuring that the mutual recognition of freezing or confiscation orders is, in line with fundamental rights, protected by the EU Charter. It finds the right balance between the need to ensure mutual recognition and the respect of fundamental rights at the same time.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: Rapporteur of the Committee on Legal Affairs. – Madam President, Commissioner, the Commission's proposal on mutual recognition of detention and confiscation orders is a typical example of European legislation that brings undeniable added value to all citizens of the European Union. We can effectively combat transnational crime only with instruments of a transnational nature. It should be noted that the current situation and the lack of sufficient harmonisation facilitate the financing of crime.  It is our responsibility, as EU legislators, not to facilitate the crime of life and to adopt procedural rules that allow the confiscation of the proceeds of crime of a cross-border nature. The Committee on Legal Affairs has drawn up an opinion on this proposal, in which it proposes, in particular, to clarify certain wordings so that the resulting text is indeed sufficiently precise.

name: Innocenzo LEONTINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to congratulate Mrs Griesbeck on her work as rapporteur and I, as shadow rapporteur and successor to my Apulian colleague, who has taken over, point out that the 98.9% of the proceeds from unre confiscated criminal activities is an exaggerated percentage. The confiscation of the proceeds of crime and the freezing of these assets is a key measure in the fight against organised crime and terrorist activity. To date, The Member States have implemented the minimum measures in force in the Member States in a deficient or rarely. On 21 December 2016, the Commission adopted a proposal for a regulation regulating the mutual recognition by Member States of confiscation and freezing of assets from criminal activities. From now on, an order issued by the authority of one Member State can be recognised and implemented quickly in all other Member States. The scope of this regulation extends to new types of confiscation, in line with Directive 2014/42/EU, but going beyond it, especially where it provides for less limited forms of non-conviction-based confiscation. The implementation of this regulation makes it possible to use resources to compensate the families of the victims, to combat organised crime and to take initiatives for social purposes, providing for the establishment of competent offices for each individual Member State. The Council and Parliament have established a text providing for 45 days for the execution of confiscation orders and 96 hours for the implementation of freezing orders. The regulation makes mutual recognition of freezing confiscation orders more efficient, faster and more homogeneous.

name: Emilian PAVEL
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank Ms Griesbeck for her work. Ms Griesbeck, you were tough and you were efficient when it came to defending Parliament’s position, especially when we fought together to protect human rights. I thank you especially for that because, as you know, it was my number one priority. This regulation is one of the three measures intended to strengthen the EU’s capacity to fight organised crime and terrorism and to cut off the sources of financing for criminals and terrorists across the Union. It is important that this is a regulation and not a directive. We must deprive criminals of the proceeds of their crime. Moreover, confiscation allows victims to be compensated and provides additional funds to invest in law enforcement activities or other crime prevention initiatives.  In June, the Council, following a provisional agreement with Parliament, agreed on new rules. The general principle of recognition means that all judicial decisions in criminal matters taken in one Member State shall be – and normally will be – directly recognised and enforced by another Member State. The regulation sets out a number of grounds for non—recognition and non—execution based on fundamental rights, which we fought for together and we were successful. I would also like to thank the shadows. In the final text, thanks to our work, many safeguards have been added and fundamental rights will be fully protected. We asked, and achieved, standards, certificates and procedures to allow speedy and efficient freezing and confiscation actions – a deadline of 45 days for the recognition of a confiscation order and, in urgent cases, a deadline of 44 hours for the recognition, and 44 hours for the execution, of freezing orders. Those limits can be postponed only under the strict conditions detailed in this regulation. Finally, yet importantly, there are provisions to ensure that victims’ rights to compensation and restitution are respected in cross—border cases.  This legislative instrument is the first regulation based on the principle of mutual recognition concerning criminal law proceedings. I encourage you to support it and to vote in favour tomorrow.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: on behalf of the ECR group. – Madam President, where are we with the confiscation and seizure? Only 1% of the property that comes from the crime is seized today. Trillions of euros are generated by crime, but we only recover 1.2 billion euros a year, the rest remain for criminals. That is why I am disappointed by the steps taken by this regulation. So I'll be the critical part, apparently, of what we're going to vote for. Of course it has many good parts, but I'll refer to the ones that disappoint me.  In the new text of the regulation, the concept of 'bona fide third parties' is replaced by that of 'affected persons' - this includes those against whom seizure or confiscation warrants have been issued. Time limits for mutual recognition and enforcement of claims, seizure or confiscation orders increase, instead of decreasing. Three - the protection of the confidentiality of ongoing investigations is greatly diluted compared to the Commission's proposal and four - new grounds for non-recognition of confiscation and seizure orders are introduced.  As such, it will be harder to seize and harder to seize.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in Europe we often talk about the added value of cooperation, recognising that we can only solve some problems at Union level. Well, this file is a good example of that. In 2010, some EUR 110 billion, or almost 1% of Europe's GDP, flowed into criminal activity. Between 2010 and 2014, we were able to freeze only 2.2% of that and confiscate only 1.1%. The reason for this is not that the competent authorities would not make sufficient efforts, and certainly not that we cannot use the money. The real reason is clear: a lack of cooperation. Terrorism and organised crime operate across borders. Thanks to this legislation, our case law will soon do the same. Dear colleagues tomorrow, we'll close the net.

name: Eva JOLY
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, Commissioner, as has been pointed out, crime deprives our States of EUR 110 billion every year and 99% of these illegal profits are never recovered and remain warm in the pockets of criminals. Let us not let the money of crime prosper: let us confiscate it across borders. This regulation on mutual recognition of decisions to freeze and confiscate assets is welcome. Thanks to it, a Member State will directly recognise and execute on its territory a decision to freeze or confiscate it by another Member State in the context of criminal proceedings. This is an important step towards a genuine European area of freedom, security and justice. Fighting crime together must not be at the expense of citizens' rights. I therefore appreciate that we have reached a compromise with the Council on the possibility of refusing recognition of a forfeiture decision in the event that fundamental rights have not been respected, such as the right to a fair trial. These precautions are essential at a time when several European governments are seriously undermining the fundamentals of justice.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, the UK’s adoption of the European Union system of criminal law is destroying our freedoms and liberties under English law.  Magna Carta said that the English could not be arrested or imprisoned without evidence laid against them in an English court. The European Union has swept away that ancient liberty. We can now be imprisoned in a foreign jail on the basis of unsubstantiated accusations on a piece of paper.  Under the Bill of Rights 1689, we could not be fined or have our property confiscated without a criminal conviction in an English court. That liberty was swept away under the EU Directive that allows our assets to be frozen or confiscated on the say—so of a foreign court. Now the EU wants to turn this directive into a regulation so that Member States will have no leeway in its application, and it even allows for non—conviction—based confiscation orders.  For centuries the English could not be imprisoned or have their property taken away without a criminal conviction under their own laws in their own courts. Now a court in any corrupt EU Member State can judicially kidnap our citizens and freeze or confiscate their property. Our governments tell us that we have to surrender our liberties so that they can protect us from cross—border crime and terrorism. The same governments open their borders to any organised criminal from around the world that wants to launder their money in our banking systems. They open our borders to any thief or fraudster that can come purely because they are EU citizens and we cannot deny them entry. Her Majesty’s Government wants to opt into this regulation and Mrs May no doubt intends to incorporate it into her proposed security treaty with the EU after Brexit. UKIP MEPs will vote against this. We protect British liberties and freedoms, not betray them.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her This is an important step towards combating illegally acquired assets. I would like to highlight a case that, coincidentally, really has to do with the United Kingdom. This concerns the ex-banker Ablyasov from Kazakhstan, who allegedly embezzled EUR 10 billion in the bank where he worked and then flew to the UK. A British court then convicted him and said: we are making a freezing order here and we are having that assets secured. He was also sentenced to 22 months in prison. And then what does this ex-banker do? He flees to France. He was also jailed in France, but after three years, in 2016, he was detained in a night-and-fog action. Since then, he has not been found. We do not know what has happened to these EUR 10 billion. Finding out this is, of course, in the interests of this bank, which is massively behind it. But it is also, I think, in our interest that this illegal money be collected and returned to the rightful owner.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Madam President, the current regime is ineffective and practically unworkable. The freezing of the assets of criminal organizations is minimal, the message that crime does not reward non-existent and the return of the product and crime profits elusive dream. It is beyond unacceptable that profits from illegal activities should remain available to criminals.  Clarity and legal certainty are needed by simplifying and clarifying the overall framework for mutual recognition of judgments and by strengthening the role of the competent national authorities.  However, any action against criminals must ultimately be served in favour of all citizens, i.e. with respect for fundamental rights, strong procedural guarantees, provisions for compensation, effective and effective access to appropriate remedies and acts of freezing and confiscation by prosecuting, prosecutorial or judicial authorities against sufficient evidence. Because procedures which do not guarantee independence, transparency, impartiality and proportionality can, in the wrong hands, abuse and malicious individual citizens.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is a good day as far as I am concerned. I remember three years ago i went to work with the police and judicial services in South Limburg. I visited men and women who work every day to ensure our security in the border region. This is not easy, especially in a province like mine where we have more borders with Belgium and Germany than with our own Netherlands. What has always stayed with me from that working visit is the frustration that has been there about how difficult it is sometimes to freeze or confiscate criminal property across the border. When a drug dealer is arrested and prosecuted in the Netherlands but his money or his Ferrari is parked on the other side of the border, it is very difficult to get there. This is not just a problem in the border region. The Commissioner has already said that the illegal markets in the EU are around EUR 110 billion. We are failing to confiscate more than one percent of that. So a large part of it remains in the hands of criminals. There's only one way we can hurt these criminals, and that's in their wallets. Criminals cannot be led or stopped by national borders, so neither can the police and the judiciary. This new legislation will make it easier in the future to seize the money and resources of criminals on the other side of the border. That is very bad news for criminals and therefore very good news for all of us. Above all, it shows that the EU can tackle these issues, that EU rules can have added value in practice and that we are able to translate the concerns of citizens in the border region into this type of policy. That is our most important task in this Parliament and I am very pleased that we have succeeded today.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like to thank Mrs Griesbeck and the shadow rapporteurs for their excellent work on a proposal for a regulation which sets another essential piece for combating transnational crime. Targeting criminal organisations where it hurts the most, that is to say in economic interests: the freezing and confiscation of assets are in fact the main means of depriving organised criminal groups of the profits and resources necessary for their illegal operation. The regulation complements and strengthens the European regulatory framework, will ensure more effective and rapid recognition of freezing and confiscation orders between Member States, allowing these criminal profits to be hit throughout the Territory of the Union, and it is particularly important to provide for the mutual recognition of so-called confiscation orders in the absence of conviction, which with the right guarantees and with respect for fundamental rights , represent a significant step forward in the fight against criminal organisations. And it is still important to forecast the re-use of confiscated assets for social purposes, a measure that promotes value and I would say a sense of legality.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: Mr President, colleagues, terrorists and criminals can all too easily siphon off their proceeds through the EU today, with the result that barely one percent of the crime money can be taken out of criminal hands. This is a very sad figure. In order to eradicate terrorism, it is crucial that we drain the sources of funding. This is an area in which the EU can and must prove its real added value. The fight against terror can only be won if we make a fist together. The wave of attacks has shown very clearly that there is a need for further European cooperation in this area. I therefore fully support this new European measure, which forces the Member States to cooperate better to freeze and confiscate criminal goods. This is a positive evolution in the European legislative framework that contributes to the development of a security culture in Europe.

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: – Madam President... congratulations, Nathalie!  The confiscation of property as a product of criminal activities is an effective instrument for combating crime and terrorism; but nothing is confiscate, almost nothing. It is therefore essential to ensure the effectiveness, throughout the Union, of the seizure and confiscation of property of criminal origin, and to prevent criminals from being able to take advantage of existing gaps in the Union in order to transfer their assets and thus circumvent orders in this regard.  The seizure and confiscation of the assets of crime are among the most effective means of combating organized crime. However, further coordination between Member States needs to be deepened. It is essential to block flows of money from and from criminal organizations quickly, as well as to improve the speed and effectiveness of procedures for recognizing seizure and confiscation resolutions.  Therefore, the strengthening of principles proposed in this Regulation, such as the recognition and enforcement of judgments in criminal matters, are essential to undermine the scourge of any form of organised crime.  What I have just said is the cornerstone of judicial criminal cooperation.  It is also important to mention the possibility of pre-emptive confiscation when you are sure that there is a link to a criminal activity; and, moreover, the notion of necessity and proportionality must be a constant, as included in the text, in the resolutions we are discussing today.  Finally, mutual recognition of procedures and improved efficiency in embargo and confiscation work are, together with the fight against laundering and the detection of illicit cash movements, essential tools to combat crime and terror financing.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, a regulation, a european law directly binding in this package of measures aimed at strengthening the European Union in its fight against transnational crime and counter-terrorism. I join the recognition of the work of our rapporteur Nathalie. But I am centred on the incardination of this initiative together with the one we discussed earlier, Eurojust. And the European Public Prosecutor's Office. And the Union's Directive on the Protection of Financial Interests, of which I had the honour of being rapporteur. But I stress, once again, the requirement that this base its effectiveness on the mutual recognition of judgments for confiscation, confiscation and seizure of property from criminal activity and criminality. And such recognition must take place on the basis of mutual trust in general so that exceptions are appraised, based solely on exceptionality, on the weighting of the particular case, on the impact on fundamental rights and on consultation with the requesting State. In addition, I stress the importance of efficient management of these assets in compensation for victims and in protecting the relatives of victims and reusing for social purposes the confiscation of all property and assets from the fight against crime and organised crime.

name: Emil RADEV
text: – Honourable Madam President, Commissioner, honourable Members, I welcome the agreement reached on the Regulation on the mutual recognition of freezing and confiscation orders. The Union legal framework in this area was quite lagging behind and did not reflect the modern development of European and national laws. Currently, 99% of possible profits from criminal activity are not confiscated and remain available to criminals. The modernisation of the legal framework for the confiscation of criminal assets is therefore a much needed and effective tool to combat crime and terrorism at eu level. The new provisions will facilitate mutual recognition, which means that all judgments in criminal matters given in one Member State of the European Union will in principle be directly recognised and implemented in another Member State. Countries of the European Union, at the request of another Member State, will now be able to confiscate assets that are not direct proceeds of crime, as well as assets belonging to a third party. I believe that confiscation of property in other Member States will now be faster and more efficient. In addition, property will be able to be confiscated, even if there is not yet a conviction, for example, if the suspect has fled. The introduction of standard certificates and procedures, as well as European Union-wide deadlines such as a deadline of 45 days for recognition of a confiscation order, and in urgent cases a deadline of 48 hours for recognition and 48 hours for the execution of freezing orders, will allow for a rapid response by the competent authorities. I believe that this European cooperation instrument will ensure precisely the effective freezing and confiscation of criminal assets throughout the European Union. This will contribute to enhancing the security of the Union by combating the financing of crime, including terrorist activities.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, here we are this afternoon debating two regulations: the regulation reorganising Eurojust, which is very important, and this regulation. I also want to stress, as colleague Paul said, that it is good that it is not a directive and is a regulation, because there will be no difference in the assimilation, in the implementation of this extremely important instrument, of the Regulation on the mutual recognition of freezing and confiscation orders. I am convinced that it will be an extremely important instrument in the internal market of the European Union. We need supervisory mechanisms and I believe that regulation will be the main mechanism.  With this regulation and its provisions we can obviously combat crime, as has been said, but we can interrupt the financing of terrorism. There are illegal markets, figures have been given here, statistics I think still do not include everything that means illegal market. It is also alarming that, for so long, we have not been able to recover a very large percentage of the profits that are estimated to be obtained through crime.  European justice means judicial cooperation in both civil and criminal matters. I believe in this regulation and I hope it will be voted on tomorrow.

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Mafia does business casually across national borders and exploits the legislative weaknesses of the different countries and also their lack of cooperation, so even on this, if we are a Union, it makes sense to try to take the good practices developed in a state and make them common European heritage. It is therefore essential to provide for strong measures such as the one we are discussing today, the mutual recognition of confiscation orders even in the absence of conviction, because precisely this aspect has proved crucial in the Italian context in order to combat mafia organisations. By the way, it is an instrument that can also be very deterrent. The Union is therefore taking a very important step today towards harmonising the rules for combating mafias, choosing to attack the strong in order to protect the weak. In fact, frozen goods to criminal organisations can be used to compensate victims and their families or to strengthen the fight against crime. So we are very happy that this tool finally gets to port.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (start of speech outside the microphone) 99% of offenders' assets are not confiscated or even secured. This is an absolutely dramatic situation which shows how the European Union's justice system is ineffective and is not coping with this problem. I would add that terrorist groups spend only a few percent of their income on terrorist attacks alone. The whole is consumed in a completely different way. The fact that we are taking up this decision and this debate today is a testament to our determination, but I will immediately emphasise the late determination. I hope that the adoption of this regulation tomorrow will make it easier that, firstly, it will be possible to secure, and secondly, confiscate assets from criminal offences more quickly and efficiently.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Mr Speaker, the Rapporteur has done a great job and has really improved the Commission's proposal and I thank her this way. The progress made on procedural guarantees is important so that those having their assets frozen have the opportunity to challenge those orders before the competent courts. While the fight against terrorism and organised crime is extremely important, and one of the key components of this fight is to stop the cross-border financing of illegal activities, we must not forget the presumption of innocence and, accordingly, we must create an effective and swift framework for litigation in such cases. As a former police officer, I congratulate the rapporteur on the proposal to finance compensation for damages to the families of police officers and other public workers who died or died badly in the line of duty.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Mr President, if we want the people of Europe to have confidence in the governments, but especially in the state systems in force in the Member States, an excellent first step would be to combat organised crime, particularly the economic one.  Mutual recognition of freezing and confiscation orders between states has already been largely delayed. We must assure the citizens that anyone who gets rich in violation of the laws will not only not enjoy their illegal profits, but they will be seized immediately and without discounts. In particular, I would not like to focus on the confiscating of property acquired through corruption by state officials and politicians. There are not a few cases where we see politicians living a life that is luxurious, disproportionate to their incomes.  Finally, I would like the measures to be taken to be much more immediate and effective, as I believe that the provisions justified to some extent in favour of the accused are detrimental to the public interest when they go beyond the measure.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: – Mr President, the fight against the financing of organised crime and terrorism is an area in which action is needed at European level, because it is of a cross-border nature. EU states must mutually recognise freezing and confiscation decisions taken in another Member State. Freezing and confiscating criminal property is an effective means of combating organised crime. At present, however, only 1.1% of funds obtained by illegal means are seized.  The purpose of the proposal for a regulation before us is to facilitate cooperation between Member States in order to recover the proceeds of crime in such a way that funds can be condemned to the State more effectively. I very much welcome the fact that frozen and confiscated funds can be used to compensate victims of organised crime and also to channel funds to the fight against organised crime.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, an effective method of dealing with organised crime and terrorism is the freezing and confiscation of assets derived from illegal activities. The necessary cooperation between the countries in order for this policy to succeed is facilitated by the mutual recognition of the commitments and confiscating warrants issued by a State. In this way, as I said earlier, we will not allow criminals to use the illegally acquired money.  On the other hand, particular attention should be paid to how this principle should be implemented and applied. It is unacceptable to violate human rights and to have preventive freezing and confiscation. In order to do so, a conviction and final decision related to a criminal offence must certainly have preceded it. Otherwise, it is unacceptable to accept such a situation. In addition, the money pledged must be returned in full to the victims.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the freezing of assets and the confiscation of the products of crime are necessary in order to combat terrorism, corruption of state officials and politicians, all kinds of criminal organisations, such as the mafia, but also the slave traders who literally fill Europe with illegal immigrants.  It should therefore be possible to enforce decisions in another Member State, across borders, because most of them commit the crime in one State and the products of the crime take them to another State. Of course, there must be a regulation, as has been mentioned, in order for the application to be immediate, the recovery of illegal revenue must take place and the principle of the protection of fundamental rights and procedural guarantees must be respected.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, thank you very much for this very interesting debate about the regulation on the confiscation and freezing of assets or income from criminal activities. Debating this topic, I am aware that it has a much wider context. I am sure that you also hear from EU citizens that there is decreasing trust among the people in the EU institutions. One of the sources of this distrust is that the people do not see justice delivering enough justice – the justice system delivering fairness. This is something we have to stop, and we have to be much better, and in the EU being better means co-operating better. This is what we are discussing about today.  We spoke before about Eurojust, now we are speaking about freezing and confiscation orders. Later today we will speak about the fight against money laundering. In all these cases we speak about combating organised crime, which has a cross-border scope and which requires perfect and well-orchestrated cooperation at EU level. Of course, as many of you mentioned here, a very efficient way to stop the criminals is to cut them off from the money. That this is exactly what we are trying to do in this proposal. Back to cooperation, I would have wished to have a good debate. For instance with Mr Batten, who spoke here about the issue of sovereignty. I don’t share this opinion. I think that cooperation is not contradicting national sovereignty. It’s a big misunderstanding, and I am sure that everything that we do in criminal justice cooperation is to create proposals and plans which fully respect the sovereignty of Member States, which fully respect fundamental rights and individual freedoms of people, and which respond to security threats to the extent which is necessary and proportionate from the side of law enforcement authorities.  Also, this proposal which we are debating today is, as I said before, well balanced, balancing the need to deliver more security and, at the same time, more justice and full respect for fundamental rights.  This is my comment on what we heard from the British Member. On this topic, I would like to mention that we have very good cooperation with the British authorities. We speak about future cooperation in the fields of security and justice, because this is of vital importance, both for the EU and the United Kingdom. I would wish for very intensive cooperation in the future, not only within the EU itself and among the Member States, but also between the EU and the United Kingdom.

name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I will be very brief and just mention a few points. The first is to say how much I share the analysis that the vera Jourova has just made in relation to the quality of this afternoon's debate. We have heard positions that, for some, were very different or even opposed, including one of the positions opposed to the regulation, which is to mix - perhaps cynically or perhaps candidly - the idea of cooperation to combat cross-border organised crime and the possession of state sovereignty. During the debate this afternoon, there were the proponents of this position, including our British friends and colleagues, and others, those who want to do everything possible to ensure that cooperation allows us to track down and shake up, while complicating the task, cross-border criminal organisations and in particular terrorists. Compared to colleagues who regretted that it did not come early enough, I will respond with the adage "better late than never". It is true that this may have come sooner, but this view may also be difficult to reach an agreement with 27 Member States, and therefore with colleagues whose positions are distinct. Last or penultimate point, I think that many of us tomorrow, for the vote, will find ourselves united on this issue and this regulation, this legal tool that will allow us to be effective and fast.  In conclusion, I am on time, I would like to thank the Commissioner, her teams and the Council, and to thank warmly also and above all the rapporteurs, the co-reporters, with whom we have spent busy hours and sometimes had bitter discussions: I really thank them from the bottom of my heart and tell you tomorrow for the vote.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place on Thursday 4 October 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. The Regulation on the mutual recognition of freezing and confiscation orders is part of the package of three legislative proposals (together with the Regulation on the control of money transfers and the anti-money laundering directive), presented by the Commission in December 2016 and aimed at consolidating the EU's capacity to combat the financing of organised crime and terrorism. As the Italian experience also shows, attacking the capital aspects of the activities of criminal organisations is one of the most effective methods of combating them, and, given the now intrinsically cross-border nature of criminal and terrorist actions, cooperation at EU level in these areas is absolutely necessary.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The adoption of a new regulation on the mutual recognition of security and confiscation orders will make it easier for national authorities to seize and collect assets at national level and improve the cross-border enforcement of security and confiscation orders. This Regulation introduces the principle of mutual recognition, which means that all judicial decisions in criminal matters in one EU country will normally be directly recognised and enforced by another Member State. This will prevent criminals from transferring their assets in the EU. The safeguarding and confiscation of criminal assets are very effective tools in the fight against crime and terrorist financing, as they deprive criminals of the proceeds of their crimes and prevent them from using these funds to finance new criminal activities, including terrorism. Furthermore, confiscation makes it possible to compensate victims and respect victims' rights to compensation. It also provides additional funds for investments in law enforcement or other prevention initiatives. For these reasons, I will vote in favour of this report.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: in writing. – Finally, the European Commission has finally come up with a European regulation to facilitate the freezing and confiscation of assets hidden abroad by criminally convicted persons. Perhaps now it will not be so easy for people who are criminally convicted to take refuge in other countries, where they can live by consuming the transferred wealth and defying the citizens of the countries where they have made these fortunes through crime.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I believe that it is fully appropriate for the EP and the Council to prepare as a matter of urgency a draft regulation on the mutual recognition of security and confiscation orders. The project must respond to the activities of criminals in Europe who benefit materially by exploiting various gaps in European law. Practice shows that hard-line crime is the most effective way to combat crime, including organised crime. According to Europol's assessment, various illegal markets operating in the European Union generate around €110 billion a year, or 1% of the Union's GDP. Police practice indicates that only a fraction of a percent is recovered from this pot, and the vast majority of profits remain at the disposal of criminals. Of course, this must be combated. It is important that these methods of combat are included in the regulation, which, as the eu's most powerful legal act, will have to be directly applied by all EU countries. The proposed Regulation should not only apply directly to criminals, but should also cover confiscation of third parties if there is no doubt that they have the proceeds of criminal activity.

name: Tadeusz ZWIEFKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Cooperation between justice and mutual trust are an indispensable part of the effective fight against crime, which is increasingly crossing the borders of the European Union. I am therefore pleased that this cooperation is also supported by a solid legal framework and further instruments that will hinder criminal activity within the Union. It is currently estimated that 98.9% of possible criminal profits are not confiscated and remain at the disposal of criminals. The new solutions will make it easier to freeze assets and confiscate property from crime across the Union. On the one hand, this will prevent these funds from being used for further criminal activities and, on the other hand, it will ensure that victims' rights to compensation and restitution in cross-border cases are respected. In practice, a confiscation order issued by a court in one Member State will be recognised and executed in another EU country within a maximum of two days. In this way, criminal law procedures will also be significantly accelerated in the area of preventive confiscation.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the report by Anna Maria Corazza Bildt, on behalf of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on a framework for the free movement of non-personal data within the European Union (COM(20) 17)0495 – C8-0312/2017 – 2017/0228(COD)) (A8-0201/2018).

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, the digital revolution is changing all parts of our lives, and we are still only at the beginning of this exciting development. Movement of data will grow in volume and importance, and my vision is for an open, safe and global internet for all. With this regulation we will remove barriers, borders and burdens impeding the free flow of non-personal data. We have, de facto, established the fifth freedom in the internal market – data – next to freedom of movement of people, goods, services and capital. It is a game changer for the digital economy. The Free Flow of Data (FFoD) Regulation is a regulation to deregulate. We are removing national data localisation requirements and facilitating portability of cloud service providers. Step by step, we are creating a legal framework for the future digital economy. We are creating a level playing field for companies to compete globally. With the USA and China moving fast – as you always point out, Vice-President Ansip – and with much more data available than in Europe, access to data for companies and especially for SMEs is crucial. FFoD has the potential to create efficiency throughout the value chain, to enable economies of scale and to boost innovation, paving the way for artificial intelligence, cloud computing and big data analysis. It is a good example of better regulation, with the clear added value of a Europe that delivers concrete results. The estimated associated GDP growth is EUR 8 billion per year – equal to the two free-trade agreements between the European Union and South Korea and Canada. So what have we achieved? With the new rules, any data that is non-personal can be stored and processed anywhere in the EU – sales data, revenues, profits, stock prices, balance sheets, product design, price lists – to name but a few. We have succeeded in keeping just one exception: in the case of a threat to public security, the Member States may still allow restriction of data localisation. Companies and public administration will have the possibility to outsource data processes anywhere in the EU, but it is not an obligation. We have clarified that this applies at all levels of government – national, regional and local. Also, public administrations which run in-house cloud service systems, like the Bundescloud in Germany, will be able to use them, and we have succeeded in ensuring that the public procurement of cloud services by Member States will be open to operators from throughout the European Union. We have also facilitated portability of cloud service providers. It has to be as simple for companies, especially for SMEs, to move, for example, from iCloud to Tieto as it is to change telephone operators from Vodafone to Telia. The market players, which are the ones best suited, will have 18 months to develop and implement codes of conduct to ensure easy switching between cloud service providers. The new law will not affect citizens’ privacy. The General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) will remain untouched. In cases where personal and non-personal data are inextricably linked in a mixed data set, FFoD will not prejudge GDPR. We have clarified the concept and added safeguards to ensure that the rules afford legal certainty and are up to date and fit for purpose, including in the future. We have asked the Commission to present guidelines on how the regulation will apply to mixed data sets, before its entry into force, and we have shortened the review time to four years. Lastly, competent authorities with a legitimate reason can access company data stored in another Member State via a simplified procedure and a point of single contact. I am proud that we can deliver rules that are simple, net neutral and easy to apply in real life. The time has come to stand up against the data protectionism that is threatening our digital economy and society. And in this case, if I may dare to say so: mission accomplished! (Applause)

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Vice—President of the Commission. – Mr President, a digital society cannot exist without data. If Europe is to get the best from the opportunities offered by digital progress, data has to flow freely with no obstacles and no constraints. Data feeds into innovation. In turn that makes the kind of technologies possible which bring new jobs and improve our environment and daily lives: the ‘internet of things’, artificial intelligence, fintech, ‘smart cities’ and electronic health systems, to mention just a few. The new regulation complements the principle of free movement of personal data that is enshrined in the General Data Protection Regulation. It guarantees the free movement of all data and does so by leaving the General Data Protection Regulation completely untouched. This regulation does not cover personal data, but it does for non—personal data what the General Data Protection Regulation has already done for personal data, namely free movement across the European Union. It has three important elements. Firstly, it prohibits unjustified requirements about where data should be localised. These restrictions are only allowed in exceptional circumstances where this is justified by public security. Secondly, there will be a mechanism to make sure that regulatory authorities still have access to data stored in another Member State. They may also impose penalties on users that do not provide access to data, but they may not deviate from the free flow principle by relocalising the data for a long period without the Commission first giving its permission. Thirdly, the regulation will make the EU market for cloud services more fluid. It allows the industry to develop self—regulatory codes of conduct so that users will be able to move data more easily between IT systems and switch between cloud service providers. This should be done within the next two years. The Regulation on the Free Flow of non—personal Data has gone through the legislative process at record speed. The Commission only proposed it last September so the time taken to reach this point of conclusion has been a little more than a year. We have been helped enormously by the political will to conclude quickly both in Parliament and the Council, which have been calling for this initiative since the beginning of this Commission’s mandate in office.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: draft opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Dear Colleagues, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. Barriers to access to data and data exchange – as we all know – can prevent the creation of innovative products, services and solutions. Such practices undermine the full potential of the data economy and are thus a factor holding back the European Union's economic growth. That is why I welcomed the European Commission's proposal for a draft regulation on the free movement of non-personal data, expecting decisive steps to counter trends towards national rules forcing providers to place data in a particular territory. The intensive work that we have been doing in the European Parliament is an expression of our support for the need for swift legislative action by the Union to address unjustified obstacles to the free movement of non-personal data, such as locational requirements, and to promote self-regulation with the definition of its framework guidelines on data portability. This should create incentives for innovative solutions and thus encourage more users to use the services provided by new and small businesses entering new markets.

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner! Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which First of all, I am very pleased that my colleague Anna Corazza Bildt has managed to make this proposal, which is important for the Digital Single Market, capable of winning a majority in Parliament at great speed and to conclude the necessary trialogue negotiations quickly with the Council. A really big thank you to her and all the shadow rapporteurs for that. It is true – and Vice-President Ansip pointed out – that we in the European Union still have the problem that data localisation rules make it difficult to harness the real full force of the internal market for digital providers. With this proposal, we are able to take a major step forward in the Digital Single Market. We have adopted a whole series of other directives in recent weeks and months. I believe that, with this proposal, we are making it clear that the Digital Single Market offers all well-meaning, all serious providers a chance to work even more efficiently. The General Data Protection Regulation, the basic principles of data protection, are not weakened by this directive, but strengthened. They remain untouched. At the same time, however, we are promoting the free movement of data in Europe in a way that allows the Member States to decide for themselves which supranational services they want to use. But the principle is that, in principle, the market is queried throughout Europe. And that's very, very good news. Secondly, I think it is important that we supplement these proposals. European citizens are, of course, increasingly concerned that much of the data they post in public directories cannot be used anywhere as is desirable. That is why it is important that we also finalise the proposal on platform regulation in the coming months, so that the picture as a whole is comprehensible to the citizens of Europe.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: for the S&D Group. Mr President! Commissioner, Mrs Corazza Bildt, colleagues. It is indeed a great thing that we are standing here today and are going to be discussing this legislation on the free flow of non-personal data around the European Union. It is a major step forward that we should establish this in the EUROPEAN Internal Market. This is part of the effort to ensure that we also have a digital single market. That is why I am pleased that we managed to find some good solutions that have the broad support of the political groups. This will provide good opportunities for many companies, and in the end it will also mean that the consumer will have much better choices.  I can mention that in my own country, Apple, Google and Facebook build data centers for the very big gold medal. A great many are being built, and it is great that we are now also creating legislation that makes it possible to attract data to countries that want it - and not least to countries that produce green energy. So I'm happy. However, I would also like to say that it is important that, in the work on the free flow of non-personal data, we pay close attention to complying with the rules we have agreed upon. It is important that we make sure that where there is any personal data involved at all, gdpr applies. We also need to be aware - but we have also written into the legislation - that there is an increasing possibility of technology converting non-personal data into personal data, and here we also need to make sure that gdpr is the law that applies. But once we get it secured, I'm very happy.  I am sure that we will have a better functioning internal market, we will get the cloud services off and we can be sure that consumers will end up getting better deals, better products, because with this competition they can also get cheaper offers. So I am very pleased and thank you for your good cooperation, not least to Mrs Corazza Bildt.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I want to thank the rapporteur for her work in driving this dossier forward. This was critical in ensuring that we reached a swift agreement.  Ensuring the free flow of data is vital to create a competitive data economy. Without genuine competition in the data processing market, we will all continue to pay more than we should do for slower quality services. A healthy data market is the first requirement for a successful digital single market. At the moment, the free flow of data is hindered by a series of obstacles. Many public authorities and branches of government have unjustifiable data localisation requirements. Their data sets were huge parts of the market and we need them to lead by example.  There’s also a lot of legal uncertainty about what laws apply in storing data across borders. We know that many customers have difficulties in switching providers for cloud storage and that there are some questionable practices in that market. Underpinning all of these obstacles to free flow of data is a lack of trust, a fear that if you store your data across borders you may have difficulties getting it when you need it.  This regulation should be a game changer for the economy. It creates a clear and unambiguous legal regime for the storage of data across borders. It prohibits data localisation except in specific justified cases of a risk to national security, and it gives legal certainty that data can be accessed across borders. It also fosters a cloud market where switching is easy, encouraging competitiveness of cloud service providers.  Let’s make no mistake, this is the biggest success in the digital single market so far and I very much hope that we can use this as a benchmark also for agreements on the free flow of data in future with third countries.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, this is a regulation that I believe the whole Parliament should support. It is a regulation that I personally fought for, sending a letter with my colleagues to the President of the Commission asking the Commission to act and make a proposal.  I am happy today to see the result that we can confirm the new fifth freedom in the European Union: the free movement of data. The free flow of data is vital to the digital economy and the single market as a whole. The free flow of data is what makes cloud computing services work. Everything from email to accountancy software needs the free flow of data to work. Everything from traffic to weather information needs the free flow of data to work. It was clear that at the European level, we needed to prevent actions which would have put our digital future at risk, including ill—advised national measures restricting this free flow. This regulation is an example of what the European Union is all about. It is about removing barriers and preventing new ones from arising. It is about making the single market work for everyone – businesses and citizens alike. It is about agreeing common European rules and then treating every Member State equally – rules that allow data to be stored anywhere in Europe without discrimination. It is about adopting simple rules and simple legislation that solve real life problems so consumers and taxpayers can get the best value for their money while facing less red tape and pointless barriers in their daily lives. This is why I was proud to be part of the team and I want to say thank the rapporteur, Maria Corazza Bildt, for her work on this file.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you to the rapporteur for her excellent work and the speed of her work. Following the regulation on the protection of personal data, the regulation on the free flow of non-personal data is another important step towards the completion of a European data market, data that is increasingly transparent, accessible and at the same time more protected. Today, businesses cannot choose the least expensive places to store or process their data. The many administrative obstacles present make it difficult to change service providers or transfer data back to their IT systems. Thanks to this legislation, companies will be able to avoid duplication of data in several places, will be able to enter new markets and strengthen their activities. The data will circulate freely throughout the European Union and barriers to storage services will be broken down, those services that are the starting point for the development of an increasingly open and digital public administration, where services and documents are available to citizens with a single click. To grasp the importance of the phenomenon, just remember that in ten years the scope of the data economy will grow almost twentyfold and therefore after people, goods, services and capital, the doors are opened to the fifth freedom in the digital single market, that of data, which will favor sectors such as the Internet of Things, blockchain, health care, remote surgery and intelligent mobility solutions , such as self-driving cars.  All this will happen, however, without weakening the control of the national authorities that will be able to exercise the right of access to data throughout Europe. This control will be crucial because an increasingly digitised world is a more vulnerable world and it is our duty to work to protect the most vulnerable parties, namely citizens, individuals and businesses.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, once again with this proposal, you are destroying every chance of a balanced text that respects the interests of the Member States and their independence.  The abolition of digital borders is a major mistake in proportions equivalent to the abolition of physical borders. The end of geoblocking, demanded once again, and the requirement to locate data are measures that further limit the numerical sovereignty of the Member States. The positive and important points of the text are thus relayed in the background, the tragic fate of most of the texts debated here in this House. The real legislative stakes are held hostage by disastrous ideological provisions. For example, the issue of the protection of mixed data, which is both personal and non-personal, deserved to be truly defended pragmatically and certainly did not deserve to be used for the benefit of an ultraliberal project, as the rapporteur here, who is once again missing the opportunity to be reasonable, did.

name: Róża THUN UND HOHENSTEIN
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I have been living in Schengen for more than ten years, I am driving all over the European Union, I do not notice the borders, because they are invisible, but they are still there. And it is these barriers that make us develop more slowly than we can, and that is why we must constantly, systematically, step by step put up with them. Today, we are taking another good step towards achieving a true digital single market in the European Union. Removing data location restrictions will not only contribute to economic growth, but will be another element that connects citizens in a very concrete and tangible way within our Union. These new rules, and in particular the principle of cross-border free movement of non-personal data, will ensure that entrepreneurs are able to carry out their business. Yes, entrepreneurs will be able to operate more efficiently, more easily and cheaply in different countries and will no longer be accompanied by the obligation to duplicate IT systems and store them in different locations. With this regulation, therefore, we will make businesses feel more confident entering new markets and increasingly use cloud services, and research shows that the new rules on the free flow of non-personal data will generate an additional EUR 8 billion per year for the EU economy.  So I would like to take this opportunity to thank the rapporteur, Anna Maria Corazza Bildt, for her continued efforts to harmonise the single market, for her extremely impressive work on this report, together with the shadow rapporteurs, with the European Commission, also with the Council, that this matter has been dealt with so effectively at this record pace. This is really a big step in the common market. And to all my colleagues, I ask that we vote in favour of this regulation tomorrow.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, at the beginning, let me thank the rapporteur, Maria Corazza Bildt, and our shadow rapporteur Christel Schaldemose for the work that has been done. We know that data management, the rules by which it is processed, transferred, marketed and stored is one of the most important challenges of the digital economy. The creation of a single non-personal data area within the Union creates new employment opportunities, in particular for start-ups and small businesses, and, at the same time, increases competition in the sector, increasing the final supply for the benefit of consumers.  Furthermore, Mr President, a common legal framework will make it easier for public authorities to exercise supervisory controls to protect citizens and will strengthen the overall data protection framework, alongside the general regulation on the protection of personal data, which is already in force. I believe that the adoption of this regulation represents a further step towards the creation of a European digital single market, which is necessary to compete globally.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Mr President, there have always been many obstacles for movement of data across systems in Europe. Businesses were not able to choose the most cost effective locations for IT resources; it was complicated and it was bureaucratic.  Thanks to this regulation we have improved the mobility of non—personal data and made it possible for professional users to choose and switch service providers while, at the same time, ensuring the security of such data. It shows, once again, that the EU can deliver and can make a difference. Removing data localisation restrictions can make our economy grow by EUR 700 million in 2020. This also means that we treat the freedom of establishment very seriously by allowing companies and public administrations to store and process non—personal data wherever they choose in the EU. This regulation is therefore a small, but very crucial victory, for the citizens and businesses of Europe.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this draft regulation aims to prevent our states from regulating the location of data. It submits us to the Commission's control to find out what data is a matter of the security of the country or not. The Commission, this Commission in the pay of lobbies and cosmopolitan oligarchy, will once again put our states under foreign domination, extra-European in addition! It knows only the coup de force, claiming to want our good and, in the name of good, systematically destroying our sovereignty. Digital technologies are not only technologies of sovereignty, but also of domination. Free competition and unfettered markets are turning our states into digital colonies of foreign multinationals. China is independent, for example, because it has banned foreign companies in this area on its territory. Digital technologies are free cooperation of states, that's all! (The speaker refuses a question "blue card" from Anna Maria Corazza Bildt)

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: – Mr President, I welcome this proposal on the free flow of non—personal data, which is essential for the success of the digital economy. With this in mind, just a few weeks ago, the UK Government issued a notice to companies to start drawing up standard contractual clauses for data transfers in the case of a no—deal Brexit. Just hours ago, at the Conservative Party conference, the British Prime Minister is still talking of a no deal.  I think this is irresponsible. UK companies doing business in Europe in the new data economy we want to encourage would be the hardest hit with a no deal because data from the EU would not be able to flow into the UK until adequacy arrangements were put in place. This can only lead to higher costs and more uncertainty in an area of the economy which has the greatest chance of growth.  Brexit is nothing about the national interest, but everything about the Tory party interest. I don’t want my country to leave the EU, but if it does, it needs to remain part of the single market and customs union for certainty, stability and security.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by We live in a time when we need to increase the strength of the European Union – a force that gives rise to development, and therefore to the well-being of the Member States and their citizens. The free movement of people, capital or services became the foundation of the common market, but 60 years ago and a few decades later, all those who worked for the Community could not have imagined that data would be of such importance for development. Today, we should add the free flow of data to this catalogue of the common market. She is nowadays, in the age of the digital economy, actually a condition for sine qua non development. Development, on the other hand, builds the well-being of the citizens of the European Union. The barriers that have existed on the European market so far are no longer justified. Not only that, they are barriers to the development of European companies, not only digital, but actually all of them that operate in the economy. They are also a barrier to our global competitiveness. That is why, firstly, I support this dossier. Secondly, of course, I warmly congratulate the rapporteur and, thirdly, I believe that we need further solutions of this kind that will deepen the integration of the European Union.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur and our negotiator for their work on this important issue.  The data economy is a sector that is growing and increasingly weighing in our economy. I want to prove that by 2020, in the European Union, more than 30 billion connected machines will be in circulation.  The purpose of this text is to take note of this situation and to define the right balance between two concerns. On the one hand, free movement - in this case, the free movement of non-personal data - and on the other, the protection of the interests of European citizens. In this particular case, of course, we are talking about the protection of personal data.  In the original proposal of the text, there were areas of uncertainty as to the scope of this text and that of the general regulation on the protection of personal data. Also, I am really satisfied with the compromise that has been found on this text. It engraves in stone the obligation to always apply a high level of protection of personal data in situations where the privacy of European citizens is at stake.  This is an issue on which the Union is today the world leader, and I think it is in its best interest to remain so.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: – Mr President, it is always a pleasure to see the Vice—President on the floor – a voice of reason and forward-looking. I would also like to thank the rapporteur for the great work that you are doing. In fact, you have driven it through like a Ferrari, to quote you. I have heard that language being used before. So we are all European here today, and we’ve got the fifth freedom in the EU. I am hoping that this will really allow free movement of non-personal data, which is a cornerstone of the digital single market that the Vice—President of the Commission is pushing so well. This regulation gives a chance to European businesses to actually experience the opportunities and advantages of the digital economy in Europe. A Lithuanian start—up working with data analytics now has the same opportunities to scale up and reach bigger markets, like Germany or France, as a German start—up, for example. We have got some fairness. It has been calculated – we’ve heard EUR 8 billion and I’m hoping it’s more, but we’ll take EUR 8 billion – and it brings an enormous boost to European businesses, especially the ones that are working in an artificial intelligence space. AI is a field where this regulation can really push Europe forward. In the artificial intelligence race with the US, and especially with China, we should really take note and action. We all agree that AI is the future and can create a lot of good, well—paid jobs in Europe. However, we need to invest in research, education and development, and give funding to European companies working in the AI area. These are the key drivers, and it’s crucial for European SMEs and start—ups, which don’t have access to huge streams of data, like big tech companies do – Google or Facebook for example. The free flow of non-personal data regulation gives this opportunity. It unlocks a huge amount of non—personal data, especially from mixed data sets, which have been like a grey zone. It brings legal certainty, which is a business need. AI technology is already here, and it won’t go away. The regulation of the free flow of non-personal data is a great example of such an approach.

name: Sergio Gaetano COFFERATI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Anna Maria Corazza Bildt and the shadow rapporteurs, starting with Christel Schaldemose, worked very quickly and, above all, with extreme sagacity, the subject they had to regulate was not simple, very delicate, complex and they did so in the best possible way. I am very pleased with what solutions and compromises have finally been reached, particularly with regard to the privacy of european citizens' personal data.  The fact that they have guaranteed and recognised that they have this right to priority in relation where there is a link with all the data to a right of priority is something that gives a complete meaning to the work that has been done, it is somewhat at the heart of the proposal, but it also exemplifies its intentions and its final capacity. Finally, I would like to say one thing to the Commissioner, there is a subject concerning privacy in the workplace. The collection of data that takes place there and their use was not a subject to be addressed and resolved in this context, but it is very important that the Commission takes responsibility for it and tackles it quickly.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: – Mr President, despite data being one of the most important assets today for a progressive economy, it is only now we are granting the free movement of non—personal data beyond national borders. To be honest, it took us quite some time. Two years ago what was being discussed was non legislative; a cornerstone of the DSM was put into question. For some, the growth generated by the EU data market, which amounts to 7% per year and up to EUR 84 billion by 2020 was not a good enough reason to grant the free movement of non—personal data within the EU. This is why I would like to congratulate Vice—President Ansip for standing firm behind some of us Members of this House, as well as stakeholders, in delivering a very good proposal. My congratulations goes also to the rapporteur and the Estonian and Bulgarian Presidency for their excellent work. This morning, during the Future of Europe debate, I said something that I want to repeat now: we cannot address people’s concerns and challenges by looking back in time, but only by looking forward. Forward—looking legislation and regulation is what will drive change in Europe and this legislation is one of them – a regulation that will bring innovation to Europe and show that Europe is open for business, for cloud computing and for big data analytics. So stay tuned and watch this space.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, Mr Ansip, the Union's territorial requirements determined by national, regional or local provisions have led to a competitive bias between cloud storage service providers.  These location policies have also compromised the sharing and collaboration capacity of researchers and scientists, losing an innovative potential in Europe. To this do so, I believe that it will be necessary to ensure that there is harmonisation in the minimum security criteria for data hosting systems in all Member States.  On the other hand, the competitive market must safeguard the possibility for citizens to be able to switch providers easily and transparently and to request structured data portability. To this do so, good practices and information requirements should be established for citizens to avoid fraudulent business.  I therefore would like to welcome the rapporteur Anna Corazza Bildt for having succeeded in devoting in the legislation mixed data, which cover personal and non-personal data, and the way in which it is linked to the general data protection regulation for a clear and properly protected right to privacy for European citizens.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Mr. Chairman, the obligation to localise data is incompatible with the idea of a Digital Single Market, so liberalisation proposed by the Commission and supported by the Rapporteur is the only logical move. The aim must be to offer consumers from across the Union better services for less money, which is a direct result of increasing competition due to market liberalisation. I am satisfied that the proposal also offers the possibility of exemption in exceptional situations or when data is needed by public authorities. I also welcome the introduction of a code of conduct in the field of data transfer, but provided that the recommendations it makes are binding and their breach is sanctioned.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, the free processing and movement of data which is not personal is a fact that contributes to the development of trade, because it allows the rapid movement and exploitation of information. However, this development must be placed and examined in the light of whether and to what extent the national sovereignty of a State is infringed. The proposed regulation certainly leaves room for non-flow of information which is not personal but which violates or endangers public safety.  What is also of concern is the fact that, once artificial intelligence is developed, we do not know how it will be used. Finally, we must bear in mind that our main competitor, China, does not allow its country to apply such procedures.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, firstly, allow me to thank Commissioner Ansip and especially my good colleague and friend Anna Maria Corazza Bildt for her good work on this file. Having been involved as a rapporteur in the Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), I know that time and effort and expertise, indeed, is required to bring a file to this level. Well done to Anna Maria and her colleagues. One of the things about the GDPR which was very interesting was that initially people didn’t want it, but it was interesting that when Mark Zuckerberg came here to the European Parliament he said that it was setting a global standard. The same will apply to Anna Maria’s work in the non—personal data sector. Obviously, things are moving at a rapid pace. We do, as Mr Guoga said, have to allow for artificial intelligence to develop, data analytics, big data of all sorts.  I think this is a very balanced proposal and that it will serve the European Union and our citizens and services very well, so well done to you all.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, it is a given that new technologies are evolving. We have cloud computing, bulk data, artificial intelligence and it is obvious that all this contributes to the growth of the economy. That is why we are now talking about 'fifth freedom', which complements the free movement of persons, services, capital and goods.  What measures should be taken in this regard? But I think that the 'four freedoms' also apply, that is to say, that there should be the possibilits of state intervention on grounds of public policy and public security, as this regulation has been shaped by the case-law of the Court of Justice of the European Union. Nothing less, nothing more.  At the same time, it is obvious that the Regulation on the protection of personal data must also apply. I do not agree with having a code of conduct for the control that companies themselves will do. I believe that the case-law of the Court of Justice of the European Union on 'four freedoms' is sufficient to apply to 'fifth freedom'.

name: József NAGY
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European Congratulations, first of all, to the report, Anna Maria, well done. The protection of personal data is always a very sensitive subject, which is why I welcome its success and support the free movement of data within the European Union. I believe that unnecessary and excessive restrictions are not only a violation of many jobs, but also a violation of citizens' freedoms, and I trust that we will continue down this path and that we will also be able to remove geoblocking, that is, the blocking of medial content. This is not only in the interest of tourists, foreign workers, but also of national minorities.

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, this regulation is a key pillar of the digital single market. It will bring benefits and immediate business efficiencies, particularly for SMEs, start-ups and scale—ups. It means that there will be no more need to duplicate IT resources across different Member States, a heavy burden for smaller companies. It will be easier for them to enter new markets and scale up. There will be no more constraints on cross-border scaling of innovative technologies that require data storage.  I believe the proposal will have three important effects: legal certainty on the free flow of data in Europe; a higher level of trust between public authorities; and more competitive EU cloud markets. It will lead us closer to a European common data space, in which data is shared, reused and flows freely. However, we still need to update the rules on public-sector information and encourage businesses to share private-sector data. All these elements are necessary to build a strong European data economy. As we all know, the data economy – including artificial intelligence, which was mentioned many times here today – is nonsense without data. We have to look at the bigger picture. China and global service providers were also mentioned many times today. In China they have huge data sets, they have 1.3 billion images and, of course, it’s much easier for them to create face recognition systems based on artificial intelligence. In the United States they have global service providers. They have Google, Amazon and Facebook. They have huge data sets and they can teach computers. Even when looking at cloud service providers here in Europe, we have to remember that 50% of those services are provided by Amazon, Microsoft and IBM.
