Local and regional authorities, but also NGOs and churches, are taking their responsibility. National governments, instead of thanking those people, are criminalising them and punishing them for doing what any decent human being would do.  Courageous local and regional politicians get punished, like a mayor in Italy who has been put under house arrest for helping refugees. But that is the world on its head. You know what I think colleagues? I think it is the 28 government leaders who should be under house arrest. Maybe we should criminalise them for a criminal failure to act at great human cost.  I don’t need to speak about all the shameful and despicable situations that we are facing, not just on EU territory but also outside the EU’s borders. I think it is deeply, deeply shameful. We are the richest continent in the world and we pretend that we are not able to welcome these people; refugees but also labour migrants.  Parliament has done its homework, and what we have done is we have bridged the political differences across the political groups, which is the responsibility of politicians. The Commission has done its homework. Now I expect the Council next week at the JHA Council to show the same responsibility and finally agree on the asylum package, because that is what it has to do.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I would also like to talk about the Italian mayor who was arrested for facilitating illegal immigration. He comes from a place that is rewritten for how he has managed to receive many migrants. He has integrated them, and he has also managed to create jobs. This win-win model of coexistence between the inhabitants and the refugees built up has been positive for the economy of society as a whole.  I really also wanted to talk about Aquarius and about Proactiva Open Arms and about the criminalisation that is taking place today also for those who save lives, but it is short on time. Unfortunately, since the large influx of refugees into the EU in 2015, we have seen an increasing trend across Europe that Member States are trying in various ways to criminalise aid to refugees and that aid is equated with people smuggling. Then, in 2015, some Member States showed a complete lack of solidarity, both with the refugees and with the other Member States. However, where the States were unable to assume their responsibilities, local and regional authorities took over, and together with civil society organisations, they jointly managed to provide shelter, food, health care and school to the new arrivals – often without any financial support from the national authorities and sometimes the exact opposite.  We Greens therefore believe that it is necessary for municipalities, regions and organisations, which take their humanitarian responsibility for the migrants who come, to be given both legal support and the resources to do so. There are so many good examples to be had from different municipalities in Europe where integration between the original population and the new arrivals works extremely well. Not least in towns with declining populations, the population contribution may be what means that the resort gets the economic boost that it so well needs. For us Greens, it is also completely out of the question that humanitarian aid for refugees should be criminalised. On 5 April this year, Parliament adopted a resolution with guidelines to avoid the very situations that we have seen in Italy today and which several others may wish to follow. We want the Commission to draw up guidelines in line with our resolution.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, five years ago to the day, a boat sank near Lampedusa, killing 368 people: they were Somali, Eritrean, Sudanese. In the process, Italy launched Operation Mare Nostrum. A year later this operation was stopped, italy could not continue it alone. "Triton" has not replaced it, either by its perimeter or by the means implemented. Nearly 20,000 people have died in the Mediterranean since 2014. The number of crossings has now decreased by 90% compared to the peak of 2015, but the number of deaths is increasing proportionally: 1 death for 5 crossings in September (20%!) compared to 1 in 47 in 2017. That's nine deaths a day! And we're not going to block them. The European Union is flouting international law, the law of the sea and the right to asylum, it is a disgrace! It is this inability of the Union and its Member States to fulfil their international obligations that has led NGOs to charter ships to save these men, these women, these children trying to cross the Mediterranean at the risk of their lives. The Aquarius is now the only boat at sea. We must act to get it back to a flag, and I very much hope that it will be French and that all boats that want to save lives can go to sea. No, we must not criminalize NGOs, citizens or elected officials, and I too want to denounce the situation in Domenico Lucano, the mayor of Riace. We must give all those who wish to help the refugees and for that, yes, we must give them direct access to European funds, without unnecessary bureaucracy.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Commission has carried out a very detailed report on all things that are not important or not so important, such as the evidence of the cases, of the problems that this debate has shown. And on the really important issue, namely the Dublin reform, it is a staggering vagueness. They tell us: let us hope that at the end of the year, perhaps next year, certainly before the end of this European parliamentary term, I am not too convinced. You still do not reform Dublin, which is one of the fundamental points, which is an agreement that the Commission itself acknowledges to be outdated, so it is a mockery of those who have seriously denounced it on one side or the other. We have denounced the distortions of this false solidarity and perhaps the episode of this municipality, of this Italian mayor, is a confirmation. What I can tell you is that the tragedy in Lampedusa today would not be repeated because of a courageous decision by the Italian Government, which is to block the ports and thus to put a barrier against the criminal organisations that have exploited the world's poor through the trade in human flesh. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: "blue card" question. I wanted to ask Mr Borghezio why the Italian Government, of which he is a member, did not support the European Parliament's proposal on the Dublin reform, and whether he considers the case of the Ship Diciotti to be a model that Italy can use as an example for Europe, given that, I would remind you, the Minister of the Interior is under judicial investigation for kidnapping.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: , answer to a blue card question. The proposed pseudo-reform certainly did not go in the sense that common sense and, I would say, the reality of the situation dictates. In the meantime, it has also continued because this reform proposed by those who dumped hundreds of thousands of immigrants on Italy in the omertous disinterest of other countries and of the European Union certainly did not lead to optimism and a calm assessment of the proposal. And with regard to the attacks, the criticism of Minister Salvini's work on the Aquarius issue, I would like to say that the European Union and all those who care about the health and safety of the people who relied and no longer rely, thank God, largely on the merchants of death, should make a monument to Minister Salvini to whom a great prize should be awarded as a relevant figure in humanitarian action , because it started the most important operation, that of cutting off the legs of the exploiters of poor people and poor immigrants. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: "blue card" question. –Look, Mr Borghezio, I know how badly to intervene, but I am going to do so because I was on a boat with Mrs Forenza, Mr Urbán and Mr López when Mr Salvini's fascist government did not allow us to dock in a port. And, therefore, I allow myself, as a person, a member of this Parliament, with enough dignity to have been in the Mediterranean, to tell you that the statements you have just made of not allowing the Government to let a humanitarian ship dock by leaving it wandering for several days leave it in tremendous dishonor.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: answer to a "blue card" question. I believe that the honourable Member who addressed these remarks to me, with the usual courtesy and courtesy, does not take proper account of the fact that, with this courageous decision, the Minister has given an important signal to all those who have so far speculated without intervention and without real controls against those who exploit these situations.  We need clarity and a clear distinction between actions of true solidarity and those, and they are many and financed by clear figures such as the great international tycoon and speculator Soros, who have nothing to do with solidarity and love for the people of the Third World.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Mr President, the European Union, the governments, SYRIZA and the New Democracy in Greece have welcomed, promoted and supported the unacceptable European Union-Turkey agreement, which turns the islands into places of double entrapment of refugees and migrants. Their policy is the Dublin Regulation, which lives and reigns, sending refugees to the gates of entry of the European Union, such as Greece. Their task is the growing power of the European border guard, the repression, the fast-track deportations. Their misery is the hotspots of the Moria type, both as a design and as an implementation, followed by new closed centers and third countries-"warehouses" of souls.  European funds, and through local government, support precisely these reactionary agreements and Euro-regulations, feeding NGOs and circuits. That's why neither relief to the refugees nor breath to the islanders can give. On the contrary, all of them are experiencing the consequences of a miserable and dangerous situation, with winter ahead. The hotspots on the islands must be closed here and now, asylum services must be transferred to mainland Greece, refugees and migrants must be quickly transferred to their countries of destination.

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: – Mr President, today we are discussing how to help local and regional authorities, who are the ones facing first of all the mass influx of migrants overflowing communities in southern Europe.  I have witnessed three realities and seen thousands of people being deceived by unscrupulous traffickers. In Lesbos, Greece, I have seen the pain in the faces of many unaccompanied minors and trafficked women and girls; I've seen him in Mineo, Italy, where thousands of immigrants spend months waiting for an asylum application that never comes—like that young mother with her baby "Miracle," whom she called that because she had survived. And I have seen it, Commissioner, in Spain — in my region, Andalusia, in Algeciras — where I have seen the efforts that the mayor and the neighbors carry out together with Salvamento Marítimo, the security forces of the State and the Red Cross, who work tirelessly to save lives and care for the migrants who reach thousands of our shores and Ceuta and Melilla.  That is why I demand greater coordination and distribution of European funds, so that they can help local and regional authorities, who receive and serve immigrants.  We need a common European policy, which leaves no room for the erratic decisions of national governments, which close and open borders as they please and which lose sight of the objective of combating mafias.  Only by cooperating with the countries of origin and transit can we stop the tragedy that shames me as a European. Not all of Africa can fit in Europe, as some want, nor should borders be closed, as others want: the two claims are populist. And I'm not.  I have a heart, but I also have a head, and I ask for political will to solve the migration challenge with the responsibility that citizens ask of us. And I do not want to give populists and nationalists the hammer of immigration, because with it they will destroy Europe and, above all, its foundations and its values.  (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: "blue card" question. "Even if you agree with some of what you've said, Teresa, I think you have to handle the language well. We have talked about the southern regions of Europe being overwhelmed by the arrivals of migrants on our shores. The data says this is the year when fewer immigrants have come in the last five years. In fact, it's just an issue that we think is important. And we have also said that we cannot house the whole of Africa in Europe. Could you tell me the fact of those who have arrived in Spain or those who have arrived in Europe by sea this year?

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: "blue card" response. – Yes, Miguel, I could tell you that more than thirty thousand have arrived in Spain; Miguel, I could tell you that I've been to Algeciras and there are so many, and you know it.  I could tell you that only in Andalusia, in Spain, there are more than eleven thousand unaccompanied minors. There are no centers in Andalusia to accommodate them; there aren't, and we can't have them.  I could tell you that I've been to Lesbos, that I've seen how in Moria they're overcrowded—they're even tempting suicide—and I could tell you Elisabeth, who's from there. I could tell you how I've seen more than two thousand desperate people in Mineo. And since I've seen it in many places, I don't want that, and neither do European citizens.  If that's what you want, for the people of Africa to come here, I want you to be able to live in your countries and for those of us who can really integrate to come.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the memory of the past is indispensable in order to build our future and, just today, our memory goes out to the 368 victims who lost their lives off Lampedusa on 3 October five years ago in an attempt to reach our coasts.  What has changed since then? On 3 October 2018, the Mediterranean continues to be an emergency and integration and inclusion policies are still very hampered. We continue to die in the Mediterranean, in the indifference of those who in recent years have been careful to erect walls and safeguard borders, rather than save human lives, in the complicity of those who have speculated on the skin of the weakest by making Europe believe that it can stop the landings by closing the ports; of those who wrecked Mare Nostrum, the first humanitarian operation in the Mediterranean, strongly desired by the Then Italian Government; of those who have opposed the system of search and rescue at sea through shameful smear campaigns against NGOs engaged in solidarity and the protection of human rights. In addition, there are disparaging campaigns against those who, amid a thousand difficulties, are trying to set up a system of reception and integration. Here I repeat my solidarity with the mayor of Riace, Mimmo Lucano. Local administrators must be supported, it is they who, by offering essential services to migrants, creating opportunities for education and work, develop an environment conducive to their further integration. No more disparaging campaigns against those who work for social cohesion, training the new citizens of tomorrow.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Mr. Chairman, local and regional self-government units are arguably most exposed to the negative consequences of the migration crisis in the Mediterranean. Despite their very limited resources, they have to bear the brunt of other people's missed policies, and are often not consulted at all in the process of making important decisions.  It is not enough to increase financial assistance to local and regional self-government units, which are the first to come under fire, because the migration crisis is not only a financial but also a cultural and security challenge for them. Migration and asylum policy need to see change, and our main advisers in this process need to be our local stakeholders. We have no right to make decisions that significantly affect their lives away from their eyes and without their knowledge.  What is also necessary to do is address the migration crisis away from European shores. We need to step up cooperation with a number of third countries and jointly fight smugglers and stop illegal migration at the beginning. Everything else is mere cosmetics that can only delay but not stop new political turbulence and security challenges in the European Union.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, European immigration and asylum policies are so unsatisfactory because States, which have responsibility for borders and visas, monopolize relations with the Commission to determine immigration policies and the use of the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund. The Commission does not care whether States adequately represent the position of cities and regions, the area in which people live, the level from which services are provided and the integration, person by person, of new Europeans is forged. A demographic, talent and vital energy contribution that our aging continent needs. This wastes available possibilities and resources. That's why many regions and cities we ask here, and in all available forums, to listen to these regions and cities. The Basque lehendakari moved this concern and concrete proposals to President Juncker at his last meeting. The Basque Country will present the SHARE (share) initiative to the Committee of the Regions next week. A concrete mechanism at the state, regional and local levels for the responsibility of reception to be shared according to three parameters: tax revenues, weighing 50%, the population, with 30%, and unemployment, with 20%. We ask for and offer a commitment. We push for a social pact for immigration. We hope that the solidarity we perceive at street level will reach directly to offices located much higher and too sensitive to populist pressure and manipulation of statistics. Please listen to this cry of people's Europe, of proximity, from which you want to build this project by adding from the bottom up. It proposes a much more humane response than we are offering right now.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: – Mr President, the enduring scandal of the European Union's inefficiency in the reception of refugees and asylum seekers has been concentrated for many months in the Mediterranean, where thousands of people have died, where we know that hundreds, thousands will still die.  Local, regional authorities, NGOs and humanitarian initiatives have helped save many lives. The rational, the humanitarian thing, would be to increase budgets and aid to institutions and groups, and a much greater involvement of States working in a network and fighting those who negotiate with despair.  Instead, humanitarian organizations are criminalized, paralyzed and persecuted and prevented from acting. The arrest yesterday of the mayor of Riace makes it clear that the humanitarian emergency is twisted against us and also the emergence of our own responsibility.  If we continue down this path, many will lose their lives and, we, dignity.

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Commission is alarmed by the deficit spending in Italy, I would remind you that there are 5 million of us as absolute poor, but it passes a security law that cuts humanitarian permits, takes away legal certainty from asylum seekers, eliminates funds for municipal reception facilities.  Draghi says there are words that are harmful to businesses, but Salvini's words about the mayor of Riace, arrested for aiding immigration are benevolently ignored. "You are a zero" said the minister of those who saved an entire village from depopulation, integrating refugees and with dwindling funds.  I am not just talking about Italy, arrests and violence against those who facilitate reception and integration are multiplying. Cédric Herrou, Diego Dumont, Mayor Mimmo Lucano, the list is getting longer, Mr Oettinger, and I would like to know whether this alarms you too.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the How long do you need experience to know that the current migration policy is not working? People come to Europe under the guise of a crime by pretending to be distressed at sea, deliberately entering this situation. In severe weather conditions, they also endanger the people who come as rescuers. We know from years of experience that the majority do not want to be integrated here at all. And we are now taking integration measures again until 2027. In fact, the world is holding its head. If we take the example of Australia, let us take the United States. In Australia, everyone who arrives there unannounced is sent back. There are no people smugglers, no one can earn anything from it. We do not need integration measures, we need the repatriation of those who are with us. Otherwise, Europe needs a wall, a fortress of steel ships that will prevent this Europe from continuing to be inundated by foreigners.

name: Innocenzo LEONTINI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the humanitarian emergency, which is still ongoing in the Mediterranean, requires us to reform the common asylum system and, specifically, the Dublin system as soon as possible, in order to alleviate the burden of reception, supported by countries, especially first-port countries such as Italy, for example. It is precisely within these states, particularly in regions such as Sicily from which I come, that local and regional authorities play a major role in the reception of refugees and migrants. We cannot leave mayors and local administrators alone, who do what they can, with the few resources they have at their disposal, but their work must be included in more decisive action both at national level and supported by the European Union. That is why I am not opposed to the idea of granting more to local authorities, within the framework of European funding under the Asylum Fund and within the multiannual financial framework. I believe it is necessary to help the efforts of the Member States, following a shared approach and avoiding supporting different criteria within the different territorial communities. The growth of migratory flows to Europe could last for decades due to the various geopolitical dynamics in the Middle East, North Africa, the Horn of Africa and the continuing situation of poverty in some sub-Saharan regions. In the light of this, and I will end here, I am convinced that the European Parliament's work must be aimed primarily at promoting better management of migratory flows, which is based on solidarity reception, the strengthening of services, but also respect for the law and the maintenance of socio-economic balance within local communities, which are called upon to support the effort of reception and integration.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Mr President, Commissioner, all the figures are there to attest to this: arrivals via the Mediterranean are falling. Of course, they will not stop sharply, especially considering the climate change to come.  So we can try to focus on how to push migrants out of our borders, but the European Union must also work on reception and integration. To do this, local governments must be at the heart of the thinking. The arrival of migrants has, above all, effects at the local level. This is where you have to stay, send school, employ newcomers.  The Challenge of the Union is therefore to support local authorities to turn these arrivals into assets. Budgetary resources exist in the European Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund. They need to be increased, directed towards local authorities and facilitated, because, contrary to what you have indicated, Commissioner, it is not a question of going to the Commission to make it work. It's infinitely more complicated than that.  In this short message, I want to pay tribute to the commitment of local communities, despite the lack of state support. They are the key to the success of integration policies.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, Dublin III has failed – I think everyone admits this – and has turned Greece and Italy into "warehouses" of souls. Thousands of refugees and thousands of illegal immigrants are now trapped there.  What's to be done? To continue the relocation programme first – we have forgotten. This programme was carried out only by 30% by Germany, by 25% by France and by very few other countries. And yet there was a promise to relocate 66,400 refugees from Greece. There are currently 70,000 refugees and illegal immigrants in Greece.  It is obvious that the funds given – and given enough – went to NGOs. And the NGOs were partying and they didn't make the most of these funds, so we're going to have a hard time in Moria. I have denounced this, Mr Oettinger, for a year and a half or two years and I have asked OLAF to intervene in order to have an audit carried out. I'm not going to stop making these complaints.  On the other hand, funds must be given to local and regional government so that they can support these people and accommodate them in real and real conditions, in human conditions.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: – Mr President, in the host crisis in Europe there have been two great heroes: NGOs and volunteers — those who have operated in the Mediterranean — and local authorities. And they seem to be bothering you. We have set aside NGOs in the Mediterranean and now the last thing is the persecution of a mayor like Domenico Lucano, to which we want to send all our solidarity and for which we ask for their immediate release, because it is an example of a person committed to welcoming and should be an example for everyone in Europe. Local authorities are currently at the front line of the reception. If we take the example of the city of Barcelona – my city – the attention has grown this year by 69%, and unaccompanied minors attended, by 87%. It's huge data. And they don't have the instruments. The Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund, Commissioner, at the moment, for example in the case of Spain, is more aimed at financing, for example, Frontex and concertinas than funding and helping local authorities, because that money is not coming. Financial support to local communities, the use of the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund, and also, in the new multiannual financial framework, should therefore be reviewed, new tools for supporting local communities should be introduced.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are having this debate, as has already been mentioned, on 3 October, that is, on the anniversary of the tragic shipwreck of Lampedusa, in which more than 360 people lost their lives. On that occasion we said 'never again', and instead we continue, the European Union continues to do worse and worse. To get to the heart of this debate, with regard to the humanitarian reception of local authorities, I would remind you – as Mrs Miranda said earlier – that when I was on the Open Arms – one of the NGOs so criminalised – together with some of my colleagues, the city of Naples wanted to welcome and keep its port open while instead the Italian Government tweeted 'let's close the ports' and inhibited the intervention of that NGO by saying that the Libyan Coast Guard should intervene. The mayor of Riace was arrested the other day. Riace is a model of reception and integration and instead the mayor is arrested for aiding illegal immigration. A mayor who since 2001 practiced the SPRAR reception and who since 2018 has been on hunger strike for funding cuts by the Interior Ministry. Finally, the immigration and security decree dismantles exactly that SPRAR reception managed by the municipalities in which reception standards were set, a single system of integration. Well, I believe that my country, Italy, is doing worse and worse and I want to renew here my full solidarity with the mayor of Riace. Riace is a model and does not stop.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, from a humanitarian point of view, the situation in the Eastern Mediterranean is admittedly tragic. Despite what is said and supported, Turkey daily sends dozens of illegal immigrants to Greece and these FRODEX, instead of repelling them, leads them safely to the Greek islands where it obliges them to remain under miserable conditions. Because the problem is not only economic, it is mainly a space problem. There's no place for an illegal immigrant to stay there.  And who gave the European Union the right to turn Greece into a permanent camp of unhappy people? If he really cares about these people, he should pressure Turkey to stop pushing them towards Greece; he should pressure Turkey to set up hotspots there and there to allocate the funds for their construction and maintenance.  The war in Syria is over. So there is no argument that we have refugees to avoid war operations and danger. These are illegal immigrants. It should also require that the Dublin III Regulation be reformed and repealed. Finally, if all this is not done, the Greek government must entrust border guard to the police, the coast guard and the armed forces. He should stop playing with the dignity of the Greeks and tolerate becoming a slave and a carpazo-collector of Europe.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: Mr President, there is a great deal of responsibility on local and regional authorities. Apart from all the regular challenges, they often have to ensure that large groups of migrants and refugees are accommodated in a decent way. We have to help them do that. The way in which we ultimately offer this aid will be discussed within the framework of the AMF. But we also have to be honest and realistic. The challenge for many local and regional authorities is partly so great, because in recent years many people have come to Europe who are not actually eligible for asylum. These migrants have not fled war or persecution, but are looking for a better future. The energy and resources needed at local and regional level to provide for these people are ultimately at the expense of the much-needed energy and resources we need to find protection for genuine refugees. So that is where a real challenge lies for the European Union. If we really want to reduce the pressure on regional authorities, we must prevent thousands of people without prospects of asylum from taking the coffers of criminal people smugglers and risking their own lives by trying to get to Europe on a rickety boat. We must ensure that asylum seekers who have been processed actually return to their country of origin. It is absurd that we only manage to actually implement a return decision in 30% of cases. Many colleagues have pointed out that, according to the statistics, the inflow has been reduced and the crisis is actually over. But let us not forget that there are still hundreds of thousands of asylum procedures in Europe at the moment and that the crisis is far from over in that respect. We must overcome this backlog and ensure that the procedures are short, fast and clear. If we succeed, we can really alleviate the challenge facing local and regional authorities.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European A few weeks ago, the UNITED NATIONS High Commissioner for Refugees published a report showing that more than 1,500 people had already died or disappeared in the Mediterranean this year. The figures are dramatic, with only one death for every 42 refugees in 2017 and one death for every 18 refugees in 2018. Traumatised refugees, sometimes horribly tortured in Libya, arrive on Europe's shores and face governments closing borders and ports. Never mind the consequences. I don't think we can stand by and watch these things happen. The common European asylum policy must be at the heart of aid to refugees, humanitarian aid, medical care, psychological care. This requires money and professionals, and that is what the European Asylum Agency could do. It could do something if governments were willing to finally deal with the report that we had already concluded with the Maltese Presidency in the summer of 2017, but nothing has happened since. I think that without changing this situation, the situation will only get worse by the day, and that will be at the expense of local communities, local mayors and regional communities. I think that we need to spend much more money than before on the care, integration, EASO and social inclusion of refugees.

name: Eleni THEOCHAROUS
text: Mr President, I was fortunate enough to go some time ago on a European Parliament mission to the islands of the eastern Aegean, where I saw the tragic situation, the inability of the established states to solve the problem and the inadequate assistance of the European Union.  Today we are discussing the same issue again, but I think we have done little to address it. We are simply giving huge sums of money to Turkey. Solidarity between the Member States of the European Union has not been shown to the southern states that are receiving the greatest burden.  I will refer to the case of the Republic of Cyprus, which I am well aware of, but it seems that its problem is little known in the rest of Europe. Cyprus is a small and remote part of the European Union, semi-resident, with thousands of Cypriots displaced living in refugee settlements. It is outside the limits of the Schengen Treaty. This may have protected it for some time, since Turkey's priority was to cause problems for Greece.  Turkey has not signed the readmission agreement with the Republic of Cyprus, since it does not recognise it, and there has been no reaction on the part of the European Union. That is why I do not believe that everyone who comes to Cyprus is a real refugee. They have no reason to come. However, in the last two years almost daily ships with "refugees" arrive in northwestern Cyprus, on the free track, with the help of traffickers, or normally arrive through the occupied ports and airports and are channeled through the perforated and unattended line of fire in the free areas. An unknown number of refugees drowned on the occupied coast, but we don't have exact figures for them.  I remind you of the immediate threats made by dictator Erdogan, who every now and then declares that he will equate the Muslim population of Cyprus with the Christian one. This poses a huge risk to the Cypriot people. Cyprus cannot be transformed into a new Moria, both because of size and circumstances, nor can it be Islamized.  Therefore, under no circumstances is juncker's proposal to give funds to Cyprus in exchange for the permanent residence of unknown migrants. Cypriots have no proof that they are not racist or xenophobic. We are a peaceful people who respect and help the stranger, the fugitive, the hunted. That is why the European Union must ensure that these people are safely moving to another place.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: – Mr President, today, 3 October, there is five years of the Lampedusa tragedy, a tragedy that left hundreds dead. Five years later and fourteen thousand drowned - it is said fast: fourteen thousand drowned - we continue to debate in this Parliament about the tragedy in the Mediterranean, about the emergency in the Mediterranean. It's just words.  Meanwhile, the only public rescue operation: Mare Nostrum, has disappeared. It doesn't exist anymore. Meanwhile, Salvini's fascist government closes its ports to search and rescue NGOs. In the meantime, the European Union criminalizes these NGOs. It must be said that, despite this criminalization, Mayday Mediterráneo and Proactiva Open Arms are still in the SAR area right now.  And yesterday we learned that this Italian government imprisoned the mayor of Riace: an example of welcome. From here, our solidarity.  All this, with fourteen thousand deaths on our backs. In the meantime, we keep talking, but what it takes is to change our policies, is to turn Europe around, that is enough, that is enough.  I don't know how they can sleep at night.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: . – Mr President, anyone who has visited a hotspot on the coast in Greece or Italy knows very well that these places need solutions and need help. Commissioner Oettinger said that we need a smart and solidarity solution. Commissioner, I think, above all, safe and solidarity. Please don't forget that. We cannot accept thousands of illegal refugees, illegal migrants, because it is neither smart nor safe, and it leads to distrust of citizens, mistrust of the population, who then refuse to help even those who need this help urgently, and it is refugees who are fleeing war, from political, religious oppression, and people simply do not have confidence. So we need a solution that is safe and compassionate.  I have visited Lesvos personally and I want to appreciate the work of the mayor of Mytiléné, who is facing enormous pressure from other and new refugees coming to the island. The talk we're having here isn't going to help anybody right now, and I feel completely helpless. That is why I initiated an activity with the Czech Government for the Czech Republic to accept from Greece 50 unaccompanied children, underage children in need of this assistance. I believe that the Czech Republic will offer this solidarity assistance. Colleagues, a solution that is supposed to be compassionate and safe, will ultimately help these local authorities as well.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, again a umpteenth debate in the European Parliament on the humanitarian emergency in the Mediterranean, only this time we are not talking about the tragedy, that balance of the dead of which five years are now commemorated, of the great death in Lampedusa. No. We are simply talking about how to help, how to support local and regional authorities, which are giving theirs on the first front of response to the absence, failure of the European Union and, above all, to the shame of the behaviour of some governments of Member States installed in panic mode. That is why we have an obligation to talk about how to establish a chapter in the Multiannual Financial Framework to help local and regional corporations. How to coordinate them, how to choose best practices among those local authorities. Like that of the mayor of Riace, infamously imprisoned — and which deserves the solidarity of this European Parliament — exactly for giving a humanitarian response at a necessary time. We are also talking about how to help local corporations maintain integration, education, social assistance, first response, even health, to this tragedy. But above all, we are talking about this showing that we will take mitigation measures as long as the States do not decide to accept the European law they signed in the Lisbon Treaty, with integrated management of external borders and with solidarity and shared responsibility in the care of migrants and asylum seekers and asylum seekers. But what this makes clear is that local and regional authorities tell us that citizens are way ahead of their governments in responding to the humanitarian emergency.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: – Mr President, indifference is killing 14,000 in the last five years alone. But indifference has active accomplices. The policies adopted by the European Council, which attack the weakest, while fueling fear and the arms industry, are the fuel of this complicity.  The coordinator of Aquarius told Le Monde yesterday that the biggest threats to migrants at sea are no longer the winds or the big waves. The biggest threats are policies. There's no other way to say it. The indifference we live in is criminal. We must help resolve conflicts. We must put our lives ahead of the arms business and a real policy of cooperation must be. But here and now, we must stop more people from dying in the Mediterranean. We have to stop the criminalization of those who save. This week, citizens of Portugal launched a petition for the Government Portuguese to award the national flag to Aquarius. It's not just a gesture. It is what it takes to begin to reverse the path and rescue humanity. I sincerely hope that the government of my country will no longer be one to turn its back. Commissioner, the European Union was once awarded the Nobel Peace Prize. Isn't it time to return it?

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there is an urgent need for the European Union to increase its support for local and regional authorities on the issue of migrants. As rapporteur for the report on the social and working inclusion of refugees adopted here in July 2016, I had stressed the inadequacy of the funds available and the need for additional resources to provide local authorities, trade unions, businesses, civil society, with direct financial support for projects in this field. This is a concept that I reiterated in my opinion in the Committee on Employment on the interim report of the multiannual budget and also in the new European Social Fund Plus, on which I have tabled amendments to directly finance projects in the field of migrant inclusion, developed by cities and local organisations. There are mayors in Italy who today are required to have a mission that is impossible to carry out without adequate instruments. I am thinking of my friend the Mayor of Ventimiglia, Enrico Ioculano, in addition to the case of the Mayor of Riace, Mimmo Lucano, whose legal case was shamefully exploited by Matteo Salvini, at a time when he wants to cancel the SPRAR, European excellence for integration, with the cynical aim of gaining consensus by striking Europe, blaming Europe for every problem. We react together by supporting our local administrators.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, in view of the lack of solidarity in some Member States and in the face of our inability to reform the Dublin System, local and regional authorities have often taken the lead in the reception and integration of immigrant refugees seeking protection within the European Union.  In my country, Portugal too, many municipalities have been an example of solidarity and precursors of good practice in the reception of asylum seekers and a region in particular, the Autonomous Region of Madeira, currently faces significant budgetary constraints when dealing with a humanitarian emergency which, while crossing the borders of the Mediterranean, we cannot ignore in this regard the thousands of Portuguese and Portuguese immigrants fleeing the catastrophe of the economic and humanitarian situation in Venezuela. The European Union needs to support the municipalities and regions that are at the forefront of migration management with more direct funding, more training and more technical support to increase cooperation structures and address the management of asylum applications, as well as possible social tensions and increased spending on the integration of these people into education , in employment and housing.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, you were talking about humanity. Humanity is the one that has lacked Europe in Lampedusa, in Ceuta, in the Alborán Sea, which has been lacking in Idomení, which has been lacking in Lesbos, in Piraeus, in Calais. Europe's shame, an agreement of shame with Turkey.  We need more humanity, not words. We've been talking for many years.  People arrive on a flight through life. States have failed, they have not taken care of them; what they have done is put fences and walls, and it is the local authorities who have to give them food, housing, schools, medicines... for humanity, for that humanity, as the mayor of Riace has done, saving lives and being at the side of those who suffer.  And that is why European funds must have the right destination, which is why our group has tabled amendments to the future programme of the European Social Fund, amendments so that those who receive migrants can directly manage that house, that food, that home, that school and those possibilities of living on the flight for life.  Today, in the Mediterranean, there are few boats left, and those who left have thrown them out, and the European Union has also thrown them out with its silence, as when we wrote to it from there and they did not have the decency to answer us because Italy did not allow us to dock the Open Arms.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: – Mr President, 17 088 deaths in the Mediterranean since 2014, 1 741 this year alone, conservative figures. It is the xenophobic and exploitative, selective and inhumane nature of THE EU's migration policies that determine the criminal dimension of this reality. Options that have limited rescue and rescue operations, either by conditioning the operation of coastguards in Member States or on other vessels directly or indirectly involved in such operations. The denial of docking for the landing of people rescued from the sea represents a serious violation of international conventions and the Law of the Sea. The dramatic situation in the Mediterranean is inextnal to a migration policy based on the concept of "EU-fortress" that externalises borders and concludes agreements with third countries for the detention and expulsion of migrants and refugees. Silent death in the Mediterranean or hell in Libya, this is the reality that the EU imposes on thousands of people seeking refuge and that history, sooner than later, will try to judge.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I am aware of the legal framework and also of the basis for this debate. This is supposed to be a discussion about supporting local and regional authorities, on the other hand, I have to say that the Real Mediterranean is our black conscience. It is such a burial ground for Europe and there is no doubt that we should urgently do something about it. I noted a report a few days ago that one refugee boat had received no assistance at all for more than a full day, and several dozen of them, including children, had died. That finding really tears my heart apart.  I have listened with interest to the statements made by both the Council and the Commission, and I would really like to ask whether the Commissioner and the Council are convinced that local and regional authorities are receiving sufficient assistance from the European Union in language integration, in the school needs of these people, their social and health needs. This really requires a high level of coordination with these local and regional authorities, and I still quite doubt the European Union's support.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: – Mr President, in the area of the reception and integration of immigrants, some cities and sub-state governments have fortunately taught a lesson to some, not all, but to many governments of Member States. Solidarity lesson, but also lesson in effectiveness. In Catalonia, for example, we made the largest demonstration in Europe last year in favour of hosting refugees. "Casa nostra é casa vostra" (Our house is your house), we told them. But the refugees did not arrive in our cities, because the Spanish government did not meet their commitments. More recently, the Government of Catalonia has offered its ports for the disembarkation of refugees, and right now, together with the town halls, an important effort is being made to welcome and integrate underage and unaccompanied immigrants, who pose a very serious problem. In the face of these efforts, Commissioner, I believe that it is necessary and right for local and sub-state authorities to be able to directly access European funds on asylum and the integration of the people who come to live with us.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, people crossing the Mediterranean to seek safety in Europe continue to die in horrific circumstances. Those in the front line who do crucial humanitarian work are for the most part ordinary citizens. Many NGOs, such as Care4Calais, the refugee support platform in Belgium, and SOS Méditerranée are amazing examples of how citizens can save lives. Despite the appalling situation that refugees and migrants face, humanitarian relief is still not being treated as a priority. I am proud that my political group has proposed to give the Sakharov Prize to the NGOs saving lives in the Mediterranean. It’s important for this Parliament to acknowledge their crucial contribution and awarding them this prize would force the EU and Member States to take a hard look at themselves and recognise that they are failing to uphold their own values and fulfil their international obligations. The very worrying political situation at national level in several countries, and in particular Italy, makes it all the more necessary to support regional and local authorities who need to fill in for the state’s failure. It’s our common responsibility as Europeans to urgently address this humanitarian crisis and to open safe and legal migration paths to Europe.

name: Julie WARD
text: Mr. The Commission. Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she I have listened very carefully to your speeches with great respect and I note a very broad and diverse position here in the House. Firstly, we are trying to help with the budgetary framework that we have, with our limited resources – we only have 1% of the European national product in the European budget, 49% are in the Member States, regions and municipalities. We are responsible for one-fiftieth of the time. Let us try to help where new tasks arise, within the framework of limited flexibility. For the past three years, we have tried to free up funds for municipalities, regions and Member States that are particularly affected by the migration task. We don't do anything that can. Our resources are limited. Secondly, our first partner is the Member State, not the municipality. That is a principle of Europe. We work with the 28 Member States, they work with the municipalities. In terms of ESF and cohesion, we work with the regions, and they work with local authorities. We trust the Member States. We can use OLAF if we have reasonable grounds for suspicion of abuse, misuse or corruption. But our principle must be: basic confidence in the proper use of funds by the governments and administrations of our Member States. The municipalities know them even better than we do. Brussels cannot know the commune better in southern Spain, in Italy, than the governments in Madrid or Rome. Nevertheless, we are grateful for all the hints. But what is clear is that debates that have to be conducted in national politics, or missteps in national politics, are not our saied. We are not the headteachers for national elections and developments thereafter. I do not want to go into which Member States I mean. This is about rule of law, we intervene when we can. And if there was a relatively broad Italian debate in the House this evening, it must first and foremost be held in Rome. As a Member of the European People's Party ( CHRISTIAN Democrats), I wonder whether Berlusconi has failed? And I ask the Social Democrats whether the Social Democrats in Italy have not done enough too, and that is why the development has come as it has come? We are making an effort, our resources are limited. In the next budgetary framework, if this is adopted in the House, we will have more resources. We want to significantly increase funding for migration and we want to look after refugees by 2025, because they are all born. For me, the debate is far too much directed into the present and the past. Over the next decade, we will have refugees who are now 8, 10, 12, 14 years old, living in Mali, Congo, Niger, Nigeria. We must give them a perspective in the interests of a fair partnership. And it cannot just consist – and I quote – of a 'fortress of steel and ships' in the Mediterranean. I would like to make an explicit commitment to this: Europe must comply at all levels with the obligations of international law, the law of the sea, international law, the Geneva Convention on Refugees, the Convention on Human Rights, which we have signed, not only in Sunday speeches, but also every day in operational practice. Or– let us discuss it: if someone in European politics wants to cancel these international obligations, he should say it here and not break the rules in daily practice, as is increasingly being tried in the grey area or at least publicly announced. I believe that an ethos, a code, is crucial here. Do we stick to the commitments we have signed, yes or no? Platforms outside the EU: It was the European Council in June. Egypt, Morocco: You don't want to. Our diplomats are everywhere. So far, there is no state, no government, neither in the Maghreb nor in the Sahel, nor in the sub-Saharan region, which are willing or even interested in setting up centres for people in need. We are doing everything we can to further question this, but so far it has been an illusion rather than a practical solution. We may put pressure on Turkey. Greetings God, I just need that! Sorry, Erdogan is not a guy who responds constructively to pressure. Where we have refugee camps, give us money, the second tranche is being negotiated in the Council and Parliament these days to finance 1.2 million people a decent life, shelter, cold, heat, electricity, clothing, food, and for 300 000 children 8000 teachers for basic education. This could be expanded in Jordan, Lebanon and Morocco. Are we prepared to invest significantly more billions in addition to the six billion now? This could only be done either by the Member States giving us more money or by agricultural or cohesion funds. I am open to it. Are we prepared to spend money on human dignity instead of the bypass and direct aid per hectare for more people in neighbouring Africa? The second tranche of three billion is already very, very difficult for all of us – the Member States and the EU. Will we still learn the art of sharing? Do we want it? This will have to be discussed as an example for the next budgetary framework. OLAF, I offer this, is an independent authority within the European Commission. I am not authorized to issue instructions. However, if you have any indications of misuse of funds and OLAF, or if I learn and continue: assume that OLAF will then investigate every case and investigate misuse of European funds accordingly and also achieve a consistent and fair result. We should promote local authorities and not give frontex money: not either-or, as well. We need support for the external border protection of the countries most affected, Bulgaria, Malta, Cyprus, Greece, Italy and Spain through Frontex, and yet the financial strength to give enough money to the main local authorities through their Member States and their governments. I can assure you that the Commission will do everything possible to support this, within the limits of our legal and budgetary capabilities, where new tasks arise – for integration, for legal review, and also for repatriation.

name: Julie WARD
text: President—in—Office of the Council. – Mr President, in June the European Council underlined, and confirmed at its meeting in Salzburg, that, in addition to a strong internal dimension of migration policy, a reinforced focus on effective external border protection, the elimination of smugglers’ business models and stronger cooperation with third countries is greatly needed. We believe that, in order to find sustainable solutions to all pending questions, we need to continue our work on the basis of such a comprehensive approach. I can assure you that the Austrian Presidency is working hard on all strands of the migration agenda – external borders as well as internal and external policies in parallel – and will do its utmost to achieve progress on all these strands. I also want to thank the Commissioner for his thoughts and to thank Members for this fruitful discussion.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The debate on this point is closed. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. On occasions of tragedies in the Mediterranean and painful anniversaries, such as the recurring one on 3 October, in which the 368 deaths of the Lampedusa shipwreck are commemorated, the same issue has been discussed several times, and there has been a number of outrages for the victims of the sea and for the traffickers of death, and the European Union has repeatedly announced measures and actions , but nothing has changed. In the Mediterranean, people continue to die and the main burdens continue to fall on the countries of first port to save and welcome. Since the beginning of 2018, the more than 80 thousand migrants who have arrived in Europe, through mediterranean routes, have been mainly welcomed by Italy, Spain and Greece. In order to address the critical issues of migration, the Resources of the European Union, which should help to support the action of the regional and local authorities of my country, represent crumbs in relation to the national resources used. In the European management of flows, there are disunity and selfishness on the part of the Member States, which disregard the principles of solidarity, of a fair distribution of responsibilities, including financial responsibilities, enshrined in the Treaties and which paralyse the reform of the common European asylum system, which should, on the contrary, apply those same principles.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. – Today's debate, initiated by the left and liberals, is their latest manifestation of a pair of migrants trying to put pressure back on Member States that oppose mandatory quotas. The left-wingers claim that the local authorities of the Member States agree and support the compulsory introduction of migrants into their settlements, and that the only obstacle to this is the governments of the Member States, which is why they are demanding access to the appropriate funding instruments for these authorities so that they can implement the introductions. I would like to draw the attention of left-wing and liberal Members to the fact that the municipalities of more than 2 000 Hungarian municipalities have taken a decision against forced resettlement in Hungary only. Furthermore, I would remind my fellow Members that the solution is not to increase the funding of municipalities for migrant resettlement, because illegal migration must not be 'managed', but stopped. No mandatory resettlement quota of any kind would be able to alleviate or resolve the migration crisis, but on the contrary, in the hope of distribution, more and more migrants would make their way to Europe. A similar pull factor is represented by NGO vessels "rescue" migrants in the Mediterranean and then transported to Europe, which only strengthen the business model of people smugglers and must be put to an end. Eu funds should be used for more effective border surveillance and to address the roots of the migration crisis, so that migrants do not unnecessarily risk their own lives and that of their children.

name: Czesław HOC
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – We are now witnessing the dramatic situation in southern Europe, particularly in the Mediterranean. The unprecedented influx of migrants into the EU in a month is expected to intensify rather than weaken. It is already a kind of people smuggling, according to many experts more profitable than drug trafficking! It is high time to call on the European Commission and all Member States to work together to help where these problems arise: at their source, mainly in the territories of African and Arab countries. Only such actions have the potential to have a positive effect, to ensure stability in areas at risk of conflict and extreme poverty, which is what most often forces thousands of people to migrate to Europe.  Decades of experience and observation of countries where a significant number of immigrants have settled often show very serious problems with their assimilation and inclusion in European communities. Let us remember that integration without assimilation is pure utopia and wishful thinking! Often, instead of assimilation, we see radicalisation and acts of terror, as we have seen so many times in recent years.  To sum up, let us act together, in solidarity but very prudently, with a particular focus on helping and resolving conflicts at their source, rather than relying blindly on mechanisms such as forced relocation.

name: Dietmar KÖSTER
text: Writing. The situation in the Mediterranean is intolerable. Private maritime rescue organisations fighting the humanitarian disaster are not supported, but criminalised. Among other things, "Sea-Watch" and "Mission Lifeline" are not allowed to save lives, even though they would be ready at any time. A reconnaissance plane and a sea rescue ship are illegally detained by the Maltese authorities, and a captain has been charged in court. At the same time, people are drowning in the Mediterranean. In order to symbolically signal support, the S&D Group has therefore proposed the maritime rescue organisations for the Sakharov Prize. Europe must finally turn its back. Civil sea rescue must be supported rather than hindered. We must not continue to conclude unfair migration deals, deport refugees to non-safe countries and set up camps within and outside Europe. Instead, the Dublin Regulation must finally be adopted by the Council, in accordance with the European Parliament's decision. Legal and safe routes of escape and access to Europe must be created and the fundamental right to asylum must be strengthened. The latter must not be undermined further and further. And we must immediately launch a civil sea rescue programme under the leadership of the EU.  We must not continue to deny our humanitarian responsibility. It is time to stand up for a human rights-based and sustainable refugee policy in Europe. Only in this way can we show that European values are more than templates for Sunday speeches and that they also apply to people outside the EU.

name: Louis-Joseph MANSCOUR
text: In writing. So far many Member States have been unable to manage migration flows at the gates of our common space. Faced with their passivity, their inaction and even their denial of what constitutes a genuine humanitarian emergency, the Commission must find effective solutions, in line with our values.  This can result in the implementation of a budget for regional communities to help them manage the reception and integration of migrants. The development of such a mechanism would not only respond to the principle of subsidiarity but would also enable the effectiveness and pragmatism of combating xenophobia and populism. I am therefore in favour of the support of local and regional public authorities, as long as it guarantees the fundamental rights of migrants and allows us to implement an orderly, safe and respectful management of migration.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Writing. I am very grateful to the Members who have asked this question. It touches on an important aspect which, unfortunately, is always overlooked in the public debate on migration and refugees. The discussion is mostly focused on symbolic activities. Prejudices are everywhere. The further away from what is happening, the more distorted they are. Such misinformation is, for example, that people in those regions where the refugees first enter European soil would be hostile and dismissive. I was able to convince myself personally on the spot that there is great empathy and helpfulness. The problem, however, is that people, most of whom are not among the wealthy, are often overwhelmed. It is therefore essential to strengthen local and regional authorities and civil society structures in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity. I have often got the impression that European funds are more likely to be stuck in the capitals. Improving aid on the ground would also help to ensure more efficient management of further operations. Local overcrowding often also leads to undesirable reactions and calls in actors who do not necessarily act in the interests of those affected. The European level is therefore called upon and should have acted earlier.

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: Written. It is extremely important to prevent further deaths in the Mediterranean, but that does not mean that those in need must be brought to Europe. The best support the EU can provide to authorities affected so far by illegal migration is to ensure that the flow of migrants is regulated from outside the EU. We know that the majority of migrants crossing the Mediterranean are economic migrants, not refugees or those in need of protection. When looking for work and income, it is very good to apply for a work permit through a country's mission, i.e. in the applicant's home country. The hard part seems to be for many politicians to realise that this is what legal migration is and the way that our voters and citizens once instructed us to manage. The smaller part that really needs protection should of course get it, but for them it is secondary where this protection is provided. We should – in cooperation with the UN and unhcr – look more closely at Australia's model of preventing deaths and illegal migration in the Mediterranean. If only the will exists, adapting this model to European and African conditions will save lives and be part of a long-term solution to many of the problems we see today.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on combating customs fraud and protecting the EU's own resources (2018/2747(SDR)).

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Mr. The Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Minister for the Presidents of the Council, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteurs for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I am grateful that Parliament is emphasising this issue this evening, thereby supporting the work of the Commission and OLAF and other Commission services. We take the fight against fraud seriously, we take the protection of the European budget seriously. This applies to the expenditure side, but it also applies to the revenue side. On both sides we have a lot to defend, lose and protect. According to settled case-law, Member States must compensate for the financial losses if they make mistakes in the collection of own resources. This also applies to interest on late payments, if they are incurred. And if the Member States do not fulfil their obligations, we are obliged to take legal action against the Member States. OLAF has repeatedly referred to the United Kingdom in recent years, warning it that no effective measures were taken until October last year to stop customs fraud – the import ation of textiles and footwear from the People's Republic of China, which have been undervalued, which have not been sufficiently represented in their material value. The failure has resulted in losses in own funds of around EUR 2.7 billion. Under current budgetary law, the UK would be entitled to 20% of this for administrative expenditure and surveys, but 80% would be the European budget. After our discussions and admonitions did not initially lead to any change, we launched infringement proceedings against the United Kingdom in March 2018. To put it bluntly, this has nothing to do with Brexit. It is our duty, and we are doing the same with other Member States. We must attach great importance to the Member States setting the correct value for imports and imposing the appropriate customs duties on them. Where this does not happen, no matter which of the 28 Member States, we take action, we must take action and we must also bring this to appropriate procedures. The United Kingdom has denied being responsible and has refused to pay the corresponding sums – I mentioned the EUR 2.7 billion. That is why, on 24 September this year, the Commission decided to take the procedure to the next level and to adopt and send a reasoned opinion. We exercise a supervisory role in the management of own resources in accordance with the relevant provisions of the EU's own resources system as the Commission. To this end, we also carry out regular checks in the Member States. This year alone, we are carrying out 16 checks related to undervaluations of imports. We regularly base OLAF reports on taking appropriate follow-ups and measures. We also coordinate with OLAF on a regular basis in this regard. As the Commission, we are determined to ensure the correct implementation of the EU Customs Code regulations and rules of the package, in close cooperation with the Member States and industry. We are currently working with the Member States on a strategy on how best to monitor, assess and verify the effectiveness of coherence and in which areas of the Union Customs Code a first round of evaluation measures should be carried out. With regard to Parliament's request that the Commission submit its proposals for a definitive VAT system in order to avoid losses in tax revenues in the EU and the Member States, we would point out that the Commission has now taken up your demands and adopted all the relevant proposals. We have also taken a number of initiatives to combat VAT fraud. In July, the Commission adopted a proposal for a directive on the fight against fraud against the EU's financial interests. This is a serious VAT fraud, which also falls within the mandate of the future European Public Prosecutor's Office. In November last year, the Commission proposed an automatic exchange of information between importing Member States and the member states of destination of the goods purchased for imports under customs procedure 42. I am grateful that the proposal was adopted yesterday and that the Council has thus created this basis. The new legal text explicitly addresses important aspects of cross-border fraud in the internal market, such as missing trader VAT fraud. As far as the Commission and our European information systems are concerned, we are participating through our funding programmes for the common and also the national components, because it remains a national main competence. All these measures and others will significantly strengthen the capacity of the Commission and also the national authorities to fight fraud and thus to protect the European budget. These acts are in line with your expectations and those of the European Court of Auditors. In this context, we are grateful that the number of Member States participating in the European Public Prosecutor's Office has risen to a high level, and we appeal to those who are not yet involved to join in. Finally, the fight against customs fraud, and thus the protection of the European budget and its revenue side, is of the utmost importance to us. Inefficient or incorrect enforcement of customs legislation and a lack of customs controls, there is a risk that the competitiveness of the European Union, and hence the foundations of our European programmes, could be damaged. If, as is happening here now, we take action against a Member State, it is intended to protect the financial interests of all Member States and, therefore, of our taxpayers. This is to prevent other Member States and their taxpayers from having to pay for the failures of a Member State. It is about fairness between the Member States and therefore the European citizens in all the Member States. The recent undervaluation case in the United Kingdom has shown that fraudsters without effective customs controls can bring the European budget by considerable sums, but we urgently need them for our tasks on a daily basis. That is why we have acted consistently, thoroughly and decisively and reacted, and we will bring the case to court as soon as possible, if necessary, so that we can implement the corresponding amounts. I am grateful to you. With your debate and your catalogue of demands, you are supporting the work of the Commission. We are happy to report to you step by step on the further progress in the coming weeks.

name: Ingeborg GRÄSSLE
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. Commissioner, thank you for your statement. I hear the words well, but I lack faith. I do not believe because the other side of this House, the Council – the Member States – to which this message is actually addressed, is not present. Member States have exclusive competence to implement EU competences in this area. That is why it is extremely regrettable that the Member States did not consider it necessary to take part in this debate. 14% of the EU budget is financed by customs duties. In other words, it is not a trivial matter. And that is why it would be necessary for us to sit down and think about how to make things better. We hear that the case of the United Kingdom is not an isolated case, that we see what we see in the United Kingdom in many Member States. If that were the case, it would be extremely regrettable. There are no uniform customs controls. This gives fraudsters the opportunity to choose the weakest link in the chain when importing goods into the EU. A popular occasion for risk analysis. This is, of course, how OLAF catches the problematic cases. We believe that there are major shortcomings in the customs regulatory framework – we are in good company with the European Court of Auditors here – and that there are insufficient financial incentives for Member States to carry out customs checks. Here, too, it would be good if we could resolve this issue. That is why the demands we are making are clear, and they are also included in our resolution, namely the harmonisation and standardisation of customs controls in the Member States, uniform sanctions in all Member States in the event of customs fraud. We want a single VAT system; that would be a colossal relief. And we want the powers of national customs authorities to be transferred to the EU level for a uniform approach at all EU border crossing points. This is a controversial paragraph, and there will also be a split vote on this tomorrow. That is why I would urge my fellow Members here to vote in favour of this request in the resolution.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, the truth is that I thank you, Mr Oettinger, for at least debating, albeit with no suddenness and alevosía, VAT as our own resource of the Union. And we claim it here once again.  And we know, through the Court of Auditors, that at least , since the 2015 report, Member States lose around EUR 50 billion annually in relation to VAT fraud.  And while tonight it is true that the issue of UK-related and fraud, which can reach between two thousand and three billion, apart from duties not levied by textiles, textiles and footwear imported from China, is not the fundamental element — I even believe that the Commons have realized that , even if they leave Brexit, the problem will no longer just be European fraud, but can result in fraud even to the UK Treasury itself; and it is good that you have learned—however, we absolutely need the Commission to take action on the matter.  I still remember the customs and authorities of the port of Hamburg who recognized the difficulties they had in order to combat this type of fraud, which comes from import from distant third countries, but which, severing in some port, manages to reach our large macroports and manages to pass through the customs filters.  That is where we are asking for this harmonisation of customs controls, that it does not take ten years to recover the funds and, finally, that the Member States , all of them – also participate in European taxation and that the Commission transfer national customs responsibilities to the European Union.  We support you on that, Mr. Oettinger. You're brave for it.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. The fight against customs fraud is a struggle to guarantee financial resources for the EU budget. This is important and efforts to combat these crimes must be encouraged, but... Yes, it is "but". Any such action to curb this practice is the right thing to do, so that it is limited to that. I have the impression that we are going beyond what we should accept. The EU legal framework for customs infringements with sanctions, the unification of sanctions, the bringing of customs duties from national level to the Level of the European Union, or the supervision of all the customs administrations of the Member States is in fact a step towards the creation of a federalist Europe. This is too much centralisation at Brussels level. Thus, by condemning all kinds of customs fraud and supporting the eradication of them, it is difficult to understand why such far-reaching proposals are included in this project.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, this evening we are debating the very serious issue of customs and VAT fraud relating to Chinese textiles and shoes imported into the EU through the UK. The European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) has calculated a loss to the EU own resources budget of EUR 2 billion in terms of lost customs duties between 2013 and 2016.  The UK’s wilfully ignorant response to the EU’s request to intervene in this tax fraud has meant the loss of this vast sum, I regret to say, and it’s an indication of poor cooperation by the UK government as is the UK’s refusal to support the creation of a European public prosecutor.  At a time when the UK is suggesting that, after Brexit, we should collect customs due for the whole of the EU, this sets a worrying precedent. It clearly undermines trust in the strength of the UK customs system and suggests that rather than maximum facilitation and trusted traders, we need to get the basics of customs control right. I’m sure that British tax customs officials at Her Majesty’s Revenue and Customs (HMRC) are as professional as ever, but I fear that, in spite of what the Commissioner said, there may be a Brexit connection here, in that there is a suggestion that the political masters of the tax policy in the UK may be using negotiation over this fraud as a bargaining chip in the it negotiations.  The UK government announced last week that it expects to have respect in the EU. Perhaps that government should respect our neighbours by supporting the process of reclaiming money through lost customs fraud and make the necessary changes to stop organised criminals from cheating the system.

name: Younous OMARJEE
