text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, Commissioner, you are here to tell us that, for the Commission, the fight against customs fraud is a priority. All right, but what are you really waiting for to tackle the tobacco industry, which feeds the parallel market and causes European states to lose more than EUR 10 billion every year?  How can we accept that billions are being lost in this way, when the European Union is constantly calling for unsustainable budgetary efforts for the peoples of Europe? In fact, the question is: What are you waiting for to really attack the tobacco lobby? The reality, the sad reality, I fear, is that, even in the fight against customs fraud, you remain tied up with the tobacco lobby, to whom you have entrusted essential tasks in tracing cigarettes, even then, and you know, that cigarettes sold on the parallel market come straight out of their factories and promote smuggling. If you are sincere in your commitment to combating customs fraud, put the tobacco directive in line with the WHO protocol without delay and permanently cut off all these toxic goods.

name: Jonathan BULLOCK
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, what we are discussing here is a non-legislative, non—binding resolution, the title of which sounds rather innocuous. The reality, of course, is that this resolution is a patchwork of ideas, seeking to take away power from elected governments and hand it to unaccountable institutions in Brussels. For example, the resolution calls for an EU legal framework for customs infringements and sanctions, in order to harmonise the way VAT is collected and paid across the EU and to transfer customs responsibilities from national authorities to an EU level. But at the heart of this, of course, is an attack on the UK. The EU is seeking to take infringement procedures against the UK based on some rather dodgy and conflicting figures and dates amounting to EUR 2.9 billion. Fraud is a widespread problem in the UK, and no doubt we are doing our best to make sure importers pay the correct duties, but this is about squeezing every penny from the UK to fill the EU’s coffers before Brexit. Theresa May has already agreed to hand over EUR 40 billion to the EU as a penalty for leaving, but the EU is now inventing any trumped—up reason to come after the UK. I urge you to reject this resolution and let due process take its course without this obvious political interference.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue—card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: "blue card" question. – I just wanted to ask you if you are aware that there has been a debate in the House of Commons in which precisely this fraud has been discussed and in which your British counterparts in that House have discovered that on the day when, if this is the case, there will be Brexit, you will have it, because VAT fraud will affect Your Majesty's Treasury. Are you aware of that?

name: Jonathan BULLOCK
text: blue-card answer. – No, I’m afraid the British Government rejects this. What this is obviously doing is raising something when Brexit is happening; it’s a way of the EU chasing money of us. This doesn’t work; this organisation doesn’t work. It’s a disgrace that we are being punished simply because we have voted to leave, and it’s not surprising that even British Government ministers now are saying that this is like the Soviet Union. It’s a disgrace.

name: Petri SARVAMAA
text: – Mr President, customs duties as traditional own resources make up a significant share of the EU budget, hence the consequences of large-scale fraud can be devastating. The fraud case in the United Kingdom brought exceptional sums to our awareness, and new cases have shown that there is a pattern of deficiencies in our customs system, particularly in our ability to fight against fraud. The system not being harmonised leaves a variety of tempting options for criminals. They get to choose the weakest link. We indeed need a more harmonised administrative procedure and sanctions to the whole of the Union. Treatment should be the same throughout the EU. As long as we don’t have a harmonised system, the crooks continue to exploit the weaknesses.  Regarding the UK case and the EUR 2.7 billion to be recovered, this has to be taken care of efficiently and effectively. I warmly welcome the Commission’s infringement procedure and expect it will execute the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) recommendations fully and swiftly.  On top of recovering all of the fraudulently uncollected EU revenue, we need to prevent this from happening again. We have to break the pattern and dissolve the deficiencies. I expect the Commission and the Member States to step up and do everything in their power to enhance our framework for the fight against fraud in this regard. But, having said what I have just said, I cannot but wonder why it is that almost every time we discuss budgetary control issues – protecting European taxpayers’ money – we do it close to midnight. It’s a shame, and I don’t think it’s just a coincidence.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Perhaps everyone should turn to their political groups on this, since the debates are decided by the bureaus. But it is an invitation, of course, to address all the group chairmen.

name: Arndt KOHN
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has The scale of customs fraud in the United Kingdom that we are discussing this evening is appalling. What sum are we talking about? We are talking about more than EUR 2 billion, which have been missed not only by the EU budget, but also in parts by the United Kingdom budget. Two billion euros! That is almost the amount we spent on Erasmus+ in 2018 – to give just one example – not to mention VAT, which follows, which we have not yet talked about in depth tonight. How could it happen that the United Kingdom did not detect, not take up this customs fraud here? At a time of increasing globalisation and increasing flows of goods, it is quite clear that customs are facing entirely new challenges. And if customs are not only tasked with performing fiscal tasks, i.e. collecting tariffs, but also protecting the internal market from piracy or also protecting internal security, it is quite clear that customs are at its limits here. The national customs authorities are not in a position to carry out all these tasks on their own. We need closer cooperation, better cooperation and better exchange of information. I very much welcome the fact that agreements are clearly already emerging in the Council in the context of customs procedure 42. But that cannot be all! The international gangs are well connected. Why are we not doing this under our customs authorities? That is why we Social Democrats – and we are not doing this alone – are calling for the Member States to make every honest effort here to generate the EU's own resources effectively, but ultimately also to generate their own resources, in order to prevent customs fraud in the future.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: – Mr President, once again today, Theresa May had nothing to say. There was not a single credible or viable proposal. Just more fantasy—Disney—Brexit. Theresa May’s Chequers plan demands the EU to ‘trust Britain’ to follow EU customs rules. They cannot even be trusted when they are a Member State! As the Commission said, the British Government allowed a Chinese fraud network to evade paying customs duties worth EUR 2.7 billion. The Tories are still negotiating with themselves, and the ‘Dancing Queen’ is twirling on the head of a pin to the fairytale tune of Boris and Rees-Mogg – the Brothers Grimm – with their ‘supercalifragilisticexpialidocious’ Mary Poppins Brexit plan. That is something quite atrocious.  We need legally binding proposals that protect the Good Friday Agreement in all of its parts – not faith, trust and a little pixie dust. This is no fairytale, and the British Brexit proposals won’t give Ireland a ‘happily every after’. The Good Friday Agreement is sacrosanct. Damn right it is, Arlene Foster of the DUP, who said that it was not.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I, too, have to comment on the absence of the Council, I think that on such a serious issue as the multi-billion dollar loss in the European Union budget, the Council should have been involved in today's negotiations. And the fact that this is the last point of the negotiations, we have become accustomed to such important points. But I would like to say that it is indeed a great reality that customs fraud is happening, it is not only about the UNITED Kingdom, but unfortunately also about Greece, and there are undoubtedly probably more of these cases.  OLAF has calculated that the loss incurred by the total Union budget in 2013-2016 as a result of duties for loss on textile products and footwear imported from China through the United Kingdom exceeds EUR 2 billion. This is indeed a huge amount, considering that in 2016 OLAF, following almost 300 investigations carried out, recommended the recovery of a total amount of EUR 631 million, so that the EUR 2 billion is indeed a very significant amount.  Moreover, another investigation revealed significant VAT evasion in relation to imports through the UNITED Kingdom, where vat exemptions were used excessively, and only these two cases from the UK caused an estimated loss of EUR 3 billion to the EU budget. Currently, OLAF is also investigating a new understatement case concerning the port of Piraeus in Greece and representing a serious loss of EU funds. It is estimated that it cost Italy several tens of millions of euros in unpaid VAT.  We should therefore really consider how to deal effectively with customs fraud cases. First and foremost, national authorities need to take consistent action against those involved in fraudulent customs evasion and those who have been knowingly involved in laundering the proceeds of this crime. We should also not passively take into account that recovery of outstanding funds normally takes up to 10 years. The Commission should ensure that Member States fully comply with the provisions of the Union Customs Code and make regular estimates of the amount of unpaid duties.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the most recent investigations carried out by OLAF have brought to light cases of customs fraud in European countries. One of them, as has been said, is the United Kingdom, but unfortunately these are cases which are not confined to certain countries, but are illegal practices that are widespread in most Member States. These are frauds which unduly take resources out of the Eu ropean Union budget, which disrupt regular competition between companies and which in some cases even fuel the activities of organised crime.  They must therefore be combated, and in order to combat them, we need standardised and harmonised customs control procedures between The Member States, so that the Member State which carries out less stringent surveillance is not chosen to make fraudulent imports. In this respect, the Commission must ensure that the authorities of the Member States fully implement the provisions of the Union Customs Code.  But I believe that it is now also necessary to prevent this type of fraud, which will result as soon as possible in a definitive VAT system, providing for uniform rules on the collection and payment of tax throughout the Territory of the Union, so as to guarantee more effective protection of the Community budget.

name: Jens GEIER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has To be the last speaker in the last debate of the day is, I believe, a special honour. This must also have been put behind us in his career as a Member of the European Parliament. So that's done for me now, hook on it. Commissioner Oettinger, thank you very much for your overview. We are discussing a case where national competences, namely fiscal sovereignty and customs supervision, bite each other with EU claims, namely the european Union's revenue and the protection of the common market, where they collide. We keep saying, ladies and gentlemen, that Member States are not very careful about fulfilling their obligations to the European Union, and that they prefer to endure breaches of the law rather than hand over competences. I would like to mention the MFF briefly in this context, because we need additional resources in the EU for the increased EU expenditure. However, not all Member States see this as a way of mobilising additional resources. At the same time, however, we are also seeing that the Member States are doing too little to recover the EU's own resources and to protect the EU's financial interests. I believe that we should draw attention to this contradiction in the context of the MFF negotiations. I do not think this casualness is acceptable any further.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, it is a given that the European Union's action to combat customs fraud must be decisive. Allow me, Mr Oettinger, to refer to a classic example of customs fraud which is the Greekisation of agricultural and livestock products. That is, products are imported from third countries and appear as Greek. We have greekization of milk and dairy products, resulting in a drop in the price of milk. We have a lot of imports from Romania, from Albania, from Skopje. Companies bring these products and baptize them Greek, resulting in a collapse in consumer prices. Now we also have an import of French potatoes called Greek potato. Tomato producers in Tymzaki, Crete, complain that various imported tomatoes have now appeared as Greek.  It is a classic case of customs fraud which, in addition to the problems it creates, I think has also broken up the rural economy itself. We need to take this seriously. And you as the Commission. I would ask you whether you have been informed by the Greek authorities on this matter and whether OLAF should, at last, undertake to check what is happening with the Greek mafia of agricultural and livestock products.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr. The Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which it has been I would like to begin by saying that there is no punitive action at stake. It is simply a question of us having to investigate abuses, everywhere. In other Member States, too, there are suspicions, investigations, surveys and results. Nor is it about centralisation, on the contrary! Tariffs have been a source of revenue that has been sought since the founding of the European Union – once with far more, today with about 14% of our total revenue. With tariffs, we relieve the Burden on the Member States by not having to make national contributions in the amount. Customs enforcement is the responsibility of the authorities of the Member States – a decentralised system. Some Members deplore this and find that there are shortcomings in the implementation of the relevant obligations by local authorities. We do not want Commission officials on the ground. However, we want local officials, national civil servants, to fulfil their obligations, in the interests of their budget – they receive 20% – in the interests of customs revenue, indirect vat revenues and in the interests of the European budget. If an MEP, who has already said goodbye and went into the well-deserved evening of work, spoke of measures such as those in the Soviet Union, then I reject this as simply absurd – simply absurd! In general, I note that those who criticise us here have said goodbye to this part of Parliament. But with 'Soviet Union' I do not allow the European Union to be insulted, let alone compare it. We are looking into tobacco smuggling. As you know, we have terminated the agreements with the tobacco industry and we are doing everything we can to reduce or prevent imports of tobacco products that do not correspond to our legal bases from countries such as Belarus, Ukraine and other countries as best we can with our limited possibilities. In the UK case that is at the centre today, we have not only calculated the amount with the best investigation, we have also collected interest on debt, so that, in the end, if the amount can be brought in, there will be no disadvantage to the European budget. I think the good thing about this is that it shows that our fight against fraud is producing results. That is why I can only encourage you: OLAF is your authority and my authority, and whenever you have suspicions, see specific abuses, please give news! OLAF will then be entitled and obliged to make a case out of it, to make enquiries and to avert damage on the expenditure side and the revenue side from the European budget. Therefore, when you, Mr Marias, show that there is indirect fraud on the subject of the reclassification of food stuff and agricultural products, you are giving me specific indications! I will follow them up and then give you a report on whether and how we see this legally. I am interested in your surveys. Good evening!

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: I have received one motion for a resolution pursuant to Rule 128(5) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, Thursday 4 October 2018.

text: The next sitting will take place tomorrow, Thursday, October 4, 2018, from 9 am to 2 pm and from 3 pm to 4 pm. The agenda has been published and is available on the European Parliament's website. The sitting is closed.
